text:
Pours an amber with an amber Malta aroma. Pours a copper golden color. E. 

5985 Polaris ave 
Las Vegas, NV 89118
On draft at the source pours clear amber brown with a thin white head that dissipates. Cardboard, caramel, slight nutmeg notes.

Draught at Hair of the Dog. Copper color, white head. Bitter taste with grapefruit, resin, hops, pine, dried fruits, a bit of wood and malts. Bitter finish with grapefruit, resin, hops, pine, dried fruits and a bit of alcohol. Excellent barley wine.

2013 bottle, at Engine House 9. Deep amber bronze, creamy tan head. Huge nose full of robust hop, roasted malt, and honey...lots of honey. After I took the first few sips, I got carried away for 30 minutes reading the Wikipedia page on Caramelization and Melanoidins and all the chemistry behind the process because I was a bit high and its really interesting stuff. Then I looked up and had a Reuben in front of me and a 6-flight of E9 beers and thought to myself..."Man I love the PNW, what a time to be alive.". Overall, pretty damn good barleywine.

Bottle, release 2015 from Kl&wine merchants Redwood city@: pours copper/amber slightly haze with off-white tan head. Aroma: intense hop profile, malts, with notes of caramel, toasted toffee, burnt sugar...flavor is very similar: malt backbone with notes of honey, caramel, toasted toffee, burnt sugar, supported with hop notes which takes on citruses, with some floral, spicy notes. Body is full, texture soft, carbonation is moderate.

Fat på Omnipollos Hatt. Brunmurken vätska med litet gräddbeiget skum som ligger kvar som ett lock och hänger kvar lite på kanterna. Söt, fruktig doft med massor av torkad frukt, kolaremmar, övermoget äpple, kandisocker, sirap. Dämpad och oerhört len kropp. Låg kolsyra. Massor av kandisocker, torkad frukt, kola och lite lätta ekfatstoner i smaken. Lite väl lätt kanske, och lite rå i kanterna. Större i doft än i smak. En del värmande alkohol, men 11,5% märks definitivt inte av.
On tap at Omnipollos Hatt. A bit hazy amber with a small head. Sweet with malt, dried fruit, caramel, some rye bread and light hay. The body was full and the finish with warming alcohol.
@Hatten 17-2-18 : söt och potent med tydlig ton av russin och råg. Trevlig att smutta på men kanske lite tjatig i längden

Bottle. Murky dark copper brown with a fluffy light tan head. Pine, lacquer, dark sweet fruits. and slight booze in the aroma. Flavor is bitter, pine, turpentine, toffee, and touch of dark fruit in a bitter solvent finish. Medium to thicker sticky body. Old school American Barleywine goodness.

12 oz bottle, into a tulip. Pours dark murky ruddy brown with thick tan head which fades slowly into long lacing. Hefty amount of suspended sediment gathers at the bottom of the glass, should have expected that and poured more carefully. Aroma is rich, creamy, nutty, toasted toffee; sweet, loads of caramel, vanilla, molasses too. Taste is likewise - crisp initial malty sweetness is cut quickly by big dry hops. Caramel and toffee here too, some figs and plums as well. Very easy drinking for the style and abv. Barleywines arent my favorite, but this is great and always worth revisiting at holiday time.

pleasant aroma of plums, dark fuit, raisins, and some vanilla. pours a beautiful hazy amber brown from tap with a quality head. leathery and earthy tastes. super smooth, velvety, and creamy. absolutely delicious. hides the high ABV extremely well.

Pours hazy mahogany with low off-white head. Aroma of caramel, blood orange, toffee, nuts. Taste is initial rich toffee sweet followed by a fairly pronounced, almost medicinal bitter finish. Rich and creamy body with soft carbonation.

Cask days 2016. Dark brown pour, Cloudy, with a big light brown head. Super sticky lacing, and sticky sweet Aroma. Lots of toffee, and caramel, with huge pine resin notes. Nutty, roasty, hints of coffee, boozy bread. Silky and viscous mouth feel, soft carb. Very high bitterness with huge pine resin finish. This is a big beer.
Bottle from share on 11/12. Hazy brown pour with small tight beige head. Very malty all the way through, in both aroma and taste. Notes of caramel and a bit of hops finish this one off.

Bottle, thanks Greg. It poured a cloudy deep amber color with a white head. The aroma was of honey, molasses, raisins, toffee, caramel and hops. The taste was similar to the aroma with more toffee, raisins, bananas, molasses and honey. Really good.
Strong boozy smell. Tons of oak. Boozy. Caramel.  Tasted at my "Variants 2.0" bottle share.
Keg. Hazelnut brown, small tan head. Alcohol, grain, hay, twigs, caramel. Medium body, some sweetness with matching bitterness. Harsh alcohol.
Bottle. Pours a brownish color. Aroma and taste are dark fruits, sweet caramel, and some bitter hops.

Pour at 2016 Eastern Oregon Beer Festival. Aroma roasty and malty, notes of raisins and carmel sweetness, medium mouth feel. Slightly hazy reddish brown with small head. Very smooth richness. Slighty citrusy bitter finish with linger brown sugar and a glow of warming alcohol. Nice!

A fantastic barleywine. Pours a beautiful bright Amber with a thick white head. Smells of strawberry And honey. Taste is thick, with strawberry and vanilla and honey with a very smooth, sweet finish. Had on tap at the brewery.

How: Draught.
Where: Omnipollos hatt, Stockholm.
Appearance: Amber colour with a tan head.
Aroma: Hops, malt, floral, caramel, alcohol.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Caramel, sweet malt, fruit, hops, some fruit, alcohol.

At the HofD brewery in Portland-USA. On tap. Dark bright caramel, cloudy with little off-white head. Nose: eucalyptus, violet flowers. Mouth: dry, clean, more eucalyptus and a bitter frizzy overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from the tap. Orangey brown with off-white head. Caramel malt, light stone fruit, mild hops. Full body.

Pours murky brown with some reddish notes a low off white head. Aromas of caramel, figs, dates, plums, raisins, toffee. Taste is quite sweet with prominent roasted notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation.

Pours murky rosehip with minimal head 
Aromas of dried fruits, wood, cherries, loads of caramel, hints of salmiak
Taste has burned caramel, dried fruits, wooden, very malty , sweet fruits from hops
Medium to full body, low carbonation, medium sweet, low bitterness

Thank you GT2 for the bottle - Hazy dark golden - Sweet malt aroma with some alcohol - Sweet malt body with some hints of dark fruts with some alcohol heat in the back - The malt and alcohol heat goes into the finish - This was good

Rating #700 (wonder how many beers Ive actually tried, yet only rated 700)...pulled one out of the cellar for this moment - 2006 (yes) vintage - pours a beautiful deep garnet with no head and near-zero carbonation. Aroma is candied fruit, booze, caramelized malt, more alcohol, raisin, brown sugars - complex and pleasant, though quite boozy! Flavor is nice as well - dark fruit at the forefront turns into a mix of brown sugar, alcohol, and red wine. Sweet throughout, Im a bit surprised that 10 years hasnt toned down the alcohol just a bit. Oily and slick on the palate - the lack of carbonation isnt a detractor. No hints of oxidization thankfully. Enjoyable - now I need to have it fresh - guess Ill have to head to Portland in 2016!

Draft at Brouwers, as part of the leftover Hard Liver festival. 2014 vintage I cant believe that Im in year 3 of rating, and this is my first experience of this beer. Dark amber pour with a foam ring head. Boozy caramel aroma. Flavor is boozy, bready, raisin, slight bran. Lingering booze, but hardly effects the drinkability. Solid barleywine.

Tap at brewery. 12oz tulip. Cloudy caramel color with thick white head and excellent lacing. Alcohol and sweet nose. Sugar and tart, long lasting punch. Prune and dark fruit. Some funk. Plenty of alcohol. Medium body. Intense and delicious. Glad I dug my claws into this one.
Oranje koper bier met een goede getinte schuim kraag. Ruikt fruitig, tropisch fruit, pruimen, misschien peer. Smaakt heftig pruimen (denk ik) , rood fruit.
Some thick caramelized malt and slight citrus. Pours hazy brown with ok head. Some tang and sweetness. Bottle shared at tasting.

12 oz bottle. 2015 vintage. Aroma is toffee, caramel, molasses, woody, lots of fruity esters--dark fruits, raspberry, lemon, raisin--woodsy hops, earth, alcohol, funk. Headless pour and a murky brown-orange hue with quite a bit of sediment floating around. Taste is bittersweet, savory, sherry-like, licorice, along with most of those aroma deScriptors. Carbonation is very low, texture is bordering on syrupy. Complex and soul-warming wintertime brew.

12oz bottle - 2014 vintage - pours a murky amber with almost no head . Aromas of molasses and dried fruit . Mostly sweet with hints of raisins and and mild bitter finish . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another aged brew from Gene aka Travler. I love Barleywines. I love the aggressively hopped ones even more. Thats why I was concerned that the 3 years of aging that this bottle had undergone would be a detriment. I need not have worried. Doggie Claws still had plenty of resinous bitterness. There was a nice caramel malt backbone in place, but the hops were still dank with pine and grapefruit zest. Id love to compare this to a fresh batch but it was a great comfort to me that this brew managed to retain its hoppiness after so much time.

(Thanks, Gene! "Travlr")

A- Hoppy, pine, caramel.

A- Copper color, hazy liquid, off white head.

T- Pine, bitter, malty.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, bitter finish.

O- I feel like I wasnt as enthused as I should have been after having my first HotD. Definitely more of a DIPA than a barleywine for me. Bottle was a 2012 so 3 years old and it was still a bitter bomb. It was alright.
Malt and mineral smell and taste. Not really impressed by this. Medium body, low carbonation, and mild foam.

2009 Vintage at Toronado SD, exceptionally well-preserved.

American BW as hell. Somehow its still got an edge of piney hoppiness, and the sweetness from the honey is a bit much for me. I can respect why someone would love this beer, but to me its not nearly as compelling as a good bottle of Adam or even Fred.

On tap at HotD. Some people would call this a dipa, aside from the color which is normal bw color. However, thats more about them failing to make a real dipa. This is a true west coast American BW. A little bit of date and booze in there in a nice way. Firmly bitter and hoppy all the way through.

355 ml bottle. 2013 vintage. Pours a murky brown colour with a small foamy head. Very little carbonation. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, licorice and herbal spiciness. Flavour of smooth maltiness, toffee, licorice, wood and orange sweetness. Quite complex yeastiness. Alcohol is quite well hidden. Great. Needs a re-rate from fresh batch.

I loved Adam and I loved Fred, so Im excited to try Doggie Claws tonight. Its a bit warm for something as rich as a Barley Wine, so Im glad that I have an excuse. It may rain and cool everything off tonight. Thats good enough for me.
I set out my snifter and find the guitar that opens most of my bottles, and pry up the cap. No huge aroma from the neck, so I pour the first glass. The liquid is the color of dark caramel, almost no head at all, just a thin bubbly lacing that races across the surface and clings desperately to the inside of the glass. Its clear and clean, and the aroma is starting to make itself clear as well. Firstly, this is hot...boozy. The aroma stings my nostrils as I breathe in the heady, thick scent; a burning incense of clover honey and ripe, honey soaked figs; a piney hops-infused bite adds so much to the sting. -- 
The first swallow is flat, though rich, and yes...very, very boozy. Tasty as hell, though, with the honey and hops both a predominant accent to the brew, a smoky vanilla caramel underlying the two and sticking to my tongue with such a tenacity! Each tilt of the glass coats my mouth with a cloying sweetness, drawing me back, swallow after swallow. -- The lack of any carbonation at all is distracting, but the rest of the beer is amazing. The finish is consistent, and warmer, in this case, is only better for the aroma and not the remainder of the experience. Because of the lack of action, I find it difficult to enjoy at higher temps, but right out of the cooler, its awesome. Id probably try this again, because I wonder that there was absolutely no head and its so flat. Maybe the second time is a charm?
(By the way...the time got away from me and I froze the last bit of my Doggie Claws. This shit, as an FYI, makes a phenomenal slushie.)

I tried to like this, but its the last Hair of the Dog for me. Maybe this is the perfect example of this style, maybe this is the precisely what the brewers were trying to accomplish. I just dont like it. Thick, sweet, honey on the nose followed by thick, sweet, honey on the palate. Thick, sweet taste with absolutely no carbonation at all to cut the thick and sweet. I defer to those with more sophisticated taste, I could not enjoy this at all. I gave it a year on a dark, temp stable shelf and wont be back.

Aroma of apples and other sweet fruits, taste is weak and thin, just not coming together that old, bottle 2013, would like to try a fresh bottle

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the Hair of the Dog, Portland, OR. 2014 vintage. 
Murky mid-brown colour with a creamy light tan head. 
Strong malty aroma with sweetness, hoppy bitterness and dark fruits. Balanced. Awesome flavour... A perfect balance of malty sweetness, hoppy bitterness and dark fruitiness. I'm in heaven... No! I'm in Portland. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 Bottle from my cellar. Pours a light mahogany brown with a suspension appearance of tiny yeast particles. Nose is crystal malt, corn sugar, honey, and booze. Taste is similar with a sweet finish. Tastes like a good 2 year old Barleywine should.
2013. Copper pour. Nose is ash, rotten apricot, paper. Taste is ash, booze, and paper.

Tap at Craftheads, Tokyo. Hazy reddish brown shade. Ring of head. Aroma has cherry, almond, caramel, a hint of chocolate and plenty of hop resinousness. Taste is a slight step down but still impressive, with a nice chewy texture. A tad underwhelming but still very good.

Several pours from a leaking 2004 magnum bottle... but still holding up well!! Pours deep copper, low carbonation. Held up very well in the nose: dates, sweet raisins, sweet desert wine, a tad madeira wine, caramel. Sweet body with bitter notes as from the middle, Taste is toffee, figs, dates... Interesting.
Pours a hazy copper color with aroma of brown sugar, caramel, fig, and honey. Sweet honey flavor with caramel, fig, brown sugar, and raisin. 2009 bottle. This is a great beer.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2015 2013 & 2014 bottles poured into a snifter..amber/brown with a thin off white head..aroma of caramel,spices,lemon..sharp taste with toffee,honey,dark fruit notes..thin,not much carbonation..expected much better.

(Cuvée 2014): Un liquide qui nest pas gâté par la nature, seulement sa mère le trouve beau. Larôme est décente, fruits séchés, mélasse, bois brûlé, fumé, une bonne dose de chaleur et de cayenne. En bouche ça goûte un peu trop jeune, presquaucune trace de madérisation, juste la présence de petits fruits et de houblons affaissés. Le corps est dénudé, leffervescence est absente, très difficile de poursuivre.

Tap sampler at brewery. Cloudy deep Amber, good head and lace. Aroma malt and faint fruit. Taste is sweet and spicy and fruity. Opens with sweet apple and apricot, ranging to banana and raisin its some clove spice. Palate is rich, carbonation moderate, perhaps a touch sharp

Bottle during (mostly) Hair of the Dog beers tasting. Many thanks again Jef!
APPEARANCE: dark blond beer, small stable off white head.
NOSE: alcohol, fruity, oak, nice.
TASTE: alcohol, fruity.
Vintage 2012. Maybe I had a bad bottle. Almost zero carbonation. Burnt brown sugar, licorice and maybe candy cane. It was a little underwhelming as those notes are defiantly muted.

I picked up a bottle of this at Whole Foods on NE Sandy in Portland, Oregon. First off, the label: I like the dark green color and the festiveness of it. Very nice-a. I should also mention this is the 2014 vintage. I poured it into my Ommegang tulip glass. Dark cloudy brown with no head on it after a minute or so. The aroma is sweet and malty. The beer in my mouth is velvety, with almost no carbonation, and sweet with a growing bitterness that sits quietly in the background doing its own thing, not bothering anyone or being out-of-line. Its just there hanging out in its own flavorful way. Overall, an excellent beer (barley wine).

Aroma of old butter, skunky malts, rotten milk, expired caramel and rotten eggs. Big murky brown appearance with a tan thin foam and small lace. Extremely strange milky, creamy caramel and expired whip cream overtones. Strange, old caramel, butter and nut overtones. Overall, Hair of The Dog products have all been absolutely dreadful to me. Something about their yeast component ruins their beers. D rating.
Bottle. Pours hazy dark amber with large spongy beige head, prominent cloves and hops aroma, low carbonation, oak flavored toasted malt taste with alcohol undertones, long finish. Great brew!

Tap at Hair of the Dog. Pours hazy brown with orange hues and off-white head. Aroma of figs, prunes, lots of grain, brown sugar. Taste is sweet, low carbonation, med to full bodied. Overall, very tasty.

aroma of feet and biscuits. Surprisingly lively carb for a two year old beer. Plenty of washed out hop bitterness and typical barleywine malts. Tiny bit of heat in the finish. Nice complexity. Lighter than I expected. Golden color.
12oz bottle to snifter. 2012. Dark amber. Chunky. Huge pillowy head. Huge malt aroma. Huge malt sweetness with a bitter bite.

Draught, 2012 vintage. Pours a hazy reddish amber color with a moderate light tan head on there. Nose has quite a bit of wheat, barley and caramel all mixing together. Taste is slightly sweet and very smooth, and ends up being very warming with a slight bite.

Bottle from a trade, manythanks Kump! Murky amber/orange colour, creamy beige foam. Aroma of peach, apricot, honey, caramel, toffee. Malty base with sweet undertones of brown sugar. Hoppy finish. Well balanced. Very good barley wine!

Bottle: Thanks, Ron. Thick pour; fuzzy, cloudy, burnt tan in color. Opaque, like unfiltered apple cider with little bits of sediment. Very thin, off-white film caps it off. Highly sweet & unattenuated aroma. Deep syrupy molasses, brown sugar, burnt toffee, graham cracker, honey, & a pinch of dark fruit. As expected, sweet on the palate, but not cloying or overbearing at all. Molasses, toffee, caramel, all quite syrupy with a mild, underlying burnt sugar element. Toasty malts with a light alcoholic bite. Warmth brings out more dark fruits; black cherry, candied plum, red apple, & even some pear. A little ash & grassiness towards the finish from the hops, but this thing is malt bomb without a doubt. Heavy body, lots of residue sticking to the palate with each sip. A very big barley wine, in terms of body, sweetness, & alcohol, but despite the intensity in all areas, it remains questionably easy to drink. Really enjoyed this one.

Muddy light brown, ringed white head. Nutty, maple sweet and sweaty socks nose. Bright bronze sweet malt and fading booze burn. Light metallic, blood and soaked pancake finish. Clean enough mouthfeel, not oily or brassy at all apart from the taste.Bottle, Independence Tasting, Cheers Paul for the long haul

12 oz bottle courtesy of JB, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy brown with a large tan head that remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big notes of molasses and toffee, along with moderate piney hops. Figs and fruit are present as well. The flavour is moderately sweet with lots of molasses, toffee and figs paired with a moderate piney, resinous hop character. Malts are complex and elegant, slightly predominating over hops that are generous for the style. The finish is long and surprisingly hoppy with a peppery character. On the palate it is medium in body with a slightly acidic texture and average carbonation. Overall, a great barley wine with very nice malts and surprisingly big hops. 2014-09-11

2011 Vintage
Tasted on 9/8/14 from a 12oz bottle received in a trade. Pours a very pretty, fiery amber with a thin beige head that leaves an average collar with spot of lace in the center of the glass. The nose is toasted, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, honey, and plenty of well-aged hops balancing. The flavor is the same with an added fruity note balancing all of the malty sweetness and bitterness from the hops. The body is very full with a bit below average carbonation, and a long sweet caramel, toffee, honey, and lightly bitter and fruity hops finish.

(old rating ACBF 12) Brown to redbrown beer, dark beige medium head. Fruity aroma of grapegruit, pineapple, red fruit, sweet malts and alcohol. Silky sweet in taste, with red fruit (wine-like) and some hop bitterness in the backtaste. Good.

Bottles shared with Belgbeergeek . 2012 VS 2013 


2012 ; 
Pours coper brown , white head . Smell is sweet, but dusty . Taste is bit metallic , sweet, typical HOTD . Bit bitter , some herbs . 4,1 -------- ; The bottle actually PUKED on me . Upon opening, there came a muddy substance out of the bottle ( at high speed ) , the inside of the cap was completely covered in a thick layer , and the neck was completely blokked with like a Centimeter of .... well, of what ? Rests of the hoppallets ? this should not be in any beer , ever , when it is bottled . certainly not so much, and how the hell did it get in the top ? this bottle was stored upwards since I had it ( a few months I believe ) . This is just groce. I will not calculate this view, If I would , this beer would end up way under average . ---
Pours pretty much the same as the 2012 , but with a darker head . Smell is green , sweatfeet ( it were probably hoppallets ) Taste is bitter , cheese, more hoppyness. Typical HOTD tastes underneath . Bit honey . 
-- a beer that is truly unique by making the biggest HOTD fan look like he was penetrated by an elephant , multiple times . This version really sucked , Not calculating this one too much , because Id like to think it is not standard . Yet if they have the respect to sell a bottle like this , its gonna cost them sóme points !

Bottle thanks to trade with jdb288! Pours a hazy copper brown with thin khaki colored head that leaves light lace. Aroma is whole cone resinous hops, definitely simcoe, then it falls to deep fruits and booze. Taste is more towards the malty sweetness, no bitterness, dark fruit of English yeast esters, nice balance and no booze until it hits your gut. Light carbonation, warming, damn fine.

New Years beer with wild honey, Simcoe and Amarillo. Off-white head on a deep bronze beer. Complex, tempting aroma of caramel, candied cherries, dates, ginger, chocolate, grapefruit; very exciting, complex taste, fruity and malty sweetness in so many layers, exotic fruits, deep and creamy palate, ending in a warm but never astringent alcoholic presence as well as delicate aromatic hops. Another masterpiece of my favorite American brewery and again a contender for the title of best beer I ever had. Man, I wish I could have this any day...

At Hair of the Dog with Taylor, Stephen, Dina, and Rob. Pours cloudy brown shit. Aroma is cardboard oxygen fig, raison, apple. Taste is cardboard, molasses, brown paper bag, oxygen, some fig, sticky. Overpowering barleywine, sweet oxygenated.

Draft at the brewery. Hazy copper color. Big fresh hops with a big malt backbone. Caramel and floral/citrus hop notes. Creamy texture. Medium heavy body. Good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Vintage 2005. Clear amber of color with a weak off white head. An aroma of honey, hops, sweet an weak oxidieced. A flavor of hay, hops, malt and oxidieced.

Draught @ Hair of the Dog

Pours dark orange with a smooth head. Aroma of fruity hops, malts, syrup, sweet toffee and caramel. Taste is sweetish, hoppy and malty with some honey and fruity notes. Finish is crisp malty, sweet and syrupy with some wood, honey and fruits. Quite balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2015 Very murky brown. Aroma is honey. Taste is honey sweet, woody hops, bitterness. Finish and lingering flavour is hop syrup. Nice stuff. Couldnt drink a lot. Overall, lovely mixture of american and english style barley wines.

Bottle, 2011. Pours clear ruby chestnut with a medium tan creamy head that dissipates slowly leaving nice lacing. Aroma is rich malty, chocolate, toffee, raisin, date. Medium sweet, malty, biscuit, just a bit of bitterness. Full body, creamy mouthfeel. ABV very well masked. Nice beer, but not all that complex.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 Pours cloudy brown with a minimal light tan head. Aroma is malts, malts, malts with a little carob thrown in. Taste is a little carob, milk chocolate, and roasted malts. Sweetness and bitterness are well balanced in the finish. Nice.
Cloudy copper light tan head. Lots of toffee and molasses aroma. Toffee with molasses then switches to brown sugar in the end. Citrus hops fighting their way through. Medium body and carbonation.

12 oz bottle. Cloudy deep amber with little to no head. Aroma is of honey, molasses, raisin bread, toffee, prune, and caramel, and light banana. Taste is of toffee, raisin, prune, molasses. Lots of hop junk and yeast in the bottle (like 1/6 of the bottle is crud), but it is a good beer.

Bottle. The look is very very filled with sediment, hops, yeast. The look is murky and some type of orange brown color. The smell is pine, yeast, alcohol, fruits, grassy, pineapple, and nice. The taste is pineapple, fruits, pine, apples, hops, and good.

A- Pours a cloudy, blood orange hue with little to no head.

S- Sweet caramel, dark fruits, brown sugar with a nice hoppy afterthought.

T- Dark fruits, fig, caramel and a wave of piney hops that sweep across the tongue.

M- Thick with low carbonation.

D- Although carbonation was a little low for my liking this is an amazing beer. Extremely tasty.

Bottle share in 2013. Pour is deep ruby with no head. Aroma is of pineapple juice, toffee, caramel, and candi sugar. Flavor is similar with the hops coming out more - citrus, floral, honey, dark caramel. Finish is hoppy and boozy.

On tap at the brewery. 2013 vintage.
Pours a dark brown with light head.
Aromas of candy, dark fruit,and roasted malts.
Flavours are same; smooth, malty, and sweet. Really well balanced.

Also had the 2004 in a 12 oz bottle
Poured a dark garnet red brown.
Aromas of brown sugar, raisins, dark caramel, and roasted malts.
Flavors are rich and similar. Incredible.
9/4/9/5/18

2013 bottle. Pours a very murky brown color with a nice foamy light tan head. Lots of sticky pine in the nose, chocolate and caramel, light citrus, dark cherries and plums, and a nice bready malt note. Nice piney hops up front on the taste, nice dark red fruits, toffee, caramel, and a great earthy flavor coming through.

Sample at Ale Alpharetta. Pours brown, with almost no head. Bitter chocolate is dominant in the nose, with notes of maple syrup and vanilla. Very sweet flavor, with a light bitterness, and a slightly dank finish. Heavy body, sticky, thick, and grainy. Overall, this is a nice, sweet and malty beer.
Bottle from bytemesis - thanks!! Very murky reddish brown pour. Raisin / dark grape, caramel sweetness, graham cracker, maybe a bit of grapefruit. Very smooth and full on the tongue. Excellent!

12 ounce bottle into snifter, 2012 vintage bottling. Big crack upon opening, very highly carbonated. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy ruby red color with a 2-3 finger foamy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty foamy lacing clings around the glass, with a large amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big tangerine, grapefruit, citrus rind, pine, pepper, floral, grass, caramel, toast, brown sugar, raisin, honey, herbal, and floral earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of hop and malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, orange zest, citrus rind, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, raisin, honey, floral, grass, pine, herbal, and floral/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of earthy floral/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, orange zest/rind, pine, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, raisin, honey, floral, herbal, and floral/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice balance and complexity of citrus/pine hops with dark malt/honey flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a moderately slick and fairly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent barleywine. All around great balance and complexity of malt and hop flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.
Tap at brewery. Copper pour with a white head. Raisin, floral, meaty, oak, pine. Medium body with a slightly bitter finish

11% abv, listed on bottom of label. $6.99 for the 12 ounce bottle purchased from El Cerrito earlier today. To pint, it pours a smoggy, hazy varnish dark brown; no head visible, only bubbles, but they had dispersed rather quickly. Aromas of wet tobacco, graham crackers, honey, duct tape, licorice, burnt rubber, elderberries, pilsner malt, sour grass, carrots, sweet onions, grapes, cedar, and caramel. Tastes the same with the addition of topsoil, walnuts, booze, cotton, white chocolate, English yeast, duck fat, and sage. Hibiscus, feta, cinnamon, and hops by swallow. Packs a wallop! Dangerously drinkable. Alcohol crept progressively, but wasnt hidden. Had a slight underlying acidic note hinting at orange peels and limes. Good grief, is there a lot in this little bottle.
Opaque copper colored brew w/ creamy tan head. Aromas of bread, toffee & brown sugar. Biscuity malt flavors with honey. Full flavored & boozy.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2014 Bottle (2013, 11% ABV) poured into a Belgian snifter. Pours a murky/cloudy dark caramel brown with no head, good bit of yeast and sediment towards the end of the pour. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, molasses, toffee, light piney hops. Tasting notes of dark fruit, piney hops, caramel, toffee, big sweetness, a bit of citrus and toast. Very smooth for 11%. Medium body with a semi-dry and slightly hoppy finish, mouthfeel is slightly sticky with low carbonation. This may be the smoothest barleywine Ive had so far, finishes just a hint warm if at all.

Dark brown with dark red very murky. Aroma and taste is dominated by dark fruit. Plums raisins. Some underlying booze is in there. This is on the darker end for a barleywine. I respect what they are doing here and see why people like it but not feeling this one today.
The perfect barley wine. On tap at hair of the dog. Amazing dark pour and strong and delicious.

2008 bottle, decided it was high time I opened this one. Pours a dark brown-amber with a white ring. Rich aroma, sweet and boozy, of dark fruits, wood, citrus, malt, brown sugar, brandy. Taste starts crisp, with citrus, malt, booze, wood, then picks up a big rich sweetness, of dates, figs, brown sugar. Lingering sweet wood and brandy that ends soft. Six years old and still going strong.

Bottle. Dark ruby with no head. Aroma is caramel and toffee with some pineapple and citrus. Taste is caramel, toffee, orange juice, other citrus. Light pine notes on the finish. Unfortunately the beer is totally flat and syrupy. Reminds me a bit of Hawaiian Punch. I actually bought this beer twice thinking the first bottle was messed up, but alas it appears this is a feature not a bug. It's really a shame. Just a little carb would make this a home run.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 Murky brown pour. sweet aroma, caramel, bread. Lots of caramel, fruity, toffee, raisin, Booze is hidden well. My big issue with this beer is the mouthfeel - wheres the carbonation??

Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a cloudy brown with medium beige head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is strong simcoe hop and candy sugar. Light mouthfeel with rich candy sugar and boozy finish. Good.

Year-old, 12oz bottle in a snifter. Pours hazy amber/copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma strong of toffee, caramel, and nutty malts, some floral hops, light dough, and light alcohol. Flavor the same with a very strong malt character and a good balance of everything. Smooth to thicker texture. A good barley wine.

2013 doggie claws. Bottle was perfectly carbonated and poured a burnt amber color with lots of sediment. Nice quarter inch of white head that stayed for awhile. Taste is as the smell with caramel and toffee slight fig. Wonderful beer and one that seems like it could stand the test of time. Well done.
Poured from a bottle it is a a muddy brown with no head. The aroma is very hoppy and the taste is of fig and a sweet after taste

From a 12 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a murky reddish brown with a thin head. Nose of grassy hops and some caramel. Flavors of citrus, mostly lemon, and some butterscotch notes. Very light carbonation. Short bitter finish.

Pours a deep chestnut brown color with two fingers of khaki foam. The nose is heavy on the bunrt honey, earthy hops, raisin, fig and toffee. Palate follows with a big chewy mouthfeel lots of layered flavors; sweet burnt sugar, wildflower honey, citrus, raisin, leather, popcorn... nice bitter edge on the finish.

Type: 12-oz. bottle
Glass: Sea Smoke oversized wine glass
From: Whole Foods in Hillcrest (San Diego), Calif.
Price: $6.99
Purchased: Jan. 4, 2014
Consumed: Jan. 10, 2014
Misc.: N/A

Poured a brown murky color with about one finger of tan head that dissipated almost immediately. Seemed to be a lot of sediment at the bottom of the glass. Minimal lacing on the sides of the glass. Minimal retention on the tops of the glass.

Smelled a potent mix of hops and malts from the get-go. Got sugary caramel malts, brown sugar, Werthers candy, toffee, honey, Amarillo hops (I think), earthy hops, grass hops and some type of liquor.

Tasted so damn smooth from the get-go, really the opposite of what I was expecting. Got Werthers candy, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, honey, butterscotch and buttery malts.

Medium body. Oily texture. Soft carbonation. Long, smooth, warming finish. Alcohol was well hidden. Best part of the beer by far. 

Nowhere as good as I hoped it would be, especially considering the $6.99 price tag on a 12-oz. bottle. Very smooth and a nice sipping beer though.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2015 This rating is for a new bottle (2012 drank 1/20/13). 

Pours looking like maple syrup with depth and a little haze and no head. Aroma is white raisins, prunes, toffee, baking spices, heavy oxidation. Flavor wood, pepper, earth, oxidization, booze. Feel is quite tight and dry. This could go for years before the flavor is ready. But the aroma is heaven. 


Same bottle jan 2015

7-3-6-2-13

Has not improved.  Modest Honey, dust, yeast aroma. Flavor is the same with muted bitterness.  flat and lifeless.  Leaving the rating of the new beer since that is how I guess it is best.

2009 vintage. Rated 1/10/14. Pours unclear, dark orange amber. Small creamy/soapy tan head, slightly lasting. Malty, caramel, Dark sugary, honey, faint hoppiness/pine, some overripe fruit, hint of pleasant alcohol, touch of spice. Full body. Soft, touch oily, syrupy, creamy... beautiful. Very sweet. Delicious sipper.

On draught at hair of dog - 2013 - pours a dark cloudy copper with medium thick head. Nose is of malt, hop, and grass. Taste is very complex blend of sweet malt, honey balanced with hops and pine. Nice and warming.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters displaying a mahogany color, with a modest layer of off white, bubbly head foam, and light lacing. The nose was esters, honey sweetness, caramel, a hint of lemon meringue or zest scent, and a wisp of sea salt? Medium+ bodied with soft carbonation, moderate but muted hop bitterness, a silky smoothness to the mouthfeel, esters that were more of a dark fruit variety, and definite alcohol presence, without the booziness. Nice complexities throughout.
2013 bottle. Dark, cloudy brown. Sweet and spicy, wonderfully viscous feeling. Hard to think of anything wrong with this one. Fantastic.

1/15/2012. On tap at the brewery in Portland. Copper color with a tan head. Floral aromas with malt, light fruit, spices and alcohol. Sweet flavors from the fruit with spices and alcohol burn on the end.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2014 Poured 2013 from bottle to glass on 12/22/13. Reddish brown hue with off white head that dissipated to thin ring. Light lacing. Yeast sediment in bottle from conditioning. Aroma is malt forward with roasted barley, melon, esters, pine, caramel, nutty. Fantastic mouthfeel with light carbonation and full body. Taste is initially sweet with a great bitter finish. Overall this is a wonderful Barleywine that I look forward to revisiting. 2014 from bottle to glass on 11/16/14. Hazy copper brown hue with no head. Very yeasty. Approx half inch of sediment was left in the bottom of the 12oz bottle. Aroma is caramel toffee, ethanol, pine, citrus. Mouthfeel is lacking with a full body and no carbonation. Taste is overwhelmingly sweet throughout with a slight bitter following and an ethanol finish. Overall this batch of Doggie Claws is quite bad. It is still, a bit too hot, and cloyingly sweet (like sweet wort). Overall 2014 is a big disappointment. Hopefully it carbonates and balances out with time.

2013 bottling picked up today at Home Brew Stuff in Garden City... Paid a pretty expensive $7... but oh well, probably not going to see them at any other stores.

Thankfully the new batch shows no overt carbonation problems (neither dead flat or explosively carbonation)... Pours with a 2 finger khaki head atop a fairly clear deep cherry wood brew... nice lacing.

Nose is pretty nice.. toasty malt and malty wort.. bright citrus hoppiness... Pretty pungent hops with warmth... I like this vintage.

Flavor mirrors the aroma but with a light punch of yeasty frutiness that makes me think of apricot.. light caramel and stone fruits.. rummy but in a good way.. big American hops.. but still there is an earthy hop component.

Body is lightly viscous but ever present yet creamy carbonation.. a sipper but I will always want another drink. Very fine.

Crap... I frequently pass on cellaring Doggie Claws because of the random QC issues... This batch is in the cross-hairs right now.... but will it stay there?

RB #s 8/3/8/4/16

Nice brown color. Good heady carbonation. Smells great . Malty very hoppy smell. Very smooth Taste. Sweet citrusy hops. Good stomach warming sensation. Great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Colour is brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, sweetness, hops, malts and hints of toffee. Alcohol, where?
vintage 2006. sweet, round and a little woody, nice barleywine, i would like to taste it fresh too

2012 bottle. I am not a huge fan of barley wines. I first tried this on tap at the brewery last year and I loved it. I bought a bottle and have been cellaring it since, trying hard to forget i have it. I broke down today and drank it. Amazing brew! I wish I had more. Super sweet, smooth, and just a hint of boozey burn.

Bottle, 2007 vintage at hair of the dog, portland, or. Sweet aroma with strong honey notes. Pours dark ruby red with a thin white head and no lacing. Taste is sweet dark fruit that finishes smooth with strong sweet honey that sticks to your palate. Outstanding. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pours reddish amber with low head, aroma is roasted sweet malts and light alcohol. taste is rich malts and nice balance, great finish

2013 on tap at brewery.

A: Full creme colored head with a warm brown body.

N: Forward malt with a good amount of honey and hops. Some brown sugar and toffee. Brittle. 

T: Peppery and hoppy. Less sweetness in the veins. Has a bite, but is well rounded overall. 

M: Sticky and medium bodied. Very nice carbonation.

O: Drifting towards a strong ale, but still well done. One of the best recent vintages fresh.

Wow, what a drink! So smooth! This is one to sip slowly with a friend and share for an hour. On tap at the Hair of the Dog brewpub. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Light head without much lacing. Flavor is fruity and moderately sweet. Big alcohol punch but its not in the flavor at all. Awesome beer. A real masterpiece. Very very smooth.
2009 bottle. Muddy brown pour. Aroma is big and hoppy lots of malty sweetness. Taste is hoppy, caramel... a big damn American barleywine and a very tasty one.

On tap @ Hair of the Dog, Portland. Vertical tasting of 2009, 2011 and 2012 vintages. Pours hazy dark brown with a finger thick head. Aroma is very fruity and bitter, with orange peel and apricots, as well as some notes of grapefruit. Full body with soft carbonation. Flavour is bitter with apricots, orange peel and lots of fruitiness coming together in a long sweet but bitter finish. The 2009 keeps amazingly well, and surprisingly enough comes off as the most hop accentuated. Still not too much difference over the years, and its really just a consistent and superb brew.

2011 Bottle // Purchased Feb 2012 // Sampled October 2013

Deep ruby tinted body with a rich amber, copper and brown body, all with a nice, single centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of amazingly complex scotch, malt, vanilla, oak, brown sugar, bourbon, metal and tons of pit fruits - very nice and ridiculously complex for a smell - even for the style. Full-bodied; Deep dense toasted malt flavours, coupled with tons of hops (still noticeable after 2+ years), earthy and deeply bittering brown sugar and caramel, some pit fruits with a little coffee flavour and a rich, dry, oaky and pine flavour that lasts quite a while. Aftertaste really brings out the complexity with malt, caramel and toffee really showing through with a good hoppy flavour showing some bitterness for a well-rounded flavour. Overall, a great barley wine and one well worth saving - even for 5+ years, it will only get better for the foreseeable future. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Tustin, California on 08-February-2012 for US$5.49 sampled at home in Washington on 28-October-2013 in celebration of running the USMC Marathon here at home in Arlington.

Pours is hazy brown with almost no carbonation but its not that big of a deal in that case. Smell has some grapefruits, a bit piney, dark fruits and caramel. Taste follows on the same path with some sherry, burnt sugar, toffee. Palate is heavy, a bit sweet but not cloying. A full bodied Barleywine that became one of my favorites non-barrel aged. Definitly a sipper.

Good barley wine that held up well as this was a 2011 bottle. Sweet malt and hoppy aroma. Nice deep coppery brown color with a small head. Higher than average weight and mild carbonation. Nice blend of flavors from sweet bready malts to toffee and caramel with a high bittering finish. Alcohol was there but not overpowering. Great sit back and enjoy beer.

2011 bottle. Brouwers, WA.
Barleywine to the tee. Chewy caramel, hops are light, citrus. 
So so clean. Fruity, light sherry notes.
Very impressed with how smooth it is.

Pours a nice deep amber colour, clear with a creamy tan head. Aroma is of caramel with subtle hop notes and some toasted barley. Taste is more sweet than bitter, but is quite balanced. Full-medium body, softer carbonation and syrupy on the palate. Overall a strong barley wine.

2011 12 ounce bottle. Pours a darker ruby with a big beige head of foam. Really nice retention. The aroma has a big nutty, caramel, toffee, ginger, resin, and brown sugar. The taste is huge sweetness with a hoppy bitterness that leaves me thinking this was a big hop bomb at some point. Damn, now I want a fresh bottle to know if it was. Sticky and chewy mouthfeel.

On tap at Hair of the Dog (2012 batch). Hazy red, white lacing. Beautiful cand-sweet aroma of fruity hops and dark fruit. Strawberry, citrus fruits, and a gorgeous malt profile in the taste... wow. Silky smooth body. This one blew me away. Best barley wine Ive tasted so far, and my favourite from Hair of the Dog.
Bottle - Vintage 2010 - Caramel, plum, earthy pine hops and a bit of alcohol. Cloudy amber with a rich off white head. Wild honey, pine, plum and brown sugar. Really well barnacled and nice.

On tap at the brewery. 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2012 vintages side by side I believe. Caramel colored and hazy ranging from light to dark. Malty and sweet aroma with spicy hops and honey. Similar flavor with light alcohol and a full body.

Had many different years on draft while in PDX. Thought they would be listed separately as server said the recipe changes every year. So here are the high points from each. Lots of candi sugar favors, very sweet and fruity esters. Sticky on the lips. No significant alcohol burn. 09 was a little spices, 12 was a little warming, more so than the others.
I had this beer on my oregon vacation a few weeks back. I didnt write down tasting notes, just an overall score, so here it is.
Shared with timfoolery. Great barley wine. A little hoppy, boozy, with honey, clove, a bit of pine, and a lot of dark fruit flavors.

Vertical of 03, 05, 07, 09, and 11, awesomely sent by SuzyGreenburg in a free beer contest because I guessed that his favorite Phish song was the Moma Dance. Also, Andy chipped in the 03. Pours deep amber with a beige head, except the 03, which is noticeably darker. As expected, the hops fade as the vintages get older, and the big, rich malts begin to come across as slightly more sweet. The hops in the fresher vintages come across almost piney. The 03 was a whole different beast altogether, with rich fruity notes and light oxidation that wasnt at all present in the 05. All were good, from the still hoppy 11 to the perfectly balanced 05, to the oxidized 03 that honestly seemed like a completely different recipe. Good stuff, all around, and really a perfect beer to set down for a few years if youre interested in learning what age can do to beers.

On draught at Hair of the Dog. 2012 vintage. Deep amber color. Sweet, citrusy, pungent hop aroma. Viscous mouthfeel. Citrus caramel taste with very intense yet balanced hop bitterness. Warm, sweet, and slightly oxidized on the finish.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours hazy burnt orange with a small offwhite head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, dried fruit, wood, little alcohol. Flavor is malt, sweet dried fruit, wood, candy sugar, hops, little booze. Full body, smooth mouthfeel, soft carboantion, some warming alcohol in the finish. 100613

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Hazy deep red with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, alcohol and a little spicy honey. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. Smooth. 100613
Bottle. Hazy dark amber with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted and toffee. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, toffee, hop, little dark fruit, thick, oak, tobacco and medium bitter.

Bottle from Whole Foods, San Diego. Nice creamy head with excellent duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich caramel, candy sugar, fruits, nuts, pine, malt and hops. Rich and creamy palate. Thick as oil.
Nice barley wine with strong taste of honey and some hints of peach. It is a nice dessert beer.

2007 bottle at the brewpub.  Reddish brown pour.  No head.  Candy aroma along with some honey.  Thin mouth.  Taste is flowery and sweet.  Sugar, candy and some toffee.  Hints of hops are still there even 6 years later.

2012 Bottle. Pours a nice dark amber with a lovely finger width of off-white foam. Aromas are hops, honey, burnt caramel, bread, alcohol and roast. Flavors are right along lines of the aroma, however, they seem a bit understated and sometimes hard to pull out. I get liquor soaked orange peel, citrus hops, breads, toffee and roast. Palate is just a tad bit overcarbonated for how I like my Barleywines, but that soon fades given a little time and temperature. Overall, a very solid American style Barleywine with upfront hops and limited sweetness.

2010 bottle. Aroma of fig, brown sugar, honey, hotd, caramel. Pours murky amber, loads of off-white head with great retention that leaves behind irregular lacing. Taste: really nice. Some oxidation, great balance of sweetness with an appropriate level of citrus hop bitterness at the end to cut in and keep it from being cloying. Unlike the 2012 bottle, this is well-carbonated. Full body, sticky texture. Overall: rich caramel sticky sweet goodness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle consumed in 2013.  Dark copper, hazy (sediment jumped up a bit when I opened this lively bottle), beige head.  Aroma of toffee and burnt sugar, raisins/prunes, leather.  Flavor is deeply malty with more toffee, dark fruits, tobacco/leather, warming alcohol (but not hot), some nutty/biscuity notes.  Very nice.

355 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you pushkinwow! Gusher! Pours hazy deep golden with lots of yeast floating around. Head is big, frothy goldenish white and slowly dissipates while leaving some thick sticky lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and fruity with caramel, prunes, raisins, alcohol, toffee, biscuits, honey, grapefruit rinds, lemon zest, sweet dark bread and hints of floral perfume. Taste is sweet, bitter, malty and fruity with biscuits, caramel, toffee, golden syrup, toasted malts, sweet dark bread, pine needles, charred wood, vanilla fudge, grapefruit rinds, grass, resin, figs, dates, raisins, honey, alcohol, leather and hints of dried apricots. Mouthfeel is soft, creamy, silky, tiny astringent and full bodied. Finish is sweet, bitter and malty with caramel, toffee, sweet dark bread, honey, grapefruit rinds, pine needles, resinous wood and lots of dried dark fruits. Very nice heavy beer!
Rating #300. Pours dark brownish red and hazy. Aroma is plum, brown sugar, dates, and cabernet. Taste is dark fruits, burnt sugar, molasses, figs, and a sherry like booze flavor. Complex yet smooth.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2013 Tap @ HOTD. Mahogney color with a creamy dense off-white head. Super fresh hop aroma with notes of caramel and brown sugar. Light sweetness, some caramel flavor, citrus and some light toast. Very enjoyable barleywine with some hop flavor.

Bottles 12oz., 2006 and 2012 vintages.
2006: Pours deep amber with no head. Aroma is of madeira, fruits, chocolate. Taste is of cardboard, oxydation, fruits, warming alcohol, madeira, metal, spices, bitterness. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Good. Nearly over the hill. I guess a 5 yo bottle would have been better. Vintage 2012: Pours deep amber with almost no head. Aroma is of fruits, malt, green apple, sweetness. Taste is of fruits, sugar, bitterness, citrus, caramel, warming alcohol. Palate: Full bodied, sticky, very sugary. Overall: I would have though that the fresher hops would have balance that one for good results. This is not the case. I prefer the oxidated bottle (OUCH!). (2012: 6.3.7.3.13)

Really good barleywine...super well balanced with a lot of flavor.  Palate of dark fruit, hops, booze, some oak, and maybe a little tobacco.  Dry sticky finish.  Note, this was 2011, so aged about 18 months.

bottles shared by tom 10101, thanks! 2006 and 2012 vintages tasted side by side. this rating focuses on the earliest version by appreciating the hereafter rationale: it is ready to drink and that majority of buyers will enjoy the product relatively young. pours hazy copper without a head. chocolate, dark fruits, awkward spices, off-apples and cloying caramel, some prunes, few garbagy and earthy notes. soft to flat carbonation, medium body - syrupy, cloying, short grassy-spicy-peppery finish. 2006 vintage: 7-2-7-3-14. not one i will seek for, neither for the declensions..

Bottle (12 oz) 2006 and 2012 vintage, side by side. Both from Daniel, thanks! 

2006: Clear amber, no head. Aroma of Madeira, fruits, sweetness, caramel and slight herbal notes. Taste is moderately sweet with caramel, fruits, Madeira and cardboard. Moderate to heavy body. Sirupy. Warming alcohol. No flat, but pretty damn near. Lack of balance. No drinkability, even for the style but quite complex. Not bad, but I wouldnt seek another bottle of this. Far from a top-10 BW.

2012: Clear amber, no head. Aroma of green apple, sweetness, fruits and hops. Taste is moderately sweet with chocolate, fruits and green apple off-flavor. Moderate to heavy body. Sirupy. Warming alcohol. No flat, but pretty damn near. Lack of balance. No drinkability, even for the style and not super-enjoyable... I wasnt able to finish my glass. 3-6-6-3-13

Bottles of 05-07, and 09-11 courtesy of blipp at a tasting at Andys.  Various ones poured anywhere from a clear ruby tinged brown (03) to a murky and muddy brown (11), some with a bit of a yellow beige head, some with no head. Newer  ones start to slowly develop a bigger hoppiness.  03 was full of sweet old plums and prunes, loads of oxidization.  Warm and chewy, cocoa dusted fruit leather, a bit warm but very gentle with the alcohol.  Sweet warm umami into the finish.  Lovely stuff. Really neat to try all of the different versions.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on April 4th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a cloudy caramel.
Aroma:Aroma mostly of caramel 
Taste:Light bitterness, medium caramel.
Palate:Medium body, light aftertaste.
Summary: A nice barleywine, I need to start drinking mine a bit younger so I can get more of the hop flavor.

2003 through 2011 vertical odd-year bottles shared by blipp at tasting with RB crew.  Ill start by saying Barleywine is really not my thing so my rating probably reflects that.  All years, except 2003 pour murky brown with thin off-white head. 2003 pours the color of soy sauce. Minimal carbonation in all years.  Thought 2011 was a bit harsh and boozy but flavor evolves with age and 2003 was much smoother; caramel, alcohol and some fruits.in the flavor.

12oz bottle into snifter.  Really cloudy brown, no head, looks almost flat.  Aroma is somewhat bland, a bit of malty sweetness. Flavor is odd, starts out nice and malty sweet, but the finish is herbal and soapy, really odd.  Nearly flat.  I thought i would love this one, but Im not impressed.

2011 Vintage on quite possibly the last cold day of winter. Cellar temp. 1 finger head formed, faded fast. Dark amber appearance. Very bitter on the nose. Smells like an IPA versus a barleywine. also nice touch of raisins and ginger.This is really nice. Insanely bitter, not too sweet and not a hint of booziness. Spicy as well.
2012 Vintage on tap at the brewery. This continues to be my favorite barley wine. An incredible balance of hops, malt, sweetness and alcohol that all merges into one single taste of goodness.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 2012. Thanks Marcus! Pours is hazy brown with almost no carbonation but its not that big of a deal in that case. Smell has some grapefruits, a bit piney, dark fruits and caramel. Taste follows on the same path with some sherry, burnt sugar, toffee. Palate is heavy, a bit sweet but not cloying. 

A full bodied Barleywine that became one of my favorites non-barrel aged. Definitly a sipper. Need to get some more bottles.

Two words: No carbonation. Bummer. Still, it smells quite nice with a hefty dose of aromatic hops so I venture further. So yeah, nose is like a good DIPA, hoppy and malty. Taste is similar, but with malt taking over. It is cloying a little but it must be because they is no CO2 to push it forward... I can see the potential really, too bad this one didnt carb up...

Pours mahogony amber with a silky cream colored head. Nose or dark fruit, citrus, caramel, and toffee. Taste follows. Medium body is creamy. This beer is impressive. But as impressive as doing the review on handed on an iphone while holding a seven week old child also while being buzzed somewhat quick.

A: Brown amber, with a soapy bubbly head. S: This was definitely aggressively hopped, pine punches you in the nose, with some butterscotch, caramel malt, pilsner malt, a touch of honey and molasses, with the hops still rolling around. T: Dark caramel malt, grapefruit, brown sugar, kind of odd and confusing. M: Crisp with medium carbonation and bitterness from the hops. O: Its good, its strange, but I think I would like to visit this one when its older.
On tap. Amber pour with an off white top. Scent is caramel with a hoppy edge. Taste is fruity and sweet with a bitter finish.

12 ounce bottle. 2012.  Pours a darker amber with a small biege head.  Aroma of caramel, fruit, pine, and alcohol.  Taste is caramel, dark fruit, spices, toffee, and alcohol.  Will age my other bottle.

2011 Bottle from Frank. Pours a murky honey orange color with a huge 4 inch white-orange head that fades to a small cap. Smells of brown sugar/toffee, honey, and huge aromas of citrus zest/pine. Taste is of brown sugar, honey, and malt mixed with a nice flavor of citrus zest and pine hops. Moderate carbonation makes for a smooth and slightly sticky mouthfeel. Overall, this is a very good barleywine with a very nice balance between malt and hops.
Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a little head. Aroma is malts,  pepper and fruits. Flavor is sweet fruity caramel with great malts and a perfect boozy finish.  Wow. So good.

2009 bottle...pours reddish amber with a tan head. Aroma brings aged yeast and sweet and almost tangy malts. Flavor has developed so well bringing smooth but still sweet malts. The 2010 bottle brings perfumey hops as well and there is sediment floating in the bottle.
Reddish orange in color... Sweet brown sugar aroma.... Flavor is sweet brown sugar, toffee and caramel notes throughout, minimal hop bitterness on palate... Delicious

The beer has gotten good reviews however the longer I drank it the quicker it wore out its welcome on my palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Being a bottle conditioned ale, you have to pray to the carbonation gods prior to opening.  If you score good carb... the brew will be much closer to perfection (4.3) than the score given here.   The carbonation will be tiny tight bubbles and they will give the barleywine a brighter feel while highlighting the hoppiness of the brew.  Tasting more like a triple IPA with that honey sweetness (think Alpines "Exponential Hoppiness")

When the carbonation is not present.... Doggie Claws is much more viscous with little to no hoppiness.  Mahogany in color with classic Barleywine maltiness made even sweeter by the Mt. Hood wildflower honey thats used.  The alcohol is completely hidden by the overly sweet taste.  Still pretty tasty but a 12oz bottle is more than enough for one session.

Has a great sweet malt, fruit and caramel with alcohol. Taste is similar but very smooth for a Barleywine, outstanding beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Murky caramel brown with fair, creamy, beige head / Bright but peculiar nose of pine, weed, turning grapefruit, and caramel / Full body, moderately sweet with chewy sugars, curious citric tartness like grapefruit juice was squeezed into glass, with otherwise good balance including some biting hops and bitter finish / Flavors of caramel, seemingly rancid grapefruit, and cut pine / There is something just not right about this.

Bottle. 2012 edition. Translucent apple cider brown pour.  Aroma is strong, but hard to describe exactly how it smells.  It smells sweet, with some muted amarillo hops.  Flavor is amarillo hops, pineapple, and caramel.  Finish is bitter.  Flavor is not bad, but this is definitely not a session beer.  Probably should have aged this one.

Serving: 2008 12 oz. bottle from JCB.  Thanks Jason!  It pours a hazy and viscous dark copper color.  It struggles to get a small tan head and the head doesnt last long.  The nose has lots of fruitcake, raisin, and dark caramel.  The flavor is on the sweet side with lots of dark honey, dark bread, and a nice lingering bitterness.  The finish is very long.  Full bodied and oily on the tongue with very low carbonation.  The up front taste almost reminds me of a mead.  Very tasty stuff.

Bottle, thanks a lot Craig! Dark amber with tiny bit of head. resinous caramel aroma, toffee, slight sherry, some oxidation. Similar taste, resinous, caramel, oxidation but not unpleasant, sherry fruits. Sweet and slightly bitter. A fine beer.
In bottle. Pours a beautiful amber colour with a lacy beige head. Aroma of candy sugar, alcohol, pine, grass and caramel. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Great!
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle thanks to Jerry. There were notes of Toffee, caramel, fruity alcohol notes. Very nice, thanks for the taste.

Bottle shared at Mikeys Christmas party 
Appearance: Hazy dark amber with a small off-white head, no lacing 
Aroma: Sweet caramel, dark fruit, pine and brown sugar 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, dark fruit and piney 
A great beer. I think it was and 05 but Im not sure.

Taken from my BA account, reviewed on 2/26/12

Live tasting 12oz. Bottle, 2011 vintage into Duvel tulip...

Appearance; pours a mahogany copper color with less than a finger of foamy light light copper colored head.. Retention is minute, with just a thin ring sticking around the edge of the glass... Lacing is essentially non-existent with just one spotty web stuck to the side of my glass...

Smell; starts off with a slightly bready aroma, all kinds of winter spices, raisins, prunes and figs...

Taste; slightly bready with caramel and vanilla hints of cinnamon, nutmeg... Notes of raisin and prunes sneak in... Alcohol becomes more prevalent as it warms, but it certainly doesnt detract from the flavors of this brew...

Mouthfeel; just a touch of carbonation, and you certainly wouldnt know it by looking at the beer which is nearly still in the glass... Full medium body goes down smooth... 

Overall; a great Barleywine with a lot of complexity that I am sure would only become more pronounced with age!

Tap at Hair Of The Dog, Portland - 06/11/12. 
Obscured dark amber with a thin off white head that soon clears to the edge.
Slight sour tones on the nose, pine, sweet sugars, toffee.
Tastes of sweet candied sugars, caramel malts, pineapple, light trace of bitter grapefruit, slightly tarte, dark sugars and toffee.
Full bodied with very fine carbonation leading to a warming alcohol finish. Excellent on the palate. Decent.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Sampled at GonzoIllinis Birthday Party (Western Springs, IL). Happy Birthday, Tony! Pours a richer deep copper brown pour, good haziness, with some orange glowing edges and bottom. A frothy tannish head remains as a thicker ring, decent lacing. Aromas offer caramel, toffee, and toast. Some oxidation, gentle dry earth, toast, dustings of oranges and gentle fruit. Nuts, orange marmalade, wet paper. Initial is gentle medium body, offering toastiness, sweet caramel, toffee. Gentle dryness, earth, and toast. Some wet paper, gentle spice, and toastiness. Some good toffee and dark chocolate elements, linger firmly, gentle spice. The middle is the best part of the beer, rich and flavorful, touches of gentle toas, earthy smoke kiss, with earthy dry finish, lingering toast, sweetness, nuts, and gentle fruit. Really just a rich middle makes this beer amazing. Great aged offering here.

Pours a dark mahogany maple brown with a nice head. Nose is cherry wood, with an oaky alcohol smell as well. Its a sipper. Taste is fruity and sweet with notes of oak and alcohol. Carbonation is soft and texture is heavy. Finish is sweet, a well crafted barley wine. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours a muddy brown with an off white head and sweet aroma of caramel and hops. Taste is sweet, of dried fruits, caramel, hops, and toasty malt with a strong, warming, long finish. Complex brew with a lot of flavor throughout, very nice

1 finger caramel/ivory head with plenty of lacing on the glass, viscous caramel color that seems to absorb light. Aroma of candy, brown sugar, and a slight hoppiness. Tastes strongly of brown sugar and caramel with a nice hop bitterness to keep it from being cloying. Thick, creamy mouth feel with just enough carbonation to keep it dancing lightly on the tongue. 

A fantastic beer that just goes to show what an obsession with quality and ones craft can lead to. This beer may have a better, but I havent tasted it yet.

A - Pours a cloudy amber-brown with a finger of frothy khaki-tannish head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of sweet toffee and caramelized malts, brown sugar, some grapefruit, citrus, and pine hops, dark fruits, and a bit of booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of lots of sweet toffee and caramelized malts with some grapefruit and citrus hops and some hop bitterness, and a bit of sweet dark fruits. Through the middle, some pine and grassy hops come through with some more bitterness alongside some brown sugar and some more sweet caramelized sugars. The finish is a mix of rich sweet caramel and caramelized malts, grapefruit and resiny pine hops, hop bitterness, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet, bitter, and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Big rich and bold malt character, but the body and hop really balance out nicely. Fantastic barleywine.

12 oz. bottle served in a Deschutes tulip. 2011 vintage. Big thanks to mfavoino for hooking me up with this guy. 

A: Pours a murky dark brown color that resembles a dull penny. A thick head forms on the pour. Light tan colored and about two fingers in height. It takes a while to die down, but it leaves thick sheets of sticky lace on the glass.

S: Definitely on the hoppier side of the barleywines Ive had. They have a slight resin smell to them with some residual burnt sugars and a malty sweet ending.

T: The taste is just as hop forward as the nose. Resiny and grassy hops are the main hop flavor profile with a nice pale malt and whole wheat bread crust malt backbone. There is a nice flowery sweetness and a green bitterness on the finish. The booze is barely present.

M: Medium bodied with above average carbonation for the style. It makes it easy to drink and with a ton of flavor this is nice.

O: An easy drinking and flavorful barleywine is always great. The booze isnt noticeable at all and the flavors are pretty solid. Ive got another one in the cellar and am excited for what a year or two will do to this as Id like to see the carbonation die down and the hops ease back a bit.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle at home. Pour is murky copper with a one-finger, off-white head and great lacing. Big caramel, raisins, toffee, grapefruit, pine, brown sugar, and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is sweet and malty, yet nicely balanced with hops; figs, vanilla, wood, prunes, orange peel, candi sugar, toffee, and a light nuttiness in the flavor ending lightly bitter. Creamy mouthfeel with medium-to-soft carbonation. So much malt, but not too sweet with a beautiful hop presence, especially for a three year old beer. So well-balanced and what a nice body. Extremely easy to drink for 11.5%, and such a nice beer, I could literally drink this all night.

Bottle. 2009 vintage. Pops much louder than expected and pours all foam. Set the bottle and glass to the side and the bottle continues to gush all over. Yikes! I decide to give it a go any ways. Color is a deep copper with a tan head. The aroma is actually nice, lots of caramel, toffee, and some alcohol notes. Very sweet flavor that is dominated by the caramel notes. Some bitterness towards the end.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, caramel/toffee, & grassy hops; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, honey, molasses/syrup, spicy hops, and dark fruit; Finish is slightly bitter with some alcohol; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, well made - very good.
12oz bottle at tasting room in Portland. Had the 2007 batch - amazing palate and distinct honey notes. Beautiful beer!

2005 on tap at HotD tasting room in Portland. Pour is slightly cloudy and deep amber. Lovely hoppy nose with dark fruits. Off white head with nice lacing. Thick, warm mouthfeel. Malty, hoppy and sweet. Wonderful stuff.

Ive been looking forward to drinking this one.  It has a dark amber/brown colored body with an off-white head and an aroma of sweet caramel malts with a hint of traditional, hoppy, American Barleywineness.  It has a light, mature, complex, almost aged and insanely respectable flavor.  I could drink this all night long.  It helps that, because of its awesome mellowness, you cant tell at all that this has such a high alcohol content.  I cant imagine how much smoother this beer will get with some real age under its belt.

2010 bottle thanks to michaelinwa.  Pours a murky and very dark amber color with a thick cream colored that lingers a long time.  Sweet aroma of caramel, red fruit, citrus, pineapple, and honey.  Taste lots of fruity and honey character.  Not as sweet as I expected based on the aroma.  Fairly strong bitterness.  Honey comes on really strong in the finish and there is a moderate alcohol burn.  Nice body and and oily texture.  Carbonation seems a bit high for a barley wine though.  Overall, a complex and great tasting beer that I have to knock down a bit due to the alcohol burn and way too high carbonation.  Still worth checking out.

This is how barley wine should taste! Dark amber colour with creamy off white head that lasts. Amazing aroma of hops, cinnamon, cloves, honey, dried fruit. Tastes marvelous. Dried fruit and malts, with nice bitter hops. Excellent stuff.

Pours a hazy gold, aroma of sweet malts and butter hops, balanced and delicious. Taste follows, nice barleywine

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep impenetrable amber, nice thin head and lacing. Invitingly sweet aroma. Really well balanced - nothing stands out; not bitterness nor maltiness. Slightly under-carbonated, but I just don't care. Dangerously quaffable.

Bottle shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike!

The appearance is dark brown with a thin head that leaves just a little lacing on the glass.

The nose brings a heavy dose of sweet malt, along with caramels and alcohol.

The flavor is quite sweet, with flavors of toffee and caramel chews soaked in alcohol. A nice, slow sipper on a cold day.

Medium to full in body, with alcohol content masked pretty well, given the 11.5% abv.

Not as complex or wonderful as Adam, but a very good example of the style nonetheless. I would definitely drink this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-20-2011

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2013 2011 vintage

Pours a dank murky brown with a creamy beige head that sticks around. Aroma is intense of huge sweet caramel and grapefruit citrus, bitter pine and raisin - definitely can tell it is on the fresher side. Taste is incredibly sweet - butterscotch, toffee, grapefruit, dark fruits and honey. There are some slight floral notes as well. Lighter body than expected - medium and chewy. 

Overall this is fantastic, the best American style barleywine Ive had. There is a big fresh hop presence but does not over power.

Cant believe it took 4 years for me to get around to rating this. Bottled on numerous occasions. Current rating is a 2010 vintage (2 years old). Beautiful amber color with a frothy white head and plenty of lace. Aroma is caramel, clove, cinnamon, vanilla with the honey showing through. Flavor is still quite bitter with the age. Flavor is malty caramel with toffee and honey. Finishes quite dry with a lasting bitterness. Definitely a sipper that improves with age.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2014 
35,5 cl bottle vintage 2009 @ home. Rated on 28.05.2011.
Aroma has some fruity hops and sweetish malt typical to American Barley Wines. Rather rich palate. Flavour is sweetish with caramel, some hops, resin and fruits. A bit too sweet for me  and actually this feels a bit thin for an 11% ABV beer. But good stuff still with a perfect balance.

After a year I realised the joke in the name of this beer.

2011 bottle. Pours a dark mahogany color with a beige head. Aroma still has a decent amount of pine and grapefruit, but I get lots of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, brown sugar and sweet malt. The flavor follows the nose, still some subtle grapefruit and pine left, with lots of dark fruit, toffee, brown sugar, caramel, sweet malt and a little alcohol. The body is full with an oily mouth feel. Overall a really tasty Barley Wine.

Bottle, 2011. Pours a deep brown with slightly tan head that doesnt retain for very long. Aroma is malty, rose, slight raisin notes. Taste is more dried fruit, malt, boozy and tiny hop profile. Overall, this one was rather hot for not being BA.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: 17 May 2012, bottle. reddish brown, faintly hazy, steady bubbles, thick, foamy head. nose is sweet, raisins, powdered ovaltine, wet grain, and some alcohol. wow! full body and moderately fizzy. like fermented raisin juice. there is a sweet, raisin flavour up front with a slightly harsh alcohol finish. red fruit, wet bread, lots of huge flavors, though not a hoppy barley wine. fantastic!

Drank this out of a magnum at DLD, bottle was from 2004. Poured a slightly hazy golden color with a slight off-white color. Flavor was surprisingly still a bit hot, a bit rough around the edges. This beer was still very interesting, and found it an entirely fascinating attempt at aging a beer (magnum?) must try!

0.355l bottle courtesy of Meilby and shared with The Kristiansandsmafia. Looks like a blurry copper-ish golden cloud with a soft sidesticking bubbly head. Looks amazing. On the aroma its quite up there on the sweetness with tones of sticky caramel, sweet rum raisins with some dried fruits and a subtle hint of chocolate. Not extreme, but fantastically melted together. Its softly carbonated and has this sticky thick texture in the mouth. Flavors are lovely sweet with yellow rum raisins, wood, chocolate, sweet caramel, dried red fruits and a thin hint of alcohol-flowers in the finish. Big thanks for sharing! 30.03.2012

Bottle 2011 pours dark nice head  smells tastes honey dark fruits caramel resin not much booze. Tastes the same but crisp with a dryness to it. Nice fizz on tongue. Really solid beer should have got more then two.
12 ounce bottle from Bine and Vine via my beer broker. Great head, lacing, and mouthfeel. Lasting bitterness but not overly boozy considering the ABV.

Very nice deep copper pour with a ridiculously blooming head that takes up most of the glass, and takes forever to recede.

Aroma of stewed red and brown fruits with a resinous background.

Taste of caramel, toffee, candy sugar, resin, plum, cherry, kumquat, date/fig, and even a bit of kiwi. Very resinous, almost endless finish. Body is somewhat syrupy, but not overly so.

Definitely one of the better barleywines Ive sampled.

355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20101022.
Pours clear copper color with small head. Aroma of ripe fruits, hops, candy sugar, caramel malts and some resin. Flavor of dark ripe fruits, caramel malts, mild toffee and wood. Excellent.

2006 bottle shared by a friend. Opaque brown pour with a thin beige head. Malty nose with notes of toffee, caramel, honey and dark fruit. Malty flavor of toffee, honey, candied fruit and chocolate with some earthy hops in the finish.

Bottle. Vintage 2005. Pours a hazy copper with a small off-white head. Aroma is dry and hoppy with honey, stale bread, dusty notes and a slight oxidation. Flavour is sweet and stale with honey, liquorice, dark fruits and molasses. Bitter finish with a liquorice note, and alcohol lingering. Overall good and well-aged; the oxidation was just perfect. 30.03.12.

2005 and 2006 bottle at tasting, thanks Enjoyit. Pours dark amber, no head to speak of. The 05 is still rather hop forward in the nose - piney, citrus, slightly oxidized hops. Also a huge maltiness with caramel, dates and raisins. The 06 is more malt forward and has a more rich and complex caramel side to it. The oxidation that is present in both really hits the sweet spot where it adds to the complexity without adding an off taste. This stuff tasted sooooo good. Heavy, heavy sweetness throughout - big caramel, fudge, dates, white raisins and a decent hoppy bitterness to balance it out. Very mellow and harmonious, just a pretty fucken solid American barleyed wine, perhaps the best Ive had.
Klebriger Beginn, leicht muffig, süß. Hefenoten, geringe Herbe, die Malzigkeit unterliegt meist der Süße. Nicht ganz ausgewogen, ziemlich schwer. 12/9/8/8//9

Bottle 355ml vintage 2005 @ Geokkjer
Pours cloudy deep brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, dried fruits and caramel. Taste is heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with a long sweet, fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Head: beige, small 
Colour: amber/caramel 
Smell: sweet caramel, toffee, bit of hops, vanilla extract 
Taste: herby in the start, sweet sticky alcohol, malts, candy sugar, dry, dropy/anisy like end , very good !

Date: March 22, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: footbalm Description: Opaque brown pour with lots of head, lacing that covered the entire glass and some sediment.   Aroma was hoppy, honey, alcohol, and floral.  Taste was honey, sweet malt, hoppy, slight alcohol and a mild piney bitter finish.  Very smooth and medium bodied.  2005 bottle.  Thanks again to Eric for another great bonus beer!

Bottle from Texas Liquor, Carlsbad. It pours cloudy deep brown, with a thick white head. The nose is pine, resin, dark fruit (currant, raisin, red grape), caramel, toffee, leaf and honey. The taste is caramel, pine, resin, hay, leather, nut, honey, dark fruit, coffee, grass and leaf, with a big, boozy finish. Full body and moderate carbonation. A bit too much booze for me - it would probably taste better with some age on it.

(draught) pours a slightly hazy ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of passion fruit, banana and kiwi, caramel and straciatella, with hints of tobacco and cornflakes. flavour is mostly the same, tropical fruit over a caramel and straciatella base, cornflakes, treebark, alcohol is hardly detectable. heavy-bodied with soft carbonation.

Dark red / brown beer, beige head. Aroma very fruity, grapefruit, raisins, floral, and caramel. Quite alcoholic. Flavour is rather sweet malty, ripe dark fruits and caramel. Finish quite hoppy, ripe fruits, with some nice lingering hops bitterness. Nice!
(From cask @ 5th ACBF, 2012. Thanks for sharing, 77ships!)

2011 vintage from the bottle. This pours very dark brown, looks almost black until you hold it right up to a light. Aroma is candied fruits, raisins, with some fresher pine and citrus notes. Surprisingly little in the way of alcohol for an 11% brew. I love this beer. The flavor is similar to the nose, which is a very good thing. There is a great caramel raisin start to the flavor, followed by notes from the hops of tropical fruits and grapefruit. This flavor lasts into the long finish, which balances the sweetness present.
