Cask & small sample from a 5 yr. old bottle @ ACBF 2012: dark brown with a slight bordeaux hue and a tanned head, smell is pretty much pure grapefruit hops, very hoppy, taste is sweet caramel, dark fruits, strong malts, brown sugar followed by an almost DIPA like fruite grapefruit hops blast in the finish (lovely but a bit contradicting & too much for the style for me), slightly preferred the 5 yr old version because it had gotten most of the hops out of it, fresh the body is slightly jammy & grainy hoppiness, old just jammy

Draft @ 5th ACBF 2012. A dark red/brown colored beer with a beige foamy head. The aroma of a lot of red fruits, with sweet malts, and notes of hopes. The taste of red fruit, malty with nice hops.. The aftertaste is sweet, moving to bitter with notes of alcohol.
Draft @ acbf. Aroma is huge hop, big caramel, more hops, spices. Flavour is huge hoppy bitterness, with an even big malt sweetness. Awesome balance.

2011 vintage. On tap at HOTD Brewery and Taproom. 3-oz. taster. Sweetish, heavy caramel aroma w/ strong hoppiness coming through as well. Dark cola-like w/ a perfect unbroken ring of lace. Sweet deep dark flavors, so complex. Medium to heavy bodied and quite sticky. Fresh, young, and feisty. This one will grow up to be an exceptional barleywine.
Flowery aroma, grainy. Very bitter. Something special like chocolate in the taste as well.

Cute rocky lil head, reasonably lasting with a lil lace clinging. Clear, dark amber ruby hued brew. Nose of alcohol, bready, grainy malts and some dark fruits. Body is mostly full, nice soft carbonation, oily on the palate, manly. Surprisingly sweet malts with fruity backing, faint raisin and plum, earthy woodsy notes, lil booze, heated. Strong finish, warm but juicy. Hmm. Bottle marked as 2003. Props to whomever hooked me up with this one!

3/III/2012 on cask @ ACBF (Moen) - BB: n/a (2012-181) 
Clear ruby red to brown beer, no head. Aroma: very fruity, strawberries, raspberry sorbet, milk chocolate, some yoghurt. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: sweet start, pretty alcoholic, ripe fruits, chocolate, passion fruits, lots of pineapple. Aftertaste: sweet ripe cherries, bit sugary, nice balancing hop bitterness, which lasts pretty long.
Got some expectations from this one... Reddish orange beer, with a very big head. Nicely hopped, with some nice yeasty touch to the brew. Good biterness. Pretty good beer.

Dirty straw color with a 2-finger head that falls to a quarter inch over top. The nose is very hoppy. Nice citrusy orange hop. Big malty base giving me hints incredibly strong bread, caramel, and figs. The flavor is all about the malts. Raisin sweetness overlayed with bready character dominates.

Keg at ACBF. Deep gold. Some citrus, plus goodly hops & malt on the nose, hints of orange. Dry & peppery at first, then some sweetness coming through, then a bitter dry finish with hints of sweetness & pepper.

Pour yikes lots of yeast buddies and partially gushing with huge beige head. Aroma very good citrus, pine, tropical fruit, caramel, toffee, bread. Taste pine, citrus, resiny, hops, sweet caramel, toffee, bread, light apple. MF medium chewy body mild carb. Interesting but not sure if as intended still surprisingly good.

36cl, Vintage 2005, at 10.5%Vol, exclusive American brew, from Beershop Alvinne Moen, very complex brew, malty/sweet and slightly alcoholic/floral, not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, good head, very good Winter brew, yet very expensive!
Shared with gkost, and ryan, poured a light ruby color, aroma of caramel, and pine.  Real nice beer overall.
Only my third barley wine but this is amazing. Very well balanced with aroma to match. Does a good job of masking the alcohol with a sweet aftertaste that begs you to drink more.
Sampled at an esbls tasting.  A well hopped nose.  This is really good but just a bit young.  Age would make it even better.  Very nice fruit and rich malt.  So good!
2011 Vintage. 11% alc, Original gravity = 1.106, Final Gravity = 1.022. This is a very rich ale. There is a thick mouthfeel without being syrupy, smooth dark winter ale.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2014 â09 on tap at HotD. Airy cap settles to concave lacing and thin scarce bubbles along top. Colour is hazy deep amber. Aroma of hops, caramel, and Brussels sprouts?!?! Oh wait, I think the guy sitting next to me just burped. So, great piney hop and caramel aromas. This bitch sticks to the glass good. Great caramel and raisin/plum flavors. This is super duper. I would molest it.

2013 on tap at brewery. Hazy brown, almost no cap. Aroma of brown sugar, raisin, hops. Taste is sweet and slightly bitter.

Poured into a snifter. 2009 vintage.

4.5 A: Unlike a lot of HOTD Ive had, this is plentifully carbonated and perhaps a bit too much so. Transluscent just-darker-than ruby red color. A full three fingers of creamy/frothy off-white head. Retention is nothing short of amazing for a beer this big. Plentiful lacing left behind.

4.5 S: This is still hoppy as hell. Really wonderful aroma on this. Tons of herbal hops with pine undertones. The barleywine underneath all the hops is toasty with caramel and plentiful fruitiness in the form of apple and overripened peach.

3.5 T: The taste, however, is a bit unrefined, though this is still good overall. The hops seem to be in an awkward state at the moment. The flavor is herbal as well. Caramel with toffee and plenty of light fruitiness. 

4.0 M: Heavier medium to lighter heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Good creaminess.

4.0 D: I think I should give this a go fresh...or aged longer. I think I might have drank this at a bad time. Oh well.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-15-2012 00:11:17

2011 vintage

Pours dark amber with a pretty good sized foam, two or three fingers. Head retains. Good carbonation. 

Very malty, dark red fruit smell. 

This is a real mouthgasm! Caramel, red fruit in the taste. Really sticky. A bit of pine. Its pretty damned good, Im looking forward to aging some of this.

12 oz bottle. 2010 vintage, enjoyed 2012-01-10.. Hazy, amber liquid with thick, small to medium off-white head. Aroma of pine, caramel, grapefruit, resin, honey and simcoe hops. Taste is light to medium sweet, medium bitter, malty and hoppy with notes of caramel, pine, resin and fresh hops. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Really nice and hoppy for a barley wine.

Bottle. Pours a very dark maroon color with a nice, frothy white head. Cherries in the aroma. Some malt as well. Cherries and raisins in the flavor. Sense of alcohol but it all blends together very well. Solid brew.

Aroma of brown sugar/ vanilla, toffee. Really nice. Appearnce is reddish brown with a thin off white head that fades quickly. Taste is sweet, malt, caramel, vanilla. Palate is thick and chewy with a warming finish. Overally his is super solid.
Bottle @ Stumbling Monk. Hazy dark brown. Thick unshakable head. Burly hopped up aroma has leather and lots of texture. Fruit and flowers sprout from moist spring soil. Yielding pineapples.

Bottle, 2011. Pours a dark brown with a white head. Smells of citrus grapefruit and some farmhouse notes. Tastes a medium to heavy bitter with a medium sweetness. Its interesting, but not particularly good. Grapefruit and raisin, with toffee. The palate is a bit rough. Finishes cloyingly sweet, and bitter.

355 mL bottle from 2008.  (Thank-you David - the beer of the night.)  Hazy brown with a small beige head.  Huge aroma of caramel, booze, spice and ice cream.  Huge flavour has herbs, sweet caramel, fruit, honey, and a hint of alcohol.  Big body.  Outstanding.

Bottle.  Fanatastically surprising.  Pours an oily amber that recedes to a small ring with not much lace.  Aroma is big citrus hops, slight booze, woodiness, and creamy caramel.  Very piney hops citrusy hops, malt backbone, warming booze, sticky goodness.  Alcohol is very, very well hidden.  This is an awesome brew.

Bottle. A Thick and sticky sipper of a barley Wine.  A very complex sweetness that dominates this brew. Can taste the hops a bit with a light bitterness throughout. Some alcohol burn at the end after it has warmed up. Solid Barley Wine but the sweetness is overkill for my taste.
A little to top heavy with the carbonation, I loved the hop profile. A must have for anyone and great for cellaring. very grape like

2009 bottle poured into a tulip.  I may rerate when I drink my 2011 bottle.  This was definitely good but I did not get the advertised "intense hop character"  Beer was highly sweet with a little alcohol warming.  Honey is definitely present.  This is good but not an easy drinker with the highly sweet finish.

Light golden brown with an off-white head, leaving good amount of lace. Aroma is pineapple, hops, caramel, figs. Taste is honey, caramel, resin, tropical fruit. Slightly creamy on the palate, somewhat bitter finish with a touch of lingering sweetness.
12 oz bottle. Roasty aromas. Dark almond color. Thick creamy head. Roasty caramel tastes. Good barley wine!

Bottle courtesy of thome50.  Gusher!  Burnt amber in color, hazy, full of trub and carbonation.  The aroma is pretty thick with skunky pine hops, sticky caramel malt, and fruit - an odd combo.  Syrupy malt profile, toasted malt, dark fruit, pine/citrus hop bitterness.  Sticky malt and mild hoppy finish.  Palate a bit messy with the over-carbonation.

This beer has an aroma with some caramel, leathery, and some candied sugar. The appearance is burnt mahogany. Little to no head retention. Tinge amount of lacing. The palate is medium and lingers a bit. It has a nice overall complex. Delicious and different from other barley wines I have had.
2009 bottle thanks to beerlando, syrupy, spicey but still with a dry finish. Honey sweetness

2011 - A thick, murky and dark brown beer with a permanent crest of cafe-au-lait coloured foam.  On the nose it is sweet, glacee cherry sweet.  There is a fresh pine woodiness lurking amongst the brown sugar in the aroma also.  Again it is sweet in the mouth With definite cherries, fading to raisins fruit notes.  It is thick but light and puffy, which I like.  There is a definite hop presence too, especially when its aerated a bit in the mouth, leaving a strong dryness in the throat.  It is full of a real barley flavour which I have encountered rarely,  husky and grainy.  Its got some warmth in the finish too but that is really the only sign of the 11.5%.

Bottle of 2011 Vintage. Pours a deep chestnut brown color with a thick layer of bubbly tan head. In the nose, theres lots of hops resin and caramel along with some rum, raisins, vanilla and orange rind. The taste begins aggressively sweet and malty with a strong dose of brown sugar, toffee, dates and honey with a shot of black cherry and citrus. Toward the end theres a little bit of resiny hops bitterness followed by more caramelized sugars. The alcohol flavor is very subtle and does a good job of balancing out the malt sweetness. The mouthfeel is full-bodied and creamy with a mildly sweet and boozy finish. Very enjoyable fresh and should only get better with age.

Best barelywine Ive ever had. Gorgeous mixture of malts and hops. Nice piney, floral aroma of european hops and malts. The flavor starts with a bouquet of floral hops, pine, and potpourri, and comes in with some nice bready malt flavors. The finish is very sweet with flavors of caramel and honey. Excellent, excellent brew. I wish I had 4 to drink!

Bottle from Valley Farm. 2010 bottle. Medium amber in color. Sweet candy aroma. quire a bit of hops in the nose as well. Sweet and floral up front. A bit of dark fruit and candy sugar, along with a little hoppiness. Alcohol is well hidden.

On tap at the brewery as part of Walking the Dog.  2010 version.  Deep color and khaki head.  Lots of great hop here on both the aroma and flavor.  Very good, but maybe i was expecting too much from this.  The flavor was complex with some deep dark fruit.

Not bad, but still disappointing.. No carbonation, which seems odd. Aroma is a little too sweet for my liking. Taste is a little flat. Appearance is a little like pond water. That said, its still not bad, just underwhelming.

BOOM! Big Beer! Wouldve given it an even better score had I noticed it was a gusher before half the beer left the bottle and therefore my mouth. What I did get had a thick, creamy, foamy, frothy, fluffy, billowy light tan head that lasts all the way down and some lace. Color is a cloudy amber brown. Aroma is yeast, caramel, toffee, hops, honey, fresh leather. Flavor is like nose but with sweet and bitter standing out most with enough tang to balance and then other flavors too fleeting for me to identify. Soft full, round body and excellent carbonation. Finish is like flavor, fairly long, and only a hint of alcohol.

2010 bottle from hannont. Dark amber color, with tiny chunks of yeast. Figs and dried tropical fruit and citrusfruit in the aroma. Red berries. Oily hops. Thick mouthfeel. Malty sweet flavor, alcoholic and massively hopped, with dried red fruit and citrus. Nice one!

(From JB84)  The introduction : Mega gusher, pretty much like the eruption of the Iceland volcano Eyjafjallajökull.   The look: Dark orange color with a huge head.  The nose: Shy aromas of fruity hops with caramel and honey biscuits.  The taste:  Hops and sweets malts are there but in a quiet way.  The mouthfeel: Body seems to be less than medium.  Carbonation is too strong.  Texture is just wrong, not the type that you expect from a barley wine.  The finale:  Few bites from hops and sugar from malts.  The conclusion:   Too bad, we had a contaminated bottle.  These are things that happen.  However, it was not a disaster. This shows perhaps that this beer is a blast of flavors.  Looking to drink this beer again.

Bouteille de 12oz. Merci Patrick et JB84. Gusher orange pas de mousse. Le nez est de houblons, fleurs blanches, miel. La bouche est chaude avec du houblon et du miel. Nous soupçonnons la contamination. À reboire.

(2010 edition)Thank you Jeff!!!!!!! Mmmmmmmmmm.My first hair of the dog!!! Coppery honey brown with a slight fog and a fluffy white cap. Massive peachy hop aroma that comes across sweet. Beer somehow just transformed into liquorish apple cinnamon thing!! How did that happen?!?!?! Slight caramel, massive malts all of it yum!! Taste is massive!! Peach bomb with wood and spice. Crap I cant stop smelling this it is soooooooo good.  Sweet malty caramel, hints of coffee balanced so nicely with the bitter sweet hops. Flowers, slight honey, maybe cherry, hidden wood. SMOOOOOOOOTH!!! Goes down fast. Fawk this is mind blowing!!! Peach-smooth-malty-sweet-awesomeness!!

Auction.

One of the best Barley Wines Ive ever had.

Aromas of brown sugar, caramel malts nad toffee. Taste is similar , but smooth and alcohol tasting. Add some figs and dates and BAM!

Picked up at the Matt / Doggie Claws release November 2010. In line early just after opening at 10AM. Held on until this moment. Excited. Smelled it and its fucking awesome. Solid bright deep orange amber with a small compact light tan head that lasts a long time. The aroma is just stupidly good. Massive hops. Peaches, nectarine, orange, sweet honey, strawberries, hint of sweat, maybe mint, some biscuity malts I think, berries, very light caramel, excellence. The taste is no slouch either. No ingredient mess. Amazing flavour - yea, a lot of the same things Ive found before but just that much better - like eating at a high end restaurant - the use of better ingredients makes the occasion special. Citrus, Nectarine big time, orange, spice, no alcohol, not pine but somewhat sort of there, peaches, softness, caramel here and there but nothing dominant. Great subdued sweetness that flows smoothly across my taste buds. AAAAA tastes so good. Why do I only have one small 12 oz bottle? Man, I fucked up by not buying more of these. Great smooth soft feeling, long soothing after taste.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours clear reddish amber with a foamy light tan head. Lots of herbal and lightly grassy hops on the nose, on top of a dry malty base. Same hop profile in the taste, with a dry maltiness, medium roast, dark chocolate, and a lightly bitter finish of hops and heat. Cocoa lingers in the mouth on the long finish. Wow. Lovely.

Full amber, cloudy, with a billowing custard head.  Aroma is huge orange citrus with... more orange, and some lavender flower garden.  Hints of deep caramel underneath the bomb of hops.  Lots of sediment, just the way I like it.  The head is beautiful and thick by the way.  Thick-bodied.  Flavor is a big candy sweetness up front.  Lots of medium-darkness caramel.  Plums.  Light-to-moderate orange, apricot, hints of berries, all relative to the sweet malt.  Sappy bitterness that sticks to the palate, but doesnt linger.  Carbonation is frothy on the palate.  Very sweet, perhaps too much.  Aroma and the head are the 2 best attributes of this beer.

2009 on Draft. Aroma: Caramel, floral hop
Flavor: Like the aroma:  Caramel and floral hop.
Comment:  Good but I didnt rate it as highly as my accomplice.

(Bottle (2009) via trade with pantanap, thanks Kan!) Murky, brownish-amber, unfiltered sweet cider appearance. Thin yellowish-beige head recedes to a thin ring around edges. Aroma of piney hops, caramel, brown sugar and candy malt. Mouthfeel smooth and soft, low carbonation. Light dabs and a light syrupy film inside of snifter. Flavor of piney hops over caramel and warm brown sugar with a bit of earthy organic-ness (the honey?) and brief appearances by chocolate and licorice as it warms. Warming ABV presence, but well-integrated into the beer.

Bought from brewery and opened into pint glass.  Looks thick carbonated apricot.  Lightly tanned frothy 3 finger head.  Smells like yeasty alc hops.  Tastes like a pretty strong and thick barley wine with a haze of hops.  Definitely some fruits and thickness on the palate.  Overall 8.5 of 10.
A beautifully blended BW. the hops and malts compliment the honey flavor beautifully. I find this beer is best with 2 years on it.

Pour medium brown with a thick creamy head. Moderate carbonation. Powerful malty, slightly hoppy aroma. Very full bodied and sweat, sweat, sweat. Complex flavors with fruit a touch of spice. Fairly bitter for a barley wine. To me this is just too over the top. You have to like this extremely big, sweat, malty style. I have a few put away to age for years, but not something Ill come back to unless its aged.
Intense and delicious.  Plenty of malt backbone to make it really sweet, but the alcohol kick and incredible yeast profile balances this out to be one incredible brew.  Bravo.

Bottle 2005, big thanks to MaxxDaddy! 
Pours a murky amber-brown colour with a tan head. 
Powerful sweet aroma of caramel, honey, raisins, fruity hops and alcohol. 
Sweet flavour of caramel, honey, raisins fruit and bitter fruity hops.
Sweet honey, bitter hoppy and alcohol after taste. 
Reminds me a bit of Nøgne Ø #100.

2007 12oz bottle shared by drowland, pours a clear dark amber with a nice off white head and lacing, aroma is very sweet with a good amount of malt, caramel and a hint of dark fruit, the flavor is extremely smooth with a good amount of caramel and malt in the finish, extremely enjoyable.
At hotd with Carla. Pours ruby red with off-white foam. Smells subtle and sweet. Tastes of brown sugar, beets, and mulled oranges with spices.

Year made: 2010 poured into a Darkness snifter. 
A- I opened the bottle and turned away for a sec which was not very smart, the beer started flowing out of the top, such a waist of beer. Luckily not a lot came out.  Really carbonated beer, from the pour 3 finger frothy head, that dissipates slowly, dark burnt orange almost brown color, a lot of sediment on the bottom and flowing throughout the beer, really nice lacing.
S- Really nice aroma, nice hoppy aromas, pine citrus, as well as spice and malt.  Looking forward to trying this one.
T- Really well brewed beer, pretty sweet, slight bitterness, nice hoppy notes, pine and citrus some grapefruit, big malt presence, nutty, bready, some spice notes as well, really tasty. 
M- Medium mouthfeel, well carbonated, smooth drinking, crisp finish.
O- Solid brew from HOTD, love what they do with their beers, making them unique and different from other beers of the same style.  Really impressed.

On tap at Hair of the Dog tasting room, pours translucent dark brown / orange with lasting white head. Aroma is a mixture of dried fruits, honey, pilsner malts and dark berries. Flavour of dried fruits, honey, malts, dark berries and booze. Lightly carbonated, nicely sweet but not cloying. Like drinking luxury.

12/23/10. 2007 12oz bottle courtesy DalzAle! Huge dark fruits, molasses, brown sugar, sweet caramel, and more on the aroma. Really awesome! Sweet brown sugar with dark fruits, a touch of sour, and a hint of malty bitterness on the flavor. Quite nice!

botte... murky medium brown, dark off white head, really nice finger cap, really nice lacing... nose is really malty, dark molasses and caramel, nice hop finish... taste is very malty, tons of caramel, super easy to drink, no alcohol, dark fruits, super easy to drink

2006 traded bottle...still had the $3.95 price sticker on the cap! Very still pour with only a thin ring of bubbles around the edges. Nice clear copper-bronze color. Pretty big aroma of sweet malt that instantly has me thinking "barley wine." Syrupy mouthfeel and definite honey sweetness. Once again the taste just says "barley wine." Theres also some heat from the booze. Pretty nice.

2004 bottle @ home, courtesy of ratman197 (huge thanks Ratzz!) Dark maroon/brown appearance with a tan head. Sweet, brown sugary, fig, slightly floral, quite sweet malty nose. Brown sugar, caramel, light toffee, brown malty, lightly floral, roasty flavor. Caramel, brown sugar, lightly bitter, mostly sweet malty aftertaste. Slightly boozy but actually very smooth. What an amazing brew! Thanks again Ratzz.
2009 bottle. Copper orange body; thin head. Rusty, flowery aroma. Light sweetness, very smooth and mellow. Characteristic HotD/PNW hops. Very nice.

Beautiful Pour caramel apple color, Toffee nose hits you before you get to the glass, Incredible balance considering the ABV, Great Mouthfeel, Insanely drinkable but the ABV hit me afterward. This is one of the best beers I have had. I continue to be impressed by Hair of the Dog. Cheers

2010 bottle. Aroma is full of rich, sweet malts; caramel and toffee, bready.  Up front floral hop aromatics, pine and citrus (grapefruit), some alcohol.  
Pours a hazy amber with a massive rocky off-white head, very good retention and lots of lacing.  Thin layer of head persists to the bottom of the glass.
Flavor is a nice mix of chewy, sweet malts and resiny hops.  Rich caramel and toffee are balanced out by flavorful pine and citrus hop flavors and a warming punch of booze.  Leaves the lips and palate coated with some lingering sweetness and hop bitterness.
Full body with moderate carbonation, coats the palate.

Truly a big time barley wine. Comes in the small bottle and obvious why. This beer is powerful. The malts are very smooth and the hit of the alcohol is great during the winter months. A great sipping brew.
UPDATED: SEP 15, 2011 Pours a cloudy orange with a fluffy beige head. Aroma is dark fruit for days. Taste is sweet and fruity, crisp and hoppy. I liked it a lot.

12oz bottle thanks to suzygreenberg. 2009 vintage.
Appearance : Clear shiny amber with medium white foamy and creamy head. Nice look.

Aroma : Very nice malt with great piny and resinous hops. Nice sweetness. Notes of honey and floral hops. Very rich.

Taste : Great sweetness with nice hops. Gorgeous malt with a nice sweetness on the finish as well as a nice bitterness. Light alcohol but not that much. Great notes of caramel with dry fruits and light hints of wood. Floral hops. Great fruits.

Overall : Really nice beer. Immensely rich with an awesome sweetness. I like that the hops are not too citrusy/piny nor too resinous. Really elegant and quite different (as most HOTD). Wow really nice beer. My type of Barley Wine.

Bouteille de 12 oz, édition 2009. Arômes très complexes de malt mielleux, deau-de-vie, de houblons fruités et de fruits jaunes. Robe orange brûlé, belle mousse qui tient bien et effervescence assez active. En bouche, la bière montre une très belle texture moelleuse et maltée. On retrouve une bonne dose de miel plutôt sucré et une touche de céréales légèrement caramélisées. Une forte amertume de houblon résineux et fruité tente, tant bien que mal, déquilibrer les sucres résiduels. Lalcool est peu apparent. Très bon, mais, dans le style, je crois que je préfère la HoD Fred.

10 bottle served in HotD tulip.  Pour was burnt orange (Hook em) with a big white head.  Lots of carbonation.  Fresh, this ale is a whole nother animal..   The taste is more like a DIPA with a large caramel malt backbone that is offset by the mellow fruit flavored hops.  Reminiscent of  Double Jack or Pliny the Younger with all kinds of caramel, toffee, and honey flavors just freakin outstanding............

Pours hazy orange with white head, aroma has notes of caramel. toffee, some dark fruit, touch of oxidized hops.  Taste is sweet vanilla, chocolate, touch of toffee, dark fruit, some oxidized hops, some nice sweet fruit and a nice caramel finish.  Delicious.

2008 bottle shared by boody.  Thanks!  Clear copper pour, with no head, no lacing, no carbonation whatsoever.  Aroma is all sweet malt, big hops, light oxidation leading to sherry notes.  Quite nice.  Taste is interesting...some sweet malt, caramel and toffee, with nice bitter malts at the end.  Quite nice.  Slightly thin mouthfeel. Not a bad beer.

Bottle thanks to daknole.  2010.  Dark burnt amber pour with a big frothy white head/  Lots of carbonation.  Aroma was miles of caramel malt mixed nicely with a boatload of fruity American hops.  Nice mix.  Like fruity candied hops.  Flavors were right on par.  Long hints of sweet caramel followed by a big hop kick that lasted.  Bitterness was light yet present.  Pleasing.  Mouthfeel was full, carbonation relaxed after a bit which led to a smoother finish.  Light heat.  Maybe reminded me a bit of Old Double Bagger...  Very nice.

(12oz bottle for Bruery Provisions).  Pours hazy copper color with massive beige head and ample carbonation.  Aroma has lots of caramel malt, maybe a little hop spice and plenty of pine.  Taste is very sweet with a hop bite on the end.  Full bodied with sticky texture.  Finish is slightly bitter, but smooth.  Nice beer, but very sweet.

A: The pour is amber in color with a short lived khaki head that is initially about a finger high.

S: Great caramel and brown sugar aromas to the nose.  Surprisingly, still a fair amount of hop content.  I pick up some grapefruit and tropical fruit aromas.  Sweet and malty, and excellent.

T: Caramel, molasses, and brown sugar provide a nice sweet base.  Some definite fruitiness in the form of pineapple, grapefruit, tangerine, and peaches.  A slight warming alcohol feel comes into play as the beer warms up.

M: Medium to full in body with a moderate carbonation and smooth feel on the tongue.

O: One of Hair of the Dogs best beers.  I look forward to it each year.

2010 bottle.  Muddy, light brown with a massive, creamy head.  Bright citrus hop aroma hits immediately, followed by honey.  The hops are pleasantly upfront in the flavor, but mix with the very sweet taste of honey somewhat awkwardly.  This is a very fresh bottle, and it would benefit from age.

2005 bottle. Clear copper body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is dark fruit, raisins, prunes, caramel and alcohol. Flavor is raisins, dark fruit, wood, alcohol, burned caramel, light hops. Dry on the palate, soft carbonation. Nice lacings.
Nice hop choices, not too heavy despite its abv. It went up against some other barleywines at a tasting and held up well.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2015 3-26-2009
Pours a murky brown color with a dismal off white head that dissipates instantly. Smells of citrus brown sugar caramel a bit of alcohol. Tastes of caramel and citrus, lots of lemon comes through. Some alcohol mixed with a mild astringency and some yeasty flavors round this one out. Sweet almost cloying but offset with the lemon and alcohol. The body on this is thinner than youd think. Carbonation is very low. Mouthfeel is syrupy and sticky. Based on the other reviews I may have gotten a bad bottle. I will revisit this one as I have a couple more bottles, but as is this one is going to clean my kitchen sink.

1-25-2014
2013 Bottle from craft shack shared with HoppasaurusRex. 
Pours a murky brown color with a couple of hollow bubbles floating on the top. The aroma is stagnant molasses, brown sugar, malt syrup and honey with hints of earth and citrus. The flavor is sweet sugary unfermented wort with hints of citrus. Sticky syrupy mouthfeel, marginal carbonation with a medium to thick body. This beer went down Todds sink. I dont know why I cant seem to find a decent bottle of this beer, but I might just be done with HOTD altogether.    


4/3/2015
2005 Bottle from Mikes Barleywine tasting, thanks for the opportunity! 
Rich caramel light pitted fruits mild oxidation. A 10 year old bottle that held up better than my previous 2 attempts with newer vintages.

12oz bottle from 2009. Pours a hazy amber, good carbonation with little head and settles to nice lacing. Sweet aroma, citrus, hops, some raisin and banana. Smooth, full bodied and nice carbonation, sweet in the mouth, nice complex finish that keeps on going with some bitterness.

Bronzish orange - fairly clear/translucent. good retention on head, top of beer still layered with foam far into the session

smell is very sweet caramel and toffee with pin & grapefruit hop aromas. A bit of booziness. smells like oranges with a bit of lemon zest sits on top of the booze when swirled.

tastes of pine resin, slightly cloying sweet. sticky and rich. hops are subdued by caramel sweetness. some orange flavor with citrus sweetness

this beer is smooth and semi0thick. touch of syrupy sweetness

definitely easy to drink but getting close to the sweet side of things

I dont tend to pair barleywines with food... maybe a bleu cheese or stilton cheese.

Anise, dark cherry and plum on the nose.  Barely opaque dark copper with off-white head.  Elements of leather, jammy fruit, slightly cloying on the finish with alcohol warmth on the aftertaste.  Smooth and medium bodied.  Residual sweetness sticks to the tounge and leaves a full filling.

From notes:

2008 vintage received as an extra in a trade and consumed fresh.

Pours a dark, murky golden orange/swampy brown color with burnt orange hues and a one finger off white head that quickly fades. I poured half of the bottle out and there are large chunks of yeast floating in the glass. This beer looks pretty awful.

Earthy soil like aroma with hints of leathery malt, dirt, alcohol solvency and lots of earthy piney hops.

Medium bodied with lots of alcohol sweetness up front. This is counters by a blast of resinous, earthy hops that give off a nice bitter, dry pine needle flavor. There is also a decent amount if citrus flavor especially grapefrut and orange peel. This is again countered mid-palate by a prominent earthy, leathery malt presence. This beer Looked and smelled like swamp water but the malt flavor is actually quite pleasant and there is a great balance of earthy, bitter and sweet flavors.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a chalice.  The beer pours a medium to slightly dark amber color, with a moderate white head that lessens, but still remains for essentially the duration of the samples consumption.  The nose shows strong English medium-high and high crystal malt; brown sugar, raison, and candied prune.  As the sample appears to have some age on it, hop notes have fallen away.  The palate is full, in-your-face, and unmistakably that of a Barley Wine-style ale.  Raison, slight sherry notes, caramel, molasses, and a slight tinge of character-adding alcohol come through.  Residual sweetness levels are high, coming quite close to being cloying.  Carbonation is nicely calibrated.  Mouthfeel is full, without being inappropriately filling.  The general flavor profile of the sample is not unlike a tawny port.  The finish is long, sweet, and full of English crystal malt character.  Overall, an example of the style that is pleasant, but highly aggressive, and close to being unbalanced.  Enjoyable.

2010. Very deep amber in color with a long lasting beige head, good lacing. The aroma is very rich with lots of malt, caramel, Christmas spice, light alcohol, dark fruits. Silky palate with loads of nice fruity notes,Brown sugar, A light burn on the finish, maybe a touch of hops. Full body, a little sweet right now, give this one some time....a year or so, then I will re-rate. I bet this will be great.

12 ounce bottle. 2010 vintage. Poured into Duvel tulip. Side note: Heard this vintage was extremely carbonated. 
 
APPEARANCE: Foam started to rise out of the bottle once the cap was removed. Massive beige, cream-colored head is thick and frothy. Head has extremely long duration, which eventually begins to settle slowly and unevenly  in a rocky manner.  Effervescence everywhere  unlike some common ales that may have a steady stream of carbonation rising, generally, from the center  you can see the carbonation trails on the sides of the glass about every half centimeter. For the thickness of the beer, effervescence is quite rapid; although it does seem as though the carbonation is battling the viscosity in its quest to the top. Actually the carbonation trails appear to be rising at several different speeds. The massive amount of carbonation rising to the top seems to suspend quite a bit of sediment all throughout the beer; slowing down the fall of the sediment towards the bottom. General color of the beer is deep caramel. Ridiculous amount of sediment at the bottom of the glass. Most of the huge sediment beginning to settle at the bottom is a pale yellow/mustard color and looks like butternut squash flavored baby food. The amount of sediment seems equal to about a quarter of a small jar of baby food. While I would generally consider this much sediment somewhat detrimental to the overall appearance, the appearance of this beer is one of the most complex I have ever seen. 
 
AROMA: Strong hops and caramel aromas, which are very well-balanced. Grass and citrus hops, as well as some subtle pine and earthy notes. Malt is huge amounts of toffee and caramel. Faint note of candy (eg, salt water taffy). Some dough, though largely covered by malt sweetness. 
 
TASTE: Citrus (more orange than lemon) hops with hint of grass on front palate. Honey sweetness mid palate. Caramel and faint dark bread/graininess on back of palate. Alcohol warmth on finish is medium length. Finish is complex interplay of heavy caramel malt sweetness, alcohol warmth, and hop bitterness. 
 
MOUTH FEEL: Lively carbonation helps reduce some of the perceived viscosity, making it seem less viscous than it appears. 
 
OVERALL: A monster of an ale, especially in appearance. Complex aroma and taste. Viscous. Excellent after dinner slow-slipping ale/digestif.

gusher out of the bottle, pours dark hazy cola, aroma of barnyard hay, sugar, caramels, piney hops, apple juice, cider, holiday spices.  massive head, great lacing.  smooth drinking, no alcohol burn, perhaps my favorite barleywine. Flavor is sweet and sugary, hoppy but not overly so. a little spice.  great beer.

Bottle; Houston - we have a gusher. That aside-  it was probably a sign of the big/epic nature of this brew. A ton of sediment is present - it was stuck on the gigantic beige head like sand in whipped cream. Amazing retention, lacing - but again, this was a gusher. Aromas are honey, caramel malts; creamy head - nice bitter hop profile. Caramel, toffee - this one is sweet, bitter, but the alcohol seems to be masked fairly well. Nice brew

Bottle courtesy of black13.  Thanks!  2010 vintage. Pours a light brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma is a sweet and malty.  A little heavy on the palate with medium carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malt, a little hops, and just a touch of booze.  I think the honey comes through a little as well.  A fantastic barleywine.

17th March 2009  Cloudy brown beer, thick pale tan head. The head has a lovely creamy bitter toffee flavour. The beer is rich and sumptuos. Sweet malt with a blooming aniseedy alcohol. Semi dry finish. Very tasty barleywine.

Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours amber with nice off-white head.  Taste is sweet with some toffee and caramel, but lots of hoppiness.  I think with a year or two on this, the hops will mellow and this will be fantastic.

Dark brown colors with a tan head.  Tastes of raisins and a little bit of honey.  A little too much IPA in this barley wine to make it a great beer for me.  Would probably do well to let sit for a year.

2007 bottle courtesy of barleypops (Thanks!)  Very hazy apricot colored pour, very well carbonated and an aroma of malt, stone fruits, and a little booze.  Flavor had a rich spicy malt backbone, some pepper and warming on the aftertaste.  Solid beer!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2012 2005 Bottle thanks to Ben! Poured a cloudy ruby brown with a light brown head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma had a nice caramel note with a surprisingly present light fruit note, a bit of flora and a hint of alcohol. Flavor had a nice caramel and sweet bread note with some light fruit and flora backing. There was a bit of alcohol in the finish.

12 oz bottle.2010.Pours a dark caramel with a nice thick off white head.Nose is honey,raisin,hops and citrus notes.Taste is creamy malts,bitter and floral hops followed by thick syrupy resiny goodness.This is like a meeting between the best IPA and Barleywine ever.What a great way to kick off 2011!!!!Hair of The Dog rocks!!

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a cloudy dark brown color with some chunks and had a medium sized tan head that left good lacing. The aroma was strong rough pine and sour fruits with a touch of mint. The flavor was sweet yet bitter with strong pine and light notes of grapefruit, lemon, mint, spruce, toffee and nut. A sweet malty base tries to come through but get repeatedly beaten down by the strong hop presence. The finish was long, bitter, fruity and piney. Thick and full body. Well done.

Sampled at 2010 Kuhnhenn Winter Solstice, thanks Chuck!  Pours deep copper/brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt, honey, brown sugar, fruits, and citrusy hops.  Taste is sweet and bitter on the back end.  Creamy smooth mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Very nice.

2010, 11% ABV. Even though young, this is one wicked nice brew. Lots of floral hops and alcohol aroma and very nice frothy light tan head. Swirling produces a thick frothy head with light lacing. very intersting to see that head come back so strong. Almost like mousse or whipped cream. Pours wood brown and a bit cloudy, but that could be from quite a large amount of yeast left in the bottle.

Flavor is sweet, strong, with a nice balance of malt and bitter. Really I get a lot of honey, full coating of tongue, and a very slow fade of flavor. Medium to thick body, almost chewy. As it warms up, I taste more citrus, like tangerine, but still warm sweetness. Wonderful, memorable beer. Definitely putting some away for later. Tasted from the bottle @ 62F.

Appearance: cloudy brown; wood. Khaki head retains a mousse-like texture even as it fades into a tight thick blanket; solid. Swirls with no lace and an even thicker head.

Nose: sweet boozy spice in the back makes for good first impressions; tickles eyes and nose. Apples, raisins, plum skins, pear skins, and stewed mandarin skins. The sweetness (maple) in back is gentle, mingling with the pear, mandarin, and possible even a tiff of mango. Black root and a hint of vanilla bean. Spice spliced wood, barreled rum if you please.

Palate: wow and OMG. Sweet, wholly coating all oral surfaces from the front to the middle; lips. Dry, spiced, and wonderfully woody in the back. Apple, pears, raisins, and plums start tart then turn sweet. Cinnamon sticks, rum spice, and wood mingle and marry. Maple and caramel linger longest on the lips. Quite sessionable for her rich intensity. Warmth slowly tickles the back of throat before settling comfortably in my chest. Chocolate oranges; marmalade and mandarin.

Final Thoughts: how can one not love a beer from a brewery called Hair of the Dog?! Even better, their beers are quite often out of this world tastetacular. Chalk this beast right up there with the best of them.

Bottle, hooked up at Holiday Wine Cellars, Escondido CA. Pours a hazy brownish red color, with a medium head. Flavor is dense and sweet, heavy malt forward, ripe fruits, honey, and residual sugars. Heavily hopped on the back end with notes of resiny spruce and citrus. Full bodied, lingering sweetness and a hint of alcohol on the back end. Although the hops are minty fresh, it seems that this beer would benefit from a bit of aging to mellow out the sweetness a bit. Still solid.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 A: Pours a nice dark caramel with a fairly nice tan head. Not too much lacing.

S: Loads of caramel and brown sugar alongside bits of alcohol, and then even more sweetness and a few fruits.

T: Very strong sweet malt presence, without being completely overdone. Plenty of brown sugar and caramel. A few ripe fruits.

M: Pretty full mouthfeel with little carbonation and just a bit of alcohol heat.

D: Very, very drinkable, especially for the style. While I did enjoy this one slowly, I could have consumed it a lot faster. A beautiful sipper that Id love to always have on hand.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-16-2010

At a tasting, thanks Shahar, pours an hazy orange to brown with a small head, aroma of lemon, orange, caramel, malt and soy sauce, flavor of soy sauce, malt, smoked malt, marmalade and coffee, full bodied, nice.

2009 vintage bottle from Ho1000B.  Pours amber with red hues and a beige, pillowy head. Caramel.  Seriously its all caramel.  And some mild honey/sweetness.  Very, very sweet, caramel, brown sugar, honey.  Reasonably balanced, alcohol forward as it warms.  Very solid barley wine.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2015 2006 vintage has been the best Ive had: 12 oz. bottle, split with manuchampions, pours amber with no head / no carbonation. Aroma of sweet dried fruits, fire / heat, and caramel. Flavour is extremely complex - sweet dried fruits, caramel, some molasses and various berries. Another absolutely amazing offering from Hair of the Dog. 9 4 10 4 18 4.5 / 5

Other versions, both draft and bottle, did not stand up to this initial experience. More hops on fresher versions and less cohesiveness, sometimes a bit abrasive. Still an excellent barley wine.

At a tasting, thanks Shachar: in the aroma dried fruits, caramel, fried butter, light honey notes, apricote jam, white port, weak saltyness, the flavor is quite the same. slightly dry, very sweet, needs hops to balance but apparently they are gone by now, some carob, syrupy, rose petals jam, very good.

At a tsting, many thanks Shachar, dark orange to light brown colour and murky, aroma of citrus, barnyard and strawberry jam, dominant flavours of dried fruit compote, with strwberry jam and some turkish delight at the end, quite sweet but pleasant and not cloying, a touch pf alcohol that blends and does not interferre, long nutty aftertaste. was probably better when a little younger, burt still very good.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Shachar. 2007 bottle. Hazy orange-brown. Sweet malty aroma with caramel, honey and marmalade. Very sweet flavor with honey, some caramel, flowers, fruits and a slightly drier finish. Full-bodied and slightly sticky. Good, but too bad almost all the hops are long gone by now.
2008 Bottle:  Dark amber with a small white head no lacing. Burnt fruity funky aroma. Very sweet malt flavor, more burnt fruits, plum,

This gem was given to me frim a fellow co-worker of mine. Had already been aging for nearly two years.. sweet! Absolutely wonderful barleywine. Nice and tart, great head, sweet taste with well masked alcohol. Light carb with a nice lingering sweetness. Wish is had two...

An orange amber ale with a thin super lacing light moka head. In aroma, a smooth malty and vinous malt, with woody qualities, caramel pudding, hard candy. In mouth, another work of art, with oily biscuitty malt, smooth with prickly c-hops, yet another wow!  On tap at Hair of the Dog, Sept. 4, 2010.

12 oz bottle of 2007 via a trade with ditmier. Crystal clear amber with a small off white head that quickly fades. Amazing aroma of dark caramel, honey, pine, toffee and alcohol.The flavor is sweet caramel malt and honey with a medium hop bitterness and a light alcohol heat. Medium body with soft carbonation and a thick, syrupy mouth feel. Great Barley Wine, the hops have faded a lot but still help temper the sweetness. This one ages great.
2009. Lovely aroma: burnt fruit, toffee, caramel, lemon. Pours cloudy orange, large dense head. Sweet licorice, wood, dark fruit. Smooth, with warming alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 09 bottle.  Massive honey, sweet malt aroma.  Taste is surprisingly smooth with honey, dark malt, some bitter hops, and a relatively clean finish.  The honey really dominates over the sweet, dark malt.  Alcohol well hidden.  An outstanding barley wine and certainly one that could be aged for years. 8/3/8/3/18: 4.0
11 bottle.  This beer is much better for my personal tastes fresh.  Killer pungent pine, bitter hops, and perfectly balanced sweet honey and thick malt.  I swear this could nearly pass for a triple IPA as the sweetness is well in check and underneath the crisp hop profile.  This beer just screams BALANCE.  Thank you Alan!  9/3/9/4/19: 4.4
Amber with a small white head. Fruity aroma with peach some malt and biscuit notes. Sweet biscuit malty flavour with dried fruits. Cloying sweetness

Trade with Beerman6686.  The aroma is fruity, citrusy.  The appearance is a very hazy brown, large off-white head.  The flavor is citrus hoppy, caramel, light fruit.  The finish is huge citrus and pine hop bittering, more pine actually.  Nice medium/thick body.  Nice beer, unexpectedly hoppy for a barley wine.  Im glad I got to try this.  Thanks, Daniel.

355mL 2008 ed. Pours a clear and then with the sediment later slight hazy deep amber with a faint yellow head that eventually forms and leaves lots of micro lace all around the snifter. Aroma of vanilla, waffles, buttered pancakes, caramel, ganache, cheesecake with caramel drizzled over it, and some off flavors like peppermint and spearmint (or maybe these are intentional). Taste is not too thick, slight piney hops poke through but mostly a caramel and crystal malt forward offering with a bit of a soapy component. Mint flavors still abound. As it warms the wild flower honey really shines and gives the beer some much sought after body. Very nice in the finish as it warms: bitter, spicy, rich honey, slightly syrupy, no cloying, no diacetyl. What an accomplishment.

A: pours a murky reddish brown color. nice rich khaki colored head. lower retention rate. great ringlike lacing.

S: a lot more hop aroma than I expected. big pine resin, lots of citrus, and a good variety of floral notes. grapefruit and blood oranges. lots of rich, sweet malts. some apples and light spices.

T: now thats a barleywine. I get a great malt backbone, some sweet flavors. vast array of grapefruits, blood oranges, figs, apples, possibly some dates. hints of maple syrup and honey. great use of amarillo and simcoe.

M: malt backbone is thinner than expected. I do get some mead like characteristics from the honey, with the higher ABV. relatively smooth for a barleywine. smooth carbonation level.

07 on tap. Deep brown with red edges, white head that falls quickly. Aroma is musty malts and caramel. Flavor is caramel, light chocolate, coconut, barely some chocolate and a slight bitter finish. Very enjoyable and lovely my crummy notes could never describe this amazing beer.

Rating #600!  Bottle, 2009.  Aroma has notes of sweet caramel, alcohol, citrus fruits, vanilla, a little honey and wood.  Deep hazy mahogany hue with a large off-white frothy head that lasted and left good lace.  Taste is very sweet, a little salty and medium bitter.  Palate is very full bodied, oily, average carbonation and has a long finish.  Overall a great looking brew that gets much better as it warms.  Very good.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a sticky white head. Aroma is figs, raisins, malt, faded hops, honey and a whiff of alcohol. Flavor is dark fruits, rasins, figs, vanilla, spices, malt, cherries. Very balanced, and has a nice warming sensation after every sip. Well integrated balanced and flavorful barleywine. Hair of the dog does it again! ;)

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2014 Ok ive no recolection of this but i have notes ... in liquid form At RBESG 2010 Rome ... amber ... rich sweet pine hop nose ... big sweet fruits ... loads of pine resins ... juicy orange peel ... nicer than i expected.
bottle at home ... dark copper ... thin tan lacing ...soft sweet roast ... dark malts ... rich dark sugers ... typical barley wine nose ... sweet toffee malts ... 

 bottle at home ... deep brown ....soft toffee fruits .. soft malts ... juicy roast ... soft toffee fruits ... light sweet malts ... juicy fruits ... 3.6

It pours out in a brownish, amber color with a nice tan head. It has decent retention and is nicely laced. Hops are very noticeable in the aroma and also has a sugary type of smell. Im guessing its like a honey smell. The taste is where the beer really shines. The hops adds bitterness into the fold and its balanced with the sweetness of the supporting flavors. Like the smell Im guessing the supporting flavor is honey with a bit of another flavor that I cant seem to place. It has very light carbonation so it goes down so smooth. It also feels smooth going down which adds to the charm. My only real gripe is that you can taste the alcohol pretty well but thats to be expected considering its a pretty strong 11.5% abv. If you dont mind the taste of alcohol then this beer is going to blow your mind. This is up there with the best beers so far.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. I think it was a 2004 vintage I had. It was tasty, just not anything that stands out as being an amazing bwine

Dont get the high schoore on this bubble at all. Mine smelled unbelievable and I thought I was in for a treat, but it seemed someone stole the cookies from the cookie jar long before I got thar. This one tasted watered down to an exreme level, not in the booze catagory, there just werent any flavors to speak of. Light caramel, light light fruitiness, no hops at all, and other barely detectable flavors. Really like a tasteless cocktail with soft carbonation. For the price, I dont think Ill consider a re-rate.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a turbid, murky mahogany amber with a thick, two finger tan head. Aroma of oat, chesnut, vanilla, roasted malts, honey, caramel, and whiskey. Full bodied with a thick, rich, spicy, velvety, sticky palate. Finishes with a huge a boozy wallop. Awesome warmer/nightcap brew. Nicely done.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2013 Bottle split with pat. Pours a dark hazy red body with small off white lacing. Mouthfeel is silky with notes of sweet caramel, spice, cinnamon,  maple syrup. Delicious - probably will pick up another one to age. 2011 - 2005 vertical courtesy of blipp. With age the beer evolves into something great. Wonderful brew.
Bottle thanks to Overml01. Pours muddy brown with off white head. Nose is cinnamon, musk, floral hops and honey. Taste is strong honey, brown sugar, molasses and cinnamon. Very sweet.
Bottle. Brown pour with white head. Hoppy aroma, caramel malt and dark fruits. Sweet malt and dark fruit, some huge hop character pine, citrus and  grapefruit. Nice bw.
Pours ruby brown with off-white head. Smell is boozy, with some caramel. This beer is really hot, with alcohol and a thin flavor coming through with some bitterness.

12oz bottle, 2005 vintage.  It did not explode, to my surprise.  Pours a translucent copper brown with some clumpy white head.  Aroma has citrus fruits, tropical fruits, sherry, caramel, brown sugar, butterscotch.  Flavor is sweet, caramel, apples, bread, whole grains, malts, pineapple.  Full bodied, sweet finish.

Flaske: Årgang 2006. Fantastisk duft af malt og tørret frugt. Udseendet er ravfarvet men uden noget skumhoved. Smagen er superlækker med et godt humlebid især alderen taget i betragtning. Desværre er der ikke nogen karbonering der trækker den ned fra en verdensklasse øl til en "bare" meget god øl.

Number 900 and even sweeter, drank it to celebrate the Chicago Blackhawks Stanley Cup win! Pours a murky brown color with low carbonation. Aroma has a very pungent caramel malt sweetness, strong piny, citrus and floral hops note, strong alcohol and honey note at the end. Flavor has an intense overall sweetness that starts off with a strong caramel malt flavor that subsides to a citrus and light piny hoppiness. Flavor finishes with a pretty strong honey flavor with a smooth toasted malt ending. Body is pretty heavy with a very sugary smooth feeling with a light alcohol heat. Overall an awesome barley wine with so many complex flavors and aromas that it almost makes it too hard to take everything in. Awesome!
Bottle @ RBESG, Rome. Pours unclear amber with a small off white head. Nose is very fruity and vinous. Dark fruit, hops and sweet caramel. Sticky and vinous. Full bodied. Syrupy and warm. Nice one

barley wine tipico in stile hair of the dog! perfetto sotto tutti i punti di vista aroma tostato caramellato molto complessoquasi di burro darachidi! corpo intenso avvolgente copre totalmente la gradazione... incredibile...devo cmq riprovarlo però

bottle, a muddy brown orangish color, slight foam, nose is hoppy pines and butterscotch, flavor of grapefruit, malt, brown sugar and a very nice smooth bitter finish, not as good as I thought it would be.

12 oz bottle.  dark yellowish red color.  Sweet smells of fruits.  Taste the wild honey from mt. hood the description says is in the bottle.  Be careful this beer will light you up.  Not my favorite but  all around a good wine.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a small amount of head.  Strong malty flavor with a slight alcohol finish.

2009 vintage a buddy picked up in Portland for me.  Thanks Carsten!  Big time carbonation, but not a bottle bomb.  Bottle continued to foam out the top after a 6 oz pour.  Brilliant clarity of copper with 1" head off white orange.  Strong carmel aroma with some nuttiness.  Taste is sweet, with some alcohol.  Aging could help add some complexity.  A nice beer that is bit sweet with strong carmel flavor and aroma with lots of hop flavor.

Pours copper. Nose is sweet caramel, sweet fruits, cinnamon, sugar coated cherries, caramel apple, hints of leather. Flavor is huge cherry, sweet pungent over-ripe fruits, toffee, Earthy hope, floral. Big mouthfeel. A bit cloying sweet for my liking, but i would contest it to a thomas hardy. Excellent beer.
2007 bottle thanks to matt that likes beer.  poured amberish with a white head.  aroma was caramel and sugary.  flavor was the same plus some pine.  body was medium with low carbonation.

Thanks to Matt for sharing this beer at thirdeye11s tasting.

2007 vintage. The beer pours a murky orange color with a white head. The aroma is awesome, with caramel and piney hops. The flavor is pine and orange hops with a nice semi-sweet, caramel malt backbone. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(12oz bottle 2007 vintage) clear deep orange pour with light white head of bubbles. Nose of caramel, honey, bread and raisins. Taste of sweet caramel, nice citrus hops, dark fruit and creamy. Excellent!

Bottle via J.O.  Long-lasting, lacing and large beige head with a hazy amber body.  Sweet.  Plum, cherry, and candied orange peel, more than a little mint and some grapefruit, grape, subtle herbal quality.  Light honeyed [is that really the right spelling?] sugariness, rich but not syrupy.  Full and thick body as expected.  At this age, hasnt really dried out, and I dont really expect it to.  A little booze but interesting as a  one-off and somewhat satisfying.

2008. Good-sized head with a lot of lacing from a nice vigorous pour. Red-amber liquid. This beer smells like caramel, sugar, grain, with a grapefruity west coast hop influence.  The taste is fantastic. Its sweet and full. I enjoy the bitterness of the hop finish. The barley character is just delicious. The feel is wonderfully sticky and coats the mouth very pleasantly.  Its just a great barleywine that warms you right up. Its fresh, elegant and delicious.

12 oz. bottle as an extra in a trade with LtDan- thanks again, Dan!  2009 vintage.  Pours a deep, hazy plum-amber color with absolutely no head or visible carbonation.  I was warned that the blue capped ones may have some carbonation issues, so that could be the reason why.  Beautiful aroma of hops, grapefruit citrus, honey, maple, cherry, pale malts, and a bit of caramel.  I could smell this all day.  The flavor doesnt quite live up to that, and the body is indeed flat.  Notes of grapefruit citrus, caramel malts, honey, hops, maple, cherry, apple, wet leaves, and floral notes.  Medium-bodied with no carbonation and a slick mouthfeel.  Some alcohol is apparent.  This would be so, so good with some carbonation; I need to get my hands on another bottle and see if its just like that or if I had a bad one.  Then again, if this is a bad one, this is an awesome beer.

12 oz. bottle from drewbeerme (2006).  The pour is like liquid caramel with a medium sized but dense ivory head.  The aroma is sweet caramel malts and ripe fruits with a decent citrus component.  The flavor centers around thick sweet caramel malt and big ripe fruits.  Additional flavors are toasted bread, vanilla, and dried fruits like apricots and prunes.  The combination works for me although I dont know how much longer I could have aged this without seeing it decline.  Full bodied and smooth.  This is one for sipping.

Majestic hazy orange-maroon colored brew with a lightly tanned head. Aroma is redolent of tangerine, sugar beach, scotch malt, candi malt and fruity hoppiness, quite the sensational synthesis of smells.  Moderately deep fruity body with a complexity of grains from toasted, to lightly kilned, to highly caramelized. Sugary, fruity sweetness. Honey-tinged throughout. Sticky, but not quite cloying. An immense amount of unattenuated sugars. A sapid liquid meal.

A caramel color beer with no head that is 100% flat. I do wonder if this really is supposed to have no carbonation. The aroma is actually nice & sweet, fruity, floral, caramel. The taste was a very sweet brown sugary mess. its like a flat super sweet malty soup with some bitterness in the end. Its mouthfeel reminds me of drinking a beer the next day that sat out in the glass overnight.

Bottle. Pours like honey with ample white foam and lots of bubbles running up the sides of the glass.  Murky in character.  Aroma is somewhat muted by the foam, but what is there is solidly pine/citrus resin and malty, hoppy, boozyness.  Strong elements of caramel, almost butterscotch, soy sauce (or something) saltiness, and an ample, though not overwhelming, portion of BOOZE in the palate.  All in all, quite well balanced.  Wish I had a pile more, and yeah, Id love to try some with a few bottle-years on it.  Another winner from Hair of the Dog.

HotD Doggie Claws 3/10/10 (2009 vintage; a very very engaging drink.  Right from the start, this BW was different:  appearance is a hazy amber hazelnut, with chunks of protein  and dare I say  hops at the bottom.  Filter not working?  Didnt matter, the murky appearance of this beer actually started to add to its mystique once I sipped it. Aroma is noticeably hoppy and boozy, a rather hot mixture of pine, sweet candied orange, cherry syrup and alcohol.  The flavor just takes you to another planet, though!  Bold notes of apricot, cherry pine, pressed flowers, and honey just burst out of the glass.  Suprisingly, the alcohol doesnt get in the way as suggested by the aroma.  Sweet blended fruit and fresh pine dominate this vintage, itll be interesting what happens in a few years with this one.

Im considering pioneering a new measurement of human activity specific to beer drinkers.  At the core of the measurement is how long it takes a RateBeer user to write a review after drinking a beer.  This is made most clear when looking back on reviews for Christmas beers which were punctually enjoyed around Christmas.  And yet here I am quickly glancing over my notes in the somewhat Springy month of May.  I think this could be considered a fair amount of time.  It helps, though, that the Doggie Claws from Hair of the Dog is more or less an unforgettable beer.  I am always unsettled with a beer pours out without so much as a single loud mouthed bubble barking out its last pop.  But the Doggie Claws does just this, sliding out of the bottle like a corpse, and settling like mercury.  The body is a nice mahogany brown, but theres all kinds of yeasty and particulate matter, even some evocative of phlegm.  This wouldnt be so bad if I wasnt already feeling I was conducting some kind of drinkable necromancy.  Surprisingly the aroma is vivacious, like fresh paint, mostly due to a sharp edge of alcohol.  But its strong too, and its hard for me to find much else here besides a rush of alcohol vapors.  The taste completes the experience, with its viscous, strong, and repelling flavors.  Foremost is the aftertaste, genuinely sweet and somewhat enjoyable with oozing pine and molasses.  But everything before that is a jarring blend of orange, bitterness, and an unexpected appearance of a raspberry-chocolate duo.  But overall, the flavor is mostly alcohol, which to me indicates skewed flavor priorities.  This beer is all over the place, and doesnt really whet the appetite, or satiate it.  Its just there, and pales compared to other widespread seasonal.  Maybe thats why I waited until March to write about it.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2010 2003 Vintage on tap at Lucky Baldwins HOTD night. Pours a cloudy orange with a creamy white head. Very sweet malty flavor which hides the 11% very well. 

Also had a 2009 bottle, very little carbonation.

2009 bottle poured on 3/9/10.  Pours hazy burnt caramel colored with little to no head.  This was a vigorous pour from 8" above the glass and left hardly anything.  Aroma is treacle, caramel, lavender, apple pie/cinnamon.  Incredibly sweet, with hardly any hops to balance.  Great mild spice flavor to go with the caramel, but Im looking for a tiny bit more bitterness.  Very good English style barleywine, but I was expecting west coast.  Full bodied, rich, buttery mouthfeel, but little to no carbonation.  Some barley wines are fine flat, but I think this couldve benefited a bit from a bit more carbonation.   Also, just noticed that the ABV is 11.5% and this doesnt taste anywhere near that high.  Alcohol is hidden extremely well and this is extremely drinkable.  A great beer that I would love to lay down for a few years.
Had this beer at Lucky Baldwins off tap 03 and 07.Mid sweetness ,heavy malt taste.

12oz bottle, 2008 release.   Red color with a small head.   The aroma is heavy on dried fruit with apple pie and light spice as well.   A touch of oxidation is showing, but not much.   Very rich overall.   The hops have mostly dropped out, leaving a rich malt sweetness, with apple and other dried fruit flavors.   Lightly spicy as well.   Full bodied, syrupy, sticky, and lower on carbonation.   Interesting, but a bit to syrupy and sweet overall.   I think this is a barleywine that I might be a bigger fan of when it is fresh.
Deep amber with fluffy white head no carb issue on this one. Deep fruity goodness and a warm alcohol and sweet aroma. Huge flavor with stone fruit and hops really nice barley wine.

On tap at Stuffed Sandwich. v.2008.  Deep red amber, crystal clear. Aroma-nice roasted malts, yeast, honey. Taste-sweet, rich, roasted malts, honey, yeasty, slight smokiness, lingering bitterness in the finish.

2009.  Bottle from South Bay.  I had heard that the blue caps had carbonation issues so I expected this to be flat but that was not the case at all.  Pours a deep amber color (the second pour looked muddy brown) with a nice initial frothy head and a thin layer of retention.  The aroma is nice; maple, honey, grapefruit, caramel, some smoke and maybe even cherry.  A very good barleywine.  Plums, tobacco, brown sugar flavors, sweet caramel and toffee malt, balanced by grapefruit and bitter leafy hops.  Towards the end of the bottle it gets quite resiny.  The 11.5% provides some warmth but otherwise is hardly noticed.  I continue to be amazed at the complexity of everything Ive had so far from HotD and Ill add this one to the need to re-visit list.

Pours a muddy brown with almost no head expect for some tan lacing of the edges.  aroma is of brown sugar, sweet malt, toffee, pine hoppyness, apricot, and some dark fruit.  Flavor is of piney hops, brown sugar, apricot, tropical fruits, toffee, sweet malts, dark fruits, and yeastyness.  has a full body with a thick, oily, chewy mouthfeel and alchool noticable but still subdued.  overall, a excellent barley wine.

2004 Vintage
I got this doggy in a trade with a generous BA who gave me a 2004 vintage; nice! The beer was poured into a snifter. The color was muddy-brown and red. The head was almost nonexistent save for a few white bubbles clinging to the side. The taste was a little chocolate and cocoa. The alcohol was prickly on my tongue. Very strong beer and good but I still prefer Bigfoot and Old Boardhead.

2/16/08 2007 Vintage

Thanks to vwcraig for the bottle as part of a recent trade. I wanted to re-review this as I have not had it fresh (or close to fresh). Nice appearance, hazy orange-red with a film of bubbles and a ring around the outside. The smell is immediately hoppy and awesome. I think I can almost smell the honey too but that may be the power of suggestion from the label. Slight hint of alcohol fumes but damn the smell is so good. I had to bump the smell score up a bit. The taste is very good and unlike any barleywine Ive had. Super hoppy and the honey is detectable with a sweet flavor. Now I just need to find some for my cellar!

04/11/08 2002 vintage 10% abv

I was able to score a couple bottles thanks to a BA mentioning a store in CO that sells vintage beers. I was told this was past its prime but it was only $3 so I figured why not? The color is a light orange with a decent head that recedes but is still a one cm layer of bubbles. The aroma is instant oxidation but then lots of cherries and fruits, interesting. The body is kinda thin but the flavor is still good, dark fruits but the flavor seems to run from my palate. It gives you a good idea and then its gone.
This is still a good beer but I would agree that it is probably past its prime and I dont see it getting any better, just thinner.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-22-2007 17:01:40

12oz. Bottle [2009 vintage] from trade with SuzyGreenberg:  Aroma of hops, pine, slight tropical fruit, hop oil, and a hint of caramel malt.  Poured copper/deep amber/brown in color with a large, creamy, dense, fluffy, rocky, off-white tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of hops, pine, slight caramel malt, resin, light brown sugar, malt, and slight cola.  Medium to full body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Medium to heavily bitter, lightly sweet, hops, pine, resin, and light caramel malt finish is slightly dry.  11.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2012 Had this on tap at HOTD. This is a re-rate. This was the 2011 Doggie. Colour...very cloudy dark brown with a VERY thick head. Nose...crushed dates and golden raisins with a slightly musty tone. Palate...velvety smooth with more dates and a golden sirop quality that mingles beautifully with flavours of candied fruits, fruitcake, pear compote and toffee. The hops are there but well balanced by all the other elements. This has changed nicely in the past year!

2009. Pours a cloudy copper with thick foamy head, lots of sediment.  Aroma is brown sugar, honey, floral/piney hops, lots of sweet malt.  Flavor is huge sweet malt, honey, carmel on a bed of lots of floral/piney hops lingering bitter in the finish.  Very thick heavy mouthfeel.  Raw flavorful barley wine, could use some age to mellow it out, but would likely lose its hop profile.

07 sampled at Baileys Taproom 2010 CellarFest.  Ive had this one before, but it had been a while and was young.  With about three years on this one it had done quite a bit of mellowing.  In fact, contrary to my memories this was just a huge, sweet malt bomb!  Poured a dark copper with very little head.  Nose was malty sweet with honey and molasses.  Hops character was very subdued in both aroma and taste.  Syrupy and sweet with plenty of cereal, caramel and assorted malty notes.  High abv is very well hidden.  This one might be a bit too sweet for my taste, but a great brew nonetheless.

2009 vintage(gold cap) thanks to secret santa, pours deep ruby with a tall frothy light tan head.....lots of hop residue in the glass.  Huge piney hop aroma with some candied grapefruit notes.  Huge sweet malt, alcohol, and strong but pleasantly balanced pine bitterness in the flavors.  Its big, sweet, but not overly, with just the right amount of bitterness and alcohol burn.  Really lovely.

2009 bottle from Liquid Solutions.  pours a deep amber / light brown with a small off white head with lots of yeast sediment... smooth citrus and pine laced hops that almost sting the nose a bit... not overpowering at all... dialed in well, but could use a bit more power.... probably have faded a bit.  medium body with more citrus bitterness up front and to the sides... along with smooth caramel malts, a big sweetness, some lingering toffee and honey.  This finishes really well with a nice balance of hops and malts along with a burst of alcohol.  Overall a very well put together American style barleywine that will definitely improve with age.

"2008 Release: Came across as a nicely balanced barleywine. A lot of malted cereal in the aroma followed by wood, flowers and a heavy earthiness. Cloudy light brown pour with a thin head and minor spots of lacing. Good feeling with this one, damn drinkable for the style. Very malty and lightly sweet. Bran flakes, sweet caramel, honey buns, nuts and wood provide for an outstanding flavor. This is tasty."

09 12 oz bottle pours a murky cider brown with minimal off white head into a snifter.  Aroma of deep, resiny, piny hops, caramel malts.  Pretty stark dichotomy, but very pleasant.  Starts with a surprisingly well balanced full hops and caramel malts, pine, little bit of lingering cocoa/vanilla (faint).  Bit of booziness in the finish.  Toffee dominates as it warms.  Silky smooth mouthfeel with low carbonation, full bodied.  I honestly cant believe how well balanced this was.  Utterly delicious.
Rating #600 of the brew.  On tap at Brouwers in Seattle.  Dark brown with red tints.  Creamy barley wine.  Sweet to spicy.  Malt afters.  Super fruity-sweet.  Great brew.  2009 edition.
These guys make great beer. This beer is no exception. Excellent barleywine. Everything is perfect......EXCEPT...its just a little to sweet.

Strong hoppy nose. Spicy pine hops with a good deal of malty sweetness- honey, caramel, toffee. Pours amber/copper with a great head and awesome lace. Pine, grapefruit hops. Caramel toffee honey. Good sweetness and awesome hops. Big but balanced. A little dankÝ hop nÓtes show up too. Big full creamy body. Nice carbonation.

Blue cap courtesy of craftycarl21. A wondrous start to the 21st birthday tasting. Well carbonated despite recent troubles. Brown pour with hints of toffee and a small white lively head. Some sediment finds its way to the bottom, but overall she looks beautiful. Aroma first presents in a hop oriented manner- lots of spruce and resin with a warming kick of nasal warming booze. Malt character is caramel and biscuity in nature, but the evergreen is inescapable. The malt character is much more prevalent in the flavor: caramel and floral honey swirl together in a sweet torrent of deliciousness. Hop profile is much less pronounced than the aromatic bouquet might suggest, but acts to provide an excellent sappy evergreen balance. Booze character is far less noticeable in the flavor and almost goes unnoticed in the wake of such a defined sweet malt presence despite its rather high content. Palate is rich, velvety, syrupy, and chewy with a nice fine bubbled effervescence and and smacking but clean finish. Masterfully put together and incredible balanced- Im going to go sip this by the fire now...

The first beer of what promises to be perhaps the best tasting of my life. Brown pour with a caramel tint to it; minimal bubbly head, and some noticeable sediment at the bottom of the glass. Aroma holds great hop character, with evergreen resin, earth, orange rind, and lemon. Near the finish the malt character comes out, with caramel, biscuit, booze, and a bit of that honey. Malt is much more pronounced in the flavor, with heavy molasses, honey, caramel, toast, but still the great Simcoe bitterness and dark, piney hop character. Palate is luscious; not too thick, but the sweetness and bitterness are beautifully complimentary. The 11.5% is warming and welcome, but not aggressive, more of a massaging booziness. Excellent American style barleywine, just the quality Ive come to expect from HOTD. Note: didnt experience any of the carbonation issues that people have been discussing with the blue caps.
2009 bottle. Pours a dark, syrupy amber. Rich aroma of pine, cherries, and brown sugar. Molasses, prunes, pineapple, and citrus. Still young, but delightful, nonetheless.

2009 bottle Picked up at Full Throttle Bottles. Dark brown in color with a small head that sits around the edge of the top; looks like a great beer to me, but I havent had a bad Hair of the Dog. Definitely a strong hop aroma with this thing. Nice pine-type hop aroma. Definitely a subtle sweet malt backing that compliments the pine almost citrus hop flavor. Slight sweet dough aroma. Fairly nuanced beer, but I think some time on this one would really improve the aroma, and bring out those malts a bit more. Definitely get a sweet subtle honey aroma. The sweet honey/malt flavor comes through more to me in the flavor than in the aroma. Hops are still there. Still a subtle pine and slight citrus hop. Pilsner malt is definitely there too. Ah, a nice smooth flavor. Very good offering from Hair of the Dog.

Now this is a winter warmer.  Cheeks flushed after drinking.  Hoppy aroma.
Big hoppy taste and alcohol flavor.  Easy to drink despite the 11% alcohol. Might taste even better after a year.

2009 bottle, Smells like caramel. Pours cloudy with yeast and looks like muddy water which is not a dealbreaker, just not very appetizing-looking in a clear glass. Also some raisin notes. Almost no carbonation in stark contrast to the Adam and Fred I had which practically burst from the bottle. Tastes sweet, but not sickeningly so. Finish is bitter with a very slight alcohol tinge. I would like more of these to store for a while and see how it tastes then.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2009 Fresh 09 bottle.  Pours a hazy mahogany with almost no head.  Very little carbonation in this.  Aroma is largely dominated by floral hops, with a healthy amount of brown sugar and honey, plus some fig like dried fruit.  This is a very sweet beer with an alcohol bite that needs to be sipped slowly.  It charms me more with each sip (I keep having to adjust my rating).  Has a lot of that brown sugar and honey in the flavor, and loads of complex dried fruit flavors (raisin, dried cherry, fig, etc).  The sweetness sticks with you throughout the finish, along with resinous bitter hops at the end.  This is almost too sweet for me, but it pulls it off.  Oddly enough, the flavors remind me a little of 120 minute IPA, which I disliked a lot, but something about Doggie Claws just tastes more "right."

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2009 Rating #1700. 2008 Vintage.  Bottle thanks to scrizzz.  Pours a pretty quiet red-brown with some whitish cover that forms and quickly dies to leave only a couple islands of carbonation recreating their best imitation of continental drift.  Aroma is raisins, fruit, caramel, apples, caramel apples, toffee, very sweet, but the potency is apparent.  The taste includes more florals, citrusy hops, a slick body, a fruity sweet maltiness, caramel, apples, more raisins and dried fruits, light alcohol finish.

Bottle from 06. Pours a nice amber color but after the huge amount of yeast that came out of the bottom made it look like a white russian. Ive never seen so much yeast come from a bottle of beer. Has a nice caramel wood smell to it. Taste about the same with a sweet finish but it isnt to sweet. Another fantastic brew from HotD
Cloudy, deep amber with a very small, soapy, quickly dissipating head.  Somewhat faint aroma, mainly honey, mellow hops and nutty malt. Heavy palate, sweet and malty flavor.

This barley wine is my favorite. Hard to get but well worth it. 12 oz bottle bought from Alan at HOTD brewery. The pour is a rich caramel/orange with a nice lacing and off white head. The nose is orange, citrus, pine, toffee, caramel, and sugar. The taste is the same and the barley and hops play well off eachother for a nice balance here. This is truly an amazing beer. Thanks Alan.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2009 12oz bottle, 2008 release, via trade with SuzyGreenberg, thanks Ben! pours a hazy, amber-orange with a very thin, off-white head, and a thread of lacing around the edges. aroma is excellent with big, sweet notes of buttery toffee, caramel, and molasses with subtle fruit notes of cherry, orange, and lemon zest with a hint of pine resin and brandy. flavor is wonderfully decadent with a marvelous balance of sweet toffee, butterscotch candy, maple syrup, and dark malts with fruit notes of pink grapefruit, canned peaches, sweet red apple skins, and tropical pineapple and smooth subtle notes of honey and cider spice on the finish. palate is full bodied, sticky and rich without being overly sweet with gentle carbonation and a lovely warming finish. overall, this is a truly wonderful barley wine.

Location: 12 oz bottle (2008 bottle) via trade with NickD717, 11/8/09


Aroma: At first, the nose actually reminds me of a nice Simcoe hop IPA with lots of citrus and pine, as it sits for a bit the rest of the complex nose opens, there are also some sugary malts, some caramel, and a nice warming peppery alcohol backing too

Appearance: Pours a nice caramel-amber color with a thin off-white head, and light drops of lace

Flavor: The taste is quite complex and mixed as well, I got lots of flavors through a well-made, full flavored beer

Palate: This one has a nice full-bodied feel to it, lots of warming alcohol, and a lasting feel

Overall Impression:
