Thanks, Nick!  Ive heard good things about them, but this is my first HotD rating.  I have to say, this one lived up to my expectations, quite a nice beer.  This was a really good quality beer that has a large flavor that fills your mouth for a long time.  It just works well, a quality, enjoyable beer for sure.

Shared this with Drink4Satan cheers mike thanksfor the tasting.  The nose is full of butter cream with a molasses and pepper kick. It is very strong and a bit acidic with some orange peel. The flavor is very bittersweet with Carmel It has a nice initial bite, pepper kick and sweet candi sugar. Very soothing to the  palate and full of carbonation that tingles the tongue.

Rating #800. 2008 bottle. Pours hazy dark copper color with minimal off white head. Very sweet aroma of brown sugar, toffee, molasses, pine and grapefruit. Flavor is sweet and fruity with lots of molasses and brown sugar. Big hoppy grapefruit taste with a slight bit of heat from the alcohol. Full body with soft carbonation and a thick,chewy mouthfeel. Excellent.

Bottle with thanks to Matt.  Pours a clearish dark amber/light orangey brown with almost no head.  Aromas have a surprising resin presence and quite a bit of cherry to them.  Stretching a little, there is a maple syrup sweetness and orange peels.  Borderline cloying flavors of cherry and maple syrup with a little bit of a resin and medicinal hops presence are nice.  It stops a little short of being off-putting with the sweetness.  Alcohol is well hidden and mouthfeel is fairly thin considering style and all that is going on with the sticky sweet flavors.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 2008 bottle thanks to DuffManSW.  Pours a bight copper color with a tiny amount of off-white, fizzy head.  Nice rich complex aromas.  Theres so many things to pick out!  I get rich toffee, molasses, orange peel, aromatic honey, ruby red grapefruit, brandy, butterscotch, some cherry and red grapes.  Every whiff brings out some new aroma!  The flavor is intense, boozy, fermenting dark fruit with some cracked pepper, caramel, brandy, pine needles, tobacco and butterscotch.  The flavor is immense but maybe a bit too rich and alcoholic.  I could really see a few more years on this as an improvement but it is still fantastic.  The body is lush, full, and sticky with gentle carbonation.  Excellent stuff and a great way to kick off the cold weather beer season!

Thanks to the generosity of STLWill for this 2005 bottle! The pour produces a trnaslucent murky orange colour with a minimal head and some sediment floating toward the top of the glass. 
The nose has a heavy molasses backbone, with white pepper, rich vinous malts, alcohol and toffee. Some tropical fruits come through in the aroma as well. The flavour is full, round, and mellowfor  a beer this big. Tropical fruits, buttercream, apple, leather, rich caramel and pepper spice are distinct overtones. The aftertaste is certainly hot, but the palate duration of flavour and mellow caramel and vinous zest balance this warming effect effectively. This beer matured nicely.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 12 oz. bottle shared at Logans 2009 pre-GABF Party (2005 vintage).  Dark, copper colored pour.  Grapefruit, peach, and brown sugar aroma.  Toffee, caramel, mango, and pineapple flavor.  This is incredible stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2015 Last bottle at a tasting ,with time constraints because we had to get a bus home.My note are almost unreadable, and scarce.Witch would indicate that my mental faculties where somewhat off at the time,i.e i was getting kinda drunk. Nice brownish barley wine ,lots of malt in both flavor and aroma.Full bodied .Will drink again if I have the chance.Had it again 10/10-2015 , still pretty nice.

Pours murky brown-orange with little head. Aroma is like pine sap, grapefruit, light alcohol, very bitter. Taste is almost like Dogfish 120 but maybe not as thick, but hops are mostly prevalent with barely enough Barley wine characteristics to classify it as such. Smooth body, bitter hop and honey finish.

Rating #500!!! Bottle with thanks to Ditmier and Beerman6686 respectively. Man. This thing pours like an apple cider...completely opaque with no head. Smells like a freshly opened hop....didnt really expect that. Flavors is a creamy silky blend of hops, a touch of caramel and light ginger...pine toffee and some bandaid funk. The semi nasty thing was the white pus oozing from the dregs of the bottle. Rather solid beer...literally.Finish has a somewhat spicy alcohol taste, with notes of honey floating in and out. Awfully good.

My 300th rating! Thanks to Butters for this bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with no head.  Some floaters as well.  In fact yeast crusted at the top of the bottle and exploded upon opening, very cool looking. Aroma of citrus hops, dark fruit, caramel, booze.  Similar taste, very fruity and boozy with a slight resiny hop finish.  Thick mouthfeel.  Definitely an old bottle, but very enjoyable. Cheers!

Bottle shared with the barrios, scottyp, curly.  Thanks to lithy! After a very eventful bottle opening (the bottle litterally sharted yeast cake)  it has a particulate filled dark amber pour with thin ring of clearish head.  Nose is amazing hoppy, with pine and alcohol and peat. Extremely resiny pine hop with a lingering sweet honey finish. Very tasty, but i would say this is more of a dipa.
Pours a fading ring of beige head with a copper body.  Aromas of caramel, resin, slightly floral.  Flavor is sweet, little spicy, herbal, some resin.  Good, oily body.  Floral, bready, sweet finish.

Bottle 2006 shared by alexsdad06.

Poured hazy reddish brown color with a minimal frothy off-white head that slowly diminished with minimal lacing. Moderate to heavy dark fruity and woody aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Moderate to heavy dark fruit sweet flavor with a medium to heavy dark sweet finish of moderate to long duration.

This is a complex standout beer.

Draught at the brewery. Thanks, Alan.
2008 version. Big citrus hops aroma with cherry, honey; very fruity. Smooth palate, fruity and hoppy flavor but limited bitterness. Huge fruitiness with a fabulously complex hop character. Love it!

Bottle thanks to Suzygreenberg.  Pour is cloudy red/brown with a very small but persistent tan head.  Aroma is surprisingly hoppy with a nice toffee and caramel malt aroma.  Its very bright and enticing. Flavor is sweet and tart up front.  Hops are notably less intense in the flavor than in the aroma.  Flavor also has a nice port wine and honey flavor that lingers.  Its complex, well balanced and really delightful.

My 700th Rating. 2006 vintage Big thanks to a great guy Odeed.... Saved this one for a special milestone. Poured carefully due to the one inch of sludge at the bottom of the bottle (really wasnt sure what to do, either pour it out or not), pouring carefully this came out a dark reddish brownish color a bit hazy, very little carbonation, almost none. Aroma is very sweet malty with a hint of hops and dark fruits, honey, molasses and toffee.  Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Taste is very cognac like  very sweet dark fruits with a funky earthy aftertaste. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft and the alcohol had mellowed nicely. I did end up pouring out the sludge with the last 4 oz and gave it a light swirl this turned the colr almost like a cocolate milk like substance, the chuncks were not enjoyable, almost undrinkable. Overall I was pleased with this barleywine pre-sludge and thought it aged nicely too. Thanks again to Jake for this gem.

Thanks to Ditmier for the bottle. Hazy dark orange pour with an off white head. Caramel malt, toffee, and a big citrus hop aroma. Smooth caramel malt and citrus grapefruit hop taste. A really nice blend of english malt toffee and nice bursting grapefruit bitter american hops. Stunningly good beer. A winner.

Bottle. 2006. 
No pfffft at all when opening the bottle. Very little foam in the beer. Toffee/amber colour. Aroma from butterscotch, heavy malt and caramel. Big malty flavour, with wood, toffee and light chocolate. Bit cellary in flavour, with flat-ish, dead mouthfeel, despite the big maltiness. Berries come to mind. Hops are long gone - in aroma as well as in bitterness. Definitely not perfect at this age.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2009 A Mes rate. Bottle at home.Shit the bed folks. This one is a real winner. Dark naughty amber with a thin but lasting off white head. When I say lasting, I mean its there until you drain the glass. Fuckin excellent. The aroma really stops you in your tracks. The Amarillo is just about there in the background but this one is all about the Simcoe. A fuckin superb hop and this one really shouts its praises. Backed up by some stunning sugary caramel malt and just the right amount of fruit along with some ridiculous but loveable peppery alcohol notes. Shit, I really could take a good while sniffing at this. The flavour is just as spank my arse and call me Mabel excellent. This is full on loopy juice. Bring on the madness. Big malt, some honey, some faint tangerine and a shit load of sugary alcohol. This is one of those take over the world beers. Marching juice for the jilted generation. Fanfuckintastic.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 Bottle. It pours a nice-looking clear, copper body under a small, off-white head. Vinous nose with alcohol, caramel, dried fruits and lots of balancing (well, sort of) hops. Alcohol, dried fruits, caramel sweetness and a nice bitterness in the mouth, warming and full-bodied. Bitter finish with both dried fruits and caramel sweetness. Some alcohol also shines through. Yet another lovely beer from this brewery. 090619
2005 bottle opened by JW77...thanks man!  Amber pour.  Big tan head.  Caramel, raisins, prunes and some hops on the nose.  Sweet and raisiny.  Caramel notes...good stuff!!
Bottle 2004 vintage. Dark amber colour with  a beige head. Aroma is Alcohol, licorice, caramel. Flavour is alcohol, hop, licorice. A beer to drink slowly. Nice beer.

12 oz bottle courtesy of ditmier. Thanks Eric. 2007 vintage.  Pours a murky amber-brown with a small off-white head that has good retention and some lacing. The aroma is strong and unique with flowers, honey, plums, raisins and something that reminds me of county landfill. The flavor follows the nose,  to me this is all kind of weird, but in a good way. This reminds me of some of DFHs offerings. The mouthfeel is full, smooth and malty, with soft carbonation. The finish is long and sweet with mild hops and honey. This was not what I was expecting, but its not bad. I could get used to this. Cheers.

Bottle from 2008... Pours an orange brown with a off white head.. Aroma is honey and floral hops.. Honey sweetness a low lingering hop bitterness.  Kinda DFH 120 minute-esque.. Low carbonation and very easy to drink.
Apples, raisins, plums, molasses, fruity bitter hops in the end. Caramel and toffee as well. Slightly sour and a bit like hard candy.

2006 bottle, thanks Jared.  Pours a deep amber orange, dark copper if you prefer, with thin off-white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of a nice citrus and herbal hops, very nice malt backbone, caramel, and spices.  Flavor matches well, but has a sweetness that starts to take over in my opinion.  Maybe with a little more age, this will be just about right, or maybe I prefer younger, I will have to try both!

Bottle from 04 obtained in a past trade. Pours out a dark amber color with some reddish hues. Still a decent amount of carbonation hanging around which produces a lasting thin tan head. Aroma is of dried fruits, chocolate, sweet malts, alcohol and shocking there is still a few notes of a hop bitterness. Taste is very complex, sweet sticky mouthfeel, sweet candy-like notes with some dark cherries, molasses, slight hops and a little biting alcohol on the finish. Very solid.

Bottle thanks to ryan poured dark and copper, decent of white head with aromas that jumped right out of the glass of hops and malts the taste was of both this one was a little more hoppier than fred but not over hoppy very well balenced chewy and thick sweet and smooth but I did like fred better imo

12 oz 2004 bottle thanks to pineypower. Wow did this one hold up nicely. Poured a deep dark ruby reddish brown with a small bubbly beige head, actually lots of head for a 5 year old BW. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel, vanilla extract, sherry, citrus hops and alcohol. The flavor is mostly dominated by caramel and toffee but a little bit of oxidation is noticed and some cardboard notes are creeping in. Thick syrupy body with still noticable carbonation despite the age of this one. Im still impressed how the hops have held up in this one and how great it was drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2014 i could see a half inch of sediment on the botttom of the bottle, and there was no head before a vigorous swirl produced a trace.  intense hop aroma followed by some sweet malt and honey...quite intruiging.  smooth medium to full body, fully masking the 11% abv.  smooth.  taste is way more in balance than i expected.  best HOTD ive had to date.  lots of floral and bitter hops, but expertly balanced with malt and the honey is the perfect touch.  no sissy weak ass honey ale will ever do the trick again.

12 ounce bottle (2008) from Holiday Wine Cellar.  Pours a muddy orange-brown with virtually no head.  Even with a careful pour, there are still a lot of floaty things and a big layer of yeast left at the bottom of the bottle.  Sweet aroma of malts, lots of fruits (bitter citrus, berry), a little bit of alcohol.  Sweet flavor of sticky caramel, honey, and fruits.  The sweetness never becomes cloying but rather the hops kick in and give this an incredible balance and a great finish.  The 10.5% is altogether hidden in this one.  Complex and very good.

12oz bottle, 2003 release
Pours a rich, dark chestnut brown with nice tight tan head. Aroma gives a hint of the lush malt and strongish hop content; some hint of raisins and a touch of soy are there too. Flavor is drier and hoppier than I had anticipated given the malt that showed up in the aroma. Dry, fairly bitter, leathery, tobacco-leafy, and finally some malt shows up. along with ints of dried tart fruit. Palate is thick and chewy. This is a well-crafted beer and hence I give it decent marks. But while I appreciate that theres some room for interpretation of the style, Im not big on examples that almost forget how the barleywine style got its name. It could have scored higher but it was just too dry, too hoppy, and not enough "wine" so to speak in this barleywine..
Had at the brewery on tap. Very good barley wine, not bitter at all. Herbal hoppy sweet aroma. Very sweet taste actually from the honey which masks the 10.5% ABV. Very good.

Wow.  I opened the cap and there is a solid cake of something under the cap.  not intimidated... this beer is fierce.  Pours dark amber with enough head for me to think its flat.  A mountain of sediment here.  Carbonation emerges slowly and shyly.  Nose is raisin, honey, caramel, piney hops, sugar, booze, fruit, and balance.  Flavor is magic- caramel, honey, alcohol-soaked fruit, and sweetness all over.  Silky mouthfeel and a light body for a barleywine.  Very lovable, and one of HOTDs best.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2014 Revisit with a 2012 bottle aged for about 2 years. Hops have died off and there is light oxidation bringing in mild sherry notes. 

Bottle 2008 poured a dark caramel colored with a thin off white head. Aroma has sweet rich malt, flowery hops, dark ripe fruit, nice yeasty smacks, and a bit of alcohol. Mouth feel coats well and has a nice heavy malted body. Flavor has a sweet malted side and a fruited hopped one. Light bitterness creeps up, dark fruit, and plenty warming. Very smooth and well  balanced with good sweetness but not too much.

2005. Great, deep amber color. Very inviting aroma of citrus and melon. Begins with a sharp bitter flavor of grass and grapefruit skins, quickly bringing in a hint of orange. Just before, and after this burst, is a more delicate, sweet, malty flavor, along with a good sour which lingers. The bitter, really the whole thing, leaves the mouth nicely dry at the end. Not  hint of alcohol, not even warmth. Every taste invites another. A masterpiece of flavor. Not everything works, but still one that stands with my very best.

2005 bottle opened April 2009.  Nutmeg color like dark iced tea.  Even in the snifter the head wont go away.  Fluffy, porous, and off white.  Intoxicating aroma from 3 feet away.  Big, sweet, and herbacious.  A mouthful of love.  Heavy, sweet, floral, with just a little more than a touch of alcohol.  Bitterness hits after about 45 seconds.  Full bodied but not sickly.  Great.  Hard to imagine much better.
Splendide bière. Barley wine très différente de couleur ambrée et presque jaune. Trouble et ayant une mousse persistante, elle nous offre de bonnes notes dhoublon et dalcool bien balancés.

2006 bottle. Great nose to this beer. No head at all. Lots of fruit going on in this one. A very good barley wine with taste of fruit but not too much. Tastes of some fruit lil bit of citrus hops. Not very much carbonation. Still a great beer that im glad i was able to try.

2008 bottle. Pours a clear deep amber with a small but lasting off white head. Aroma of honey, sweet malts, caramel, and a good dose of citrus to back everything up. Taste is sweet honey, citrus hops, sweet malt, caramel, and almost a light molasses finish. Full mouth feel with a moderate amount of bitterness and a warm but smooth finish. A damn fine brew.

Bottle from bottletrek.  Pours hazy brown with no head.  Aroma of caramel, fruit, and since this one is newer...dominated by hops, mainly citrus.  Hides the 10.5% very well and it doesnt seem as thick or have the syrup consistency some other barleywines can get.  Very good.

12oz bottle of 2006 vintage. Ive had this several times before (I bought a whole case) but never got around to rating it. Man is it aging nicely.

Pours with almost no head and no carbonation at all. Wildly aromatic with fruit notes, toffee and apricot. More toffee, figs, tea (maybe Im imagining that one), excellent malt and a lingering, hop bite. Theres very little evidence of the alcohol as this one ages. It really has developed beautifully. 

Wonderful!

Best beer from my session at Sals. Great big fresh nose. Huge sweet floral tones. Full bodied. Rich and flavourful. There is lots of fruit, particularly apricot. Not as sticky and over the top as some other barley wines, therefore I think I enjoyed it that much more. Really well done for the style.
Poured brown with no head. Aroma of caramel. Fruit and caramel flavors. Thick and smooth.

2005 vintage. Mature, full aroma of sweet fruit, raisins, earthy hops and sweet caramell. Flavour has the same with a extra touch of liqourice and leather. Very candylike, fairly complex, extremely well composed brew that satisfies when you want a real slow sipper.
Pours out dark copper with light foam. Taste is sweet and malty. Toffee, caramel, and honey. Piney hoppy finish with some alcohol warming. Spicy, fruity sweet syrup. A full flavor brew, complex.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2009 Re-rate.  I used to not like barleywines, I had trouble with the huge malty body that most of them have.  It was just too much for me.  I rated this one pretty badly at the time when I first had it, and upon looking back I honestly have no idea what the f*ck I was thinking.  I know that I tried to like it since Id heard so much about how great HOTD is.  I just didnt get it I guess, because this is just a fantastic beer.  The great caramelly malt body (which is a little much, bordering on cloying, but it works) is counter-balanced wonderfully by a perfect amount of resinous hop flavor and bitterness.  Ill have to go get more of this before it disappears off the shelves this xmas.  Cheers Alan and thanks for another great beer.

Dark and clear copper/amber body, amazingly steady lacing on small head. The nose reached accross the room! Very rich honey and malts, tons of over ripe fruits and some toffee. Too many scents to break down, a lot going on. Very sweet taste, a bit over the top, but it clams down through the sip. Some spice in the opening as well. Very rich. Fruits, toffee, and rum sweets as well. A very rich and complex brew. Palate is pure oily syrup. A beautiful desert wine, but it almost bowled me over after imbibing some others first.

12 oz. Bright orange/amber pour with a small amount of off white head. Quite a bit of bubbles throughout and nice lacing. Sweet malt and candied fruit aroma. Just hints of citrus and pine. A less lively mouthfeel than it appears, quite sticky. Taste has much sweet malt and candied fruits. Brown sugar and piney citrus accent it. Finish is lingering candy as well. Thought it would be just a bit more drinkable with some more carbonation. I think this is a pretty unique take on the style though, and definetely worth trying. 2nd good brew Ive had from HOTD in 2 tries.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of HogtownHarry- Pours a very still deep rusty bronze. Bose is big and fruity, fig and plum, some gold rum, hop resin, pine, lots of wood. Tastes of sweet caramel malts, earthy piney hops, grapefruit, bourbon, butterscotch. Nice. Still again in the finish, very warming, syrupy. A good sipper. Thanks Harry!

2006 bottle... . lots of sugary aromas, honey and golden syrup .. . dark golden on the pour, head b+  .. . sooo smooth, age is good .. . sweet molasses and more golden syrup.. . albatross cum, very nice .. enjoyable.. .

Thanks for sharing, bro!

Pours a coppery caramel-color with a lot of tapioca-looking sediment.  Aroma is resinous hops, earthiness, and apple peel. Taste is rather bitter with earthy hops, apple, and slight caramel malts.  I expected more from this, but not too bad.

Trade from Ross.  Thanks man.  Pours a cloudy caramel color with no head.  Seriously, it looked like a Werthers candy had diarrhea in my glass.  Anyway, the aroma is intensely hoppy.  Man, lots of grapefruit and citrus intermingle with alcohol, some lemon, caramel, and light spice.   Taste is citrus hops, alcohol, caramel, and some fruitiness.  Very small trace of carbonation but the alcohol is not boozy, just warming.  Lot of grainy sediment in this one as well, like I was drinking sand.  Not what I was expecting from HOTD, but still a decent beer.  Thanks Ross!

Very deep amber in colour with a long lasting beige head, good lacing.  The aroma is very rich with lots of malt, caramel, gingerbread, light alcohol, dark fruits and figs.  The flavour is a bit oxidized, more alcohol is noticeable then in the aroma, gingerbread, stale hops with a moderate bitterness.  Warming mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, malty and quite warm.
I found this one weird.  Definitely starting to show some age.  High bitterness makes it a bit harsh at times, I would like to see this a little smoother.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with 5000, thanks Andre.
Opened on November 28, 2008.
Vintage 2003.

Liked this one better than HOTD Adam.  gotta find a way to get ahold of some dave though.  this beer smells great.  opens up the room.  with they made hard of the dog doggie claws cologne or something
2007 on draft at Hard Liver Barleywine  Fest 09. Well balanced, with good fruit and solid sweet malty backbone. Excellent and way to easy to drink for 10.5 ABV.

Wow this is by far the best Barley Wine out there. Zero soapiness and no flowery scents. Most BW are cough syrupy. This is a more hopped up version and the sweetness comes in the form of brown sugar and thick malts. The hops are not bittering but definetly present. A bit on the sweet side but its a great desert beer.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2012 Couldnt believe I hadnt rated this one before. 07 vintage at Brouwers Hard Liver 09. Pours orange-copper with a thin head. Ripe fruit, sweet malts - almost syrupy sweet. Definitely not enough on the hop end to balance this one out. Covers the alcohol well, but this one would get old after more than half a glass. Good, for sure... but not great. RE-RATE 08/09/12: After rounding out my taste, this one has kicked up a couple notches. The sweetness offered by the wild flower honey (and the massive malt bill) have become my favorite flavors in a barley wine. Hops are apparent, but sit in the background on this one -- which is how I think it should be. Tastes something like a really old English barley wine -- sweet, toffee-infused candi sugar -- just delicious. Especially if you can find it on tap.

12 oz bottle, 2004 version sampled March 2009: rocky foam rises from the bottle, curling and twisting 1/2 an inch above the top of the bottle...maroon & mahogany hued, cloudy body with an off white cream that diminishes into a thin film.  Still thick aromatics...the floral hops have died off significantly and the caramel has turned slightly burnt, with some alcohol bitterness.  Resiny hop oils are left lingering and tickle the nose.  Sweet strawberries, cherries and raisins make up an incredibly smooth and creamy palate.  Tart and acidic with an amazing amount of citrus left over after 5 years.  A bit of cloyed honey builds up as I work my way through the glass.  The citrus has turned overly sweet and sappy and without the bitterness of the fresh hopsI am left feeling a little one-sideddang it, why did I wait 5 years?  2 or 3 would have been perfect8/4/6/4/15-3.7

12 oz bottle, 2004 version sampled July 2005: elegant violet-ruby body with an incredibly thick, sticky off-tan cream that leaves a thin, though dense layer of lace all around the snifterthick, melted caramel aroma with notes of alcohol soaked raisins, hop cones and strawberries.  Silky palate with loads of nice fruity notes: sweet, sticky honey drips over toffee, pineapple slices, rhubarb, and candy sugar.  The finish leaves a good bit of alcohol on the tongue and stickiness on the lips, but this after dinner treat leaves nothing but satisfaction though out the body8/4/8/4/17-4.1

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2015 2007 bottle thanks to ditmier, he sent it out to congratulate the upcoming birth of my son, Aidan. Well, he was born today and I drink this beer as a new father, but also as a man who appreciates the real friends I have on RB. So how can I give a objective rating after all of this, well I cant. Im unbelievably tired but this beer just hit the spot so well. Pours a ruddy copper color with lots of particulates and a big beige head. The aroma is amazing; sweet caramel, hops, lots of fruity and caramel malts. Powerful and enticing. The flavor is so smooth its sick; lots of initial sweetness, sugars, caramel, and toffee. The nearly dry malt is powerful, and a ton of juicy citrus hops in here. Light alcohol noticed. Warm and merry. Sweet and balanced. A top beer . Also, a great full mouthfeel.   
2013 is very good. Well carbonated. Newer versions have been flat and not tasting as well.

Poured hazy orange-bronze with a short white head.  Thick lacing.  Earthy herbal hop aroma with heavy pine and some honey.  Semi-viscous mouthfeel.  Great taste.  Lots of resiny goodness up front and throughout.  Avoids the soapiness in some of these hoppy barleywines.  Smooth, sweetened citrus and brown sugar flavor towards the back.  This flows with tropical fruit overtones; pineapple, mango, kiwi, and some melon.  Long finish, slightly sticky.  Wish I had bought more.

Pours orange with a thin white head. Good lacing in my snifter. Nice aromas of caramel,toffee,pine hops,and heavy alcohol. Medium to Full bodied with some fizzy carbonation. Texture was slick with a average bitterness and a heavy sweetness. Overall an awesome barleywine.

12oz bottle courtesy of mfielden. Pours a hazy dark caramel with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of honey, chocolate, citrus, caramel some slight spice. Flavor is sweet and floral with honey, caramel, malt, apple, bread, some hints of spice and yeast with notes of phenol as well. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing caramel malt finish. Nice BW.

2005 Bottle. Poured a ruby color with a creamy tan head that had some lasting and left light lace. Nice aroma of chocolate and honey with a light hopped undertone. The flavor found honey, caramel, chocolate and a hop background. Medium to full body, sweet, and a honey aftertaste. Very nice.

[Bottle] brought back from S.F. Pours a hazy caramel with a soapy beige head. Powerful malty aroma with some citric hops, caramel/toffee, and significant alcohol. Flavor is a bit different from the aroma, and is lighter than what I was expecting. Plenty of alcohol presence, caramel, fruity yeastiness, somewhat oily palate, and a touch of butter.

08 vintange bottle shared with the kid. Pours a cloudy amber brown with mild carbonation that looks a little oily on the glass. Malty, bready but not much for a hop aroma as far as I can tell. Alchohol warming over the tongue with a load of sweet caramel and bit of a butter to the taste and a little oily on the tongue. This one may have been consumed while it was a bit young but it was very good none-the-less.

2007 bottle thanks to my sis in law who said "This looked neat and I thought you would like it!"  HA!
12oz bottle pours medium copper brown with a slight off white head.  Alot of dark fruits come out in the aroma.  Some figs, toffee, creme brulee, caramel and even some oak in the taste.  A bit of chocolate at the end.  Some alcohol bunr, but not overly noticeable.  Very easy drinking and just what I needed on a Friday.

Plumb and malt and sweetness. As amazing as this barley wine is, it baffles me since most Hair of the Dogs defy taxonomic categorization. But this...this is a barley wine. No doubt about it. A great barley wine. Caramel. Sweet. Really nice.

A very interested brew. I was told that it should be left to age, and would better with age, but Im not typically one to cellar beers, so I consumed it upon returning to my home. This was the most tasty, drinkable barleywine I have ever encountered. I usually have a hard time consuming them. Citrus aroma and sweet caramel malts. Fresh hops up front and ends sweet with a slight hint of alcohol. Very good beer!

Courtesy trade with Chewy. Thanks man! Yet another beer I thought Id only read about. A nice barley wine and a lot more drinkable than most. Aroma was good. All caramel with nothing else. Pour was perfect. A thick and soupy mix with no bubbles and a light tan film for a head. Looks like sewage and that is fine with me. Its actually intimidating. Taste was very mellow and easy to drink. This beer tastes like a liquified Sugar Daddy. Its all sweet caramel malt with no hops present. Just a hint of carbonation rounds this beer out. Very interesting. Imagine drinking a glass of lightly carbonated caramel and you have this beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor. There was a bold and upfront aroma of lightly citrus scented hops and sweetness from a sugary caramel malt. Appearance is a glowing mahogany color with a firm development of foam head but it will die out after some time has passed.  The flavor is extremely sweet and also possesses a bitter hop profile that creates a sticky resin coat inside my mouth .

Wow, this is a flat-out phenomenal beer.  Pours a cloudy orangish amber color with a small head.  Hop aromas jump out at you immediately along with a honey sweetness.  Flavor is fresh hops up front - Simcoe and Amarillo work well together - then lots of wild honey along with caramel malts.  Alcohol is present but well hidden.  Smooth palate.  Some sediment remains at the end, not that it detracts from the beer at all.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 08 bottle Pours hazy dark amber, caramel, nutty, fruity, alcohol, little gritty, little citrus peel, little hoppy.  Rerate at Toronado Barleywine Fest.  Smoother, better all around.  My favorite of what I tasted that day.

08 bottle. Completely opaque, murky tan-grapefruit red, small white head gone quickly. Strong fruit nose thats bitingly citric: sour grapefruit is most dominant, some light caramel and nut with warmth, but its not entirely cohesive, something dragging. It reminds me a bit of DFH120. Flavor is similar except there is far more balance and the fruit takes on a slightly lactic, sweet note in the finish. Unique to say the least.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle. Courtesy of tomthompson. 2006. pours a murky coffee & cream color. Hoppy, caramel, boozy, butter scotch. Last beer of a long Saturday night @ the Coles Rare Beer Fest. 7/2/7/2/14

2011 bottle. murky bronze copper pour. Sweet honey notes, orange heavy citrusy hops. Rich rich maltiness, toffee & piney hops, Very good
8/3/8/4/17

2006 Bottle thanks to MrChopin.  Just looking at the bottle, I knew I was in for a murky treat.  It poured a muddy, semi-bright brown with orange hues.  Zero head.  Looked like a strong English Breakfast tea with milk in it.  Intimidating, actually, but made me curious.  Instead of making me think of caramel flavor, this smelled and tasted like sweet, complex caramel.  Big Amarillo hop presence, too.  The combination of the hops and malt added up to a really nice creamy bready fruit taste.  Mixture of dark and lighter fruit notes. Bit of butterscotch that could perhaps indicate some oxidation.  Nice bitter finish. Thin body, but overall this was a treat.

Pours a dark amber, almost brown color.  Head is beige and dense.  Hop aromas of grass and earth come through, while the more citric hoppiness blends with the intense honeyed malt character.  Flavor is sweet with caramel and honey notes.  Some raisin bread and an earthy finish with medium bitterness.  Warming but not too viscous.  Nice drinkability.
2006 vintage.. poured a murky creamy orange color... odd. nose is nice big booze, caremel malts and hops flavor is strong booze and hops malt is sweet. good but odd. wondering about the color????

2008 Bottle.  Nice mostly clear reddish orange color, but head/carbonation is so nonexistent, I wonder if something went wrong here.  Nose is fruity and hoppy, but not very strong.  Good viscous mouthfeel, but a LITTLE more carbonation would be nice.  I hope Im not crucifying a bad bottle for this.  Strong strawberry sweetness is mostly balanced by the hoppy bitterness- pretty good.

I almost had to cry I went to put this 2005 vintage bottle that thethrone sent me in the cellar for another day and heard it hissing so I quickly chilled it down and poured it into a snifter that was a close one. We did have a gusher, so I wont get to much into the appearance, big tan head hazy apple cider colored yes floaties as well good thing I like Belgians. My score reflects giving it the benefit of the doubt

But the aromas made up for the whole gusher moment one of the best Barleywine noses I have ever had the pleasure of drinking. Sweet caramel, wait is this a melted sugar daddy ;-) toffee, candy sugar, fruity as well 

A nice sweet sipper even more enjoyable as the glass goes on. the flavors folow the nose to a T. The warmth of the alcohol is still present and helps this brew from being to coy. This barleywine is medium in the mouth and sticky on the tongue.

I must say some of the brews I have had on my want list I have tried and thought wow that was a waste of space. This is not one of them, this brew is truly a must try for any barleywine fiend. Thanks again Adam, I didnt plan on drinking this tonight but I am glad I did. Drinkability that is answered simply by saying I want more

Really delicious.  Pours a thick, cloudy honey color--inelegant but distinctive.  Piney, grapefruity aroma.  Tastes like prunes, figs, green apple, bright citrus, and pine in a honey/brown sugar sauce.

2008 bottle.  Pours a very clear glowing dark deep blood red with a slight orange tint, no bubbles, with a very small frothy white head.  Strong fresh hop aroma, spicy, perfumy, floral, fruity, stingy fresh citrus nose, sweeter red fruits, with an toasted malt undertone.  I assume fresh this is best served a bit on the cooler side because of the hops.  Strong hop forward first taste, turning dry, pretty bitter, salty and toasty before finishing with a touch of honey and hint of brown sugar.  Doesnt seem quite as complex as other HOTDs however the flavors are definitely of the same quality.  Really quite dry despite its obvious high gravity.  Unbelievably smooth and somehow creamy body, super fine soft carbonation that fluffs up a malty beer that otherwise would seem syrupy.  I have 3 other bottles for some age comparison.  [Pour slowly as I had a considerable amount of yeast ruin the last 3 oz or so of my beer]

Bottle thanks to BMan1113VR. Almost no head. Orange reddish hazy colored body. Nose is citrus, pink grapefruit, red wine, and alcohol. Smells pretty dang good. Taste is carmel, butterscotch, dark corn syrup (think popcorn balls), very sweet but finishes with a bitter kick. Mouthfeel is nice and sticky and the finish is long. Nice effort.

courtesy of goodzoid10.
Pure goodness, ber is amazing from start to finish. Bets enjoyed at somewhat close to room temperature.
Pours clear brown - amber with tan head and lingering lacing.
Aroma is loaded with good hops, light sugary - honey notes, citrus-grapefruit fruits, caramel.
Where the whole charm of this beer comes to life is in its taste.
All the hops come together with the malts for an amazing experience. All is terrifically well balanced.
The bitter hops is balanced out with the hops and the sweet addition of honey - brown sugar, making this beer an extremely smooth and sweet beer.
Some floating sediments in the bottom. Beer could just get better with age.
12oz, 2006 vintage. Dark amber pour with very little head, lots of yeast stuck on the bottom of this bottle as well. Sweet, malty aroma. Flavor is muck the same, pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 2006 12oz bottle. Thanks to kegbear for this brew. Pours murky reddish brown with no head. Aroma is sweet malt, hops, brown sugar and some booze. Flavor is sweet malt, dark fruits, hops, brown sugar, booze. Mouthfeel is flat. Finishes sticky and sweet like HoTD Fred and DFH 120. I liked this better than Fred but still not my favorite barleywine. It has a nice complexity but I prefer a thicker mouthfeel and more carbonation.
Crushed with CaryTheDude and JakeBra. Pours murky brown. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Flavor is sweet and sticky. Pretty nice. Cool to drink.
Crushed with Jakebra and Honkeybra.  Murky look.  Sexy.  Good hop nose, but somethings missing.  Nice mouthfeel.  Flavor is good.  Not quite excellent, but definitely aight.

2008 12oz from Bottleworks. Brilliant ruby, hazy amber pour with absolutely minimal head. Nose of pine, funky french cheese, maple. Luscious, velvety mouthfeel with a touch of heat and stickiness. Flavor is robust brown suggary malt and undertones of leather, jerky, smoke and dark wood. Notes of Fred, really... this is most definitely a HOTD beer. Very well balanced, unique and intriguing BW; im very impressed. Would love to try this aged...

12 ounce room temp 2008 bottle in Duvel glass.  Decanted clear amber wih lasting ring and some lace.  Caramelized brown sugar port wood and fresh aromatic floral hop aroma.  Caramelized brown sugar raisin wood bready flavor, not excessively fruity.  Dry bitter finish.  Perfectly blended complex flavors.  Full body and medium-low carbo.  Hard to imagine a better barleywine.  A new fave.

Marvelous drink. Huge hop character atop an incredible fruit-laced, honey-sweetened, caramelized barleywine malt backbone.  The hops really shine with fantastic spicy character and floral components.  Slight herbal bits with notable raisin and plum.  Incredible complexity that is well matched to a fantastic hop lineup and a well hidden alcohol content.

bottle. 06. dark marroon with a minimum of head. practically still. booze and fruit nose.  sweetness is all over this, very little bitterness, verges on cloying.  too much plum and raisin for me. not one i’m going to look for again.
2 5 4 2 9

2008 bottle thanks to hannont.  deep amber pour with no head at all.  no carbonation at all with a nose of slight hops but mostly honey and malts.  thick on the palate with a hop flavor and a touch of honey in the finish.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 2008 bottle.  Aroma of cinnamon and caramel.  Dark amber.  Tastes very much like a good scotch ale, however you describe one of those.  Balanced malt and caramel.

12 oz. bottle.  Cloudy dark golden color, very small head and low carbonation.  Aroma is like an IPA, lots of floral hops and some honey.  Very sweet flavor initially which gives way to the hops.  Starts with caramel, toffee and some sweet fruit, then finishes bitter and extremely dry.  A bit too sweet at first, but the finish makes up for it.  Palate is thick and sticky.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, vintage 2004. I already had a great Christmas - just take a look at the other ratings- but this finishing beer really made it perfect. Loads of malts in the aroma, dough, raisin and too much to mention. Brown color, yellow/brown head, good lace. Grapes, raisin, madeira, very sweet, loads of malts, pretty bitter. So complex, they didnt forget anything. To me its like a perfect marriage between Westvleteren and Thomas Hardys.

2008 Bottle. Pours a beautiful hazy auburn with a light ring of head. When agitated it produces a fine sea of off-white head. Great lacing, on a really pretty beer. Aroma is strongly simcoe, with pine and citrus intermixed with honey and orange blossom. Taste is very nice and sweet but not cloying in any way. Notes of honey and orange blossom, great alcohol presence. Near perfect balance of sweet and hop bitterness, which makes it dangerously easy to drink. Syrupy mouthfeel, with notes of honey, warming, but not hot at all. Light carbonation. I absolutely love this beer, and plan on aging a couple, although it doesnt seem to need any extra age.

Bottle. Vintage 2005. Pours a wonderful clear amber / hazelnut brown. A small, creamy-ish yellow-beige head. Stunning aroma, oxidized a bit. Lots of fruity hops, butterscotch, honey, some apples, plums. Light vinious. Low and elegant carbonation, fabolous oily mouthfeel. Flavour is truly well-balanced. Lots of plums, some Christmas cookies, apples. And a shit-load of caramel. The oxidation is nearly nowhere in the flavours. It is quite sweet and a bit sticky, but the alcohol serves it really well. It never becomes overpowering. This is just like a well-cellared Old Stock with added honey and some Christmas notes. Fuck, this is a good Christmas beer!

Bottle courtesy of Styles.  2006 Batch.  Pours a caramel apple color with a trim tan head.  Turns amber as it settles.  Loaded with butterscoth, caramel, honey, and overripe red apples.  Yeasty, and so sicky sweet its retarded.  A memorable beast of a beer.

Well, I had made this review after having enjoyed the 2008 "Fred from the Wood." This, now, is incredibly smooth and altogether especially as it is fresh--this is the 2008 bottle. It is overall sweet and spicy. But what works is how all the ingredients are blended together subtlety--hops, honey, and malts are very good. I think I note butterscotch, chocolate, honey, brown sugar, some tea quality, and some citrus. There is more to this. It is festive. And there is no overbearing alcohol note. This is a very good brew.

Hair of the Dog Doggie Claws
Huge thanks to bitbucket.

Smells very good, complex, sweet malts, spices, hops

Pours hazy red amber with a bit of head  very nice

Taste  even though this is a 2007 bottle it tastes quite a bit hotter than I would prefer, sweet, spices, some hops, maybe a spice thats a bit strange? 

Mouthfeel  good and thick 

Overall this is a confusing beer.  It smells glorious but the taste is less good.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2009 updating this, as I pulled a bottle from the cellar.  6 months old.  Wow what a change.
Well balanced thick malty front with a nice hoppy finish.  aroma of citrus and honey.
This is really fantastic.

Bottle from 07. Pours a murky copper with no head. Nose is hops, alcohol, and fruity. Interesting in that it starts off syrupy, but then the hops kick in, and they are pretty  big,and good.Carbonation is pretty light, helping create the syrupy effect.But the hops dominate. Has kind of a spice bittersweet  finish. And the 11% is pretty noticeable, but not overpowering. Very good.

bottle,  a muddy brown orangish color, slight foam, nose is hoppy pines and butterscotch, flavor of grapefruit, malt, brown sugar and a very nice smooth bitter finish, not as heavy or overpowering as expected

Cloudy orange-brown, slow-to-rise yellow-tinted head that generates lace for the first half of the glass. Very rich, heady toffee and spice aroma, along with candied orange, and subtle resin. Velvety, heavy mouthfeel. Rich toffee flavour, chewy, with beguling spices competing with a massive hop attack (bitter citrus oils and resin, a definite hint of anise). Sweet up front, but balanced very nicely by a bitter finish that is very long and very dry. There is subtlety in here that I enjoyed to the last drop. Wonderful!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Great pour, nice hazy ruby/golden with meaty looking head.  Powerful malty aromas to smell and even more to taste.  Powerful and complex flavors all over the place work very well together.  Drinks easily for the high alcohol content, and this one makes a great nightcap.  Delicate and layered, yet forceful on the palate, very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 12oz bottle 2005: 11/20/2008

appearance dark brown in color with huge cream color head, aroma heavy in citrus and grapefruit hops and a good amount of malt, flavor huge in the citrus and grapefruit hops as expected but backed by a very unique malt flavor that has hints of chocolate and nuts  and just the right amount of carbonation. I hate to say it but this was a much better BW then the 08 doggie claws I had. Best beet I have had to date.

08 doggie claws: 11/20/2008

9 4 9 4 17
Didnt have as complex malt flavor and needed more carbonation who knows it could age to be as good as the 05 but I know I will be picking more 05 up at the next dock sale.

2010 doggie claws: 12/24/2010

Ar:9, Ap:5, T:9, P:5, O:19

12oz bottle:

Appearance is very dark amber brown with very long lasting creamy off white head. Aroma is of floral hops and a slightly less powering malty notes. Flavor is why I continue to buy this beer! Huge on hops up front with an equally powerful malt backbone and a slightly nutty flavor. I was thinking this one had to age a bit before it tasted as good as the 05, as the 08 was relatively green when I fist had it and the 05 had aged 3 years. But this 2010 doggie claws should only be a month or two old and is right up there with the 2005 brew. Once again, my favorite beer is back.

2007 Bottle - Pours an amberish copper with a large off white head...aroma is palpable hop bitters and caramel malt...from the nose, I fully expected this to be a hop bomb, but that was not the case...well balanced caramel and subtle hops, tons of dried fruit, killer alcohol, a year in the bottle made this twice as nice...great dessert

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 Getting notebook online. Bottle, 2006. A hoppy port! The good raisin/date oak flavors usually in a barley wine with some great hop flavors. Very nice!

Re-sampled with the 2010. I really enjoy the Simcoe hope profile in this batch. A sweet honey and malt thread really pulls it all together. This batch isnt as forward with the oak and dark fruit notes like the 06 I remember. I wonder if that comes more with aging. Overall a really tasty American Barleywine.

Bottle.  Pours a copper brune body with 1 finger off white head.  Sweet with caramel malt dark fruit dates, plum and raisins.  Hoppy with lots of pine and dried fruit.  A very enjoyable bw with a nice warming.

Bottle. Courtesy of Pinball. Muddy brown colour with no head. The bottle should have rested for a day or so before opening it. Lots of barley and dry fruity hops in aroma. Flavour is very ridh malty and hoppy in a great balance. Some spices and peach there as well. Creamy body.

Bottle. Low and fluffuy quickly disappearing off-white head. Dishwater look-a-like body. Malty heavy barley malt aroma with some alcohol notes. Flavor pretty alcohol dominated hoppy but also with some sweet and fruity notes. Low carbonation. Short aftertaste. Complex and well balanced.  Too bad that the alcohol is so dominant.

Pours a dark amber color with a big light brown head. Very sweet tasting and smelling barleywine with toffee, raisins and almonds being apparent in both. Very chewy consistency and all in all just pretty damn good.

Botella. Muddy yeasty coffee with milk looking brew. Lovely intense hoppy fruity aroma. Very good mouthfeel. Sweet very hoppu soft nicely bitter alco pleasant flavour. Sweet yeasty nice hoppy mild alco finish.

thanks jeppe!. ar: hoppy, after a while, goes dark fruity.
appearance: sewer water, moud.
flavor: hoppy, mouldy, sweet. has been better, signs of too much aging.  15 overall high, flavor taken down bc the honey gives me a sharp bitter flavor i don’t like. this beer is better than 3.1

Vintage 2004. Pours a hazy dark amber with an off white head and a few floaties. Smells of caramel. Quite sweet with lots of toffee aromas. Also aromas of raisins and prunes. Also a faint touch of citric hopsaromas. Full body. Medium carbonation. Slightly sticky mouthfeel. Some residual sugars. Short toffee-and-raisin finish. Awesome. BIG thanks to whoever traded me this one; sorry for forgetting who you are.

Bottle thanks to BuckeyeBoy. Poured dark amber with big tan head. Aroma was floral, hoppy, citrus, and sweet. Taste was very smooth and creamy, with floral and citrus hops. Finished very nice and enjoyed very much. A nice barley wine.

I had a 2007.  This dark amber pour has notes of hops, citrus, and grain.  Sweet, warming flavor.  It is a very distinct barley flavor.  You can definitely taste the northwest in this beer if that makes any sense.

Sampled in a single blind tasting side by side.  I had 2 properly stored vintages, 04 and 05.  The total score is an average of the two scores.  Beer #1 (2005) - Aroma is sweet, fruity, vinous, and very aromatic.  There is a lightly ethanolic note to this.  This is wonderfully aromatic and very pleasant.  There are some chocolate-milk like notes in this.  Smells soooo good.  Very muddy, murkey sludge-like brown-amber body with a nice off-yellow head.  Wow...this is like cigar tobacco.  A bit smoky, too.  This is actually very similar to the cigar I had last night, as a matter of fact.  Some dry, roasty, lightly astringent notes are present in the middle with plenty of roastiness in the finish.  This is like a liquid cigar.  9/3/7/4/15/3.8  ..... Beer #2 (2004) - Sweet, caramel, vinous, fruity aroma with a little chocolate, too.  Pretty quaffable, but not as good as the first beer.  Mildly hazy garnet body with a nice, frothy light tan head and nice lacing.  A very attractive brew.  This brew also has a bit of cigar tobacco flavor with some peaty malts and chewy, caramel flavors in the middle.  Ethanol is not detectable.  Very mellow brew with some lightly bitter hops in the finish.  I also get some chocolate flavors late.  Really good brew.  7/5/9/5/17/4.3

2007 bottle.  Watching southpark and waiting for a pretty girl to come over to my apt.  Tasted Dales Pale ale before this and it was Very good.  Im really excited about this brew.  
Hazy golden pour, dissipating fizzy white head.  Dark sticky malt aromas, sweet and hoppy.  a little bit of burnt sugar and or caramel.  Intense Malt and  tobacco.  Almost like a sweet bourbon, the mouthfeel  is relatively creamy.  Alcohol is present in the mouht but mostly comes out in the finish as a woody alcohol finish.  Very enjoyable, a great sipper.

Bottle. Huh....this is one unique brew from start to finish. Garnet colored with just a hint of a soapy head, nearly flat. Massive nose of oiled leather, scotch, rich fruits, and a few notes of red wine. Really sweet flavors of syrup, honey, tobacco, and a lovely warming sweet bourbon filling the mouth at the end. It’s really impressive how there is zero alcohol burn or heat left in the mouth with a beer this strong and this flat. Typically it takes carbonation to hide this burn, but not here. Weird, unique, almost more like a super sweet bourbon than a beer, but really enjoyable.

2006 bottle acquired via trade with kegbear...thanks Craig!!!  This brew poured  a rich ruby red/garnet with absolutely no head and only minimal carbonation bubbling up from the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is dark candied fruit, toffee, caramel, and brown sugar.  Nice natural sweetness, the hops have all but melted away with aging as has the alcohol burn.  A very nice beer...would love a fresher bottle for comparison.

12oz bottle from new beer distributors in manhattan.  pours a dark red-brown color with a medium head that stick around.  aroma of citrus hops and fruity dark candy caramel malts.  aroma still somehow comes off as more of a dIPA than barley wine.  taste is sweat caramel, apricot and light alcohol.  syrupy medium texture.  nice light bitter finish.  a really well balance brew.  could be my favorite barley wine so far.  K-8

Appearance is a murky ruby red/amber hue with a modest layer of creamy white head, fair lacing on the glass.

Smell is a range of hops, mostly floral/grassy/citrus, sweet toffee and caramel malts, dark fruits, brown sugar, oak, and booze.

Taste is initially dark fruits, booze, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, and caramel malts, transitions to sour and piney hops, finishes with sweet honey and raisins with alcohol warming.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied, thick and oily texture with a prickly feel from the carbonation and alcohol presence.

Drinkability is moderate, this is a lighter yet more flavorful barleywine than what I’m used to, a great mix of taste sensations in the overall profile and a not-overwhelming alcohol presence, another solid offering from HoTD.

Tasted @ Higgins in Portland.
I’ve had the Hair of the Dog Doggie Claws 2007. Very nice barleywine. Orange colored. Aroma is sweet, hoppy and fruity. Herbal, hoppy, creamy, sweet caramel flavors. Flavor shifts during tasting, very nice smooth brew.

Bottle from PC Market of Choice in Ashland, OR.  I bought another bottle of this because I was excellently trashed (on our 13th serious brew of the night) at the time.  All I remember is this one had a beautiful, sweet tinge to it that was awesome.  I wrote that it smelled almost lambic and fruity, and it had a sweet and malty backbone.  I’m aging my other bottle.

This was 2007 12 on bottle.  This was special evening as I also reached my 1000th rating with Brew Dog Paradox Macallan. Interesting....two "dogs" in one night.  

As good as the Brewdog was I think I liked this even better.Got this from Market of Choice in Ashland. Poured a cloudy orange color with moderate off-white head with good lacing. Very powerful nose of citrus and floral hops.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Very flavorful, with grapefruit, oranges, lemons, and everything citrus.   Finish is both bitter and sweet. I love it when that happens.   A simply remarkable brew.

2007 bottle. Pours a hazy golden amber with a one-finger off-white head that lingered for quite a while leaving decent lacing.

Smell starts with a big citrus hop aroma with grapefruit up front giving way to the caramel malt and toffee background.  There is also a big sugar sweetness throughout the nose.

Taste is a bigger version of the nose with the hops up front in the form of grapefruit and lemons.  The sweetness takes over right after that burst with molasses and caramel.  There is a hint of the booze as well on top of a ton of raisins and dates before the citrus hops come back for a slightly bitter finish.

Mouthfeel is unbelievably creamy with strong carbonation that prickles the tongue.  Alcohol is present but not overpowering in the least.

This is a fantastic and original take on the style and one that I enjoyed immensely.  Another great brew from HotD.  Highly recommended!

Bottle from PC Market of Choice in Ashland, OR. 2007 Vintage. Poured a orange color with a hint of red. Almost no head and very little carbonation. Smelled like summer fuits and flowers. 
Thick a creamy, but smooth and went down easy. Probably the best barley wine I’ve had to date.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of nutty and caramel, moderate orange for the hops, moderate dough and soap for the yeast and date and brown sugar (or maybe it was the honey). Head was average sized, creamy, off-white with fair lacing and was mostly diminishing. Color is murky orange. Flavor starts heavily sweet and lightly acidic and the long finish is moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, syrupy (but not bad) and the carbonation is between soft and lively. It finishes moderately alcoholic. A well rounded Barley Wine with some of the deepest aromas I’ve experienced in a beer

Bottle from 2006, two years cellared. No head at all even though I tried to pour one. Low carbonation. Aroma of sweet fruits, honey and toffee. Tastes of sweet fruit and toffee with no hop bitterness. Smooth with a thick mouth feel and creamy taste. Tastes like cream sherry. I knew a girl named Sherry once, but she was no dog.

Really outstanding.  Bottle from Hi-Time in Costa Mesa aged 6 mo.  Very dark.  Later sips had me reminding myself that it wasn;t a stout.  Roastiness galore, currant, the faintest hint of pralines, chocolate and hops.  A very impressive beer.

Aroma: very, very nice, fresh, fruity  flowery hop aroma. Biscuity malts. Slightly chemical (bitter). 
Flavour: sweet, toasted, smoky, fruity, I love it! So many sweet malts leading to a non-cloying end. Bittersweet aftertaste. Fullbodied. 
Palate: near perfect, vinous, smooth but adequately fizzy... very fullbodied. 
Appearance: slightly dim orange, slightly coppery body with pale, fine sandy, yellowish foam. Nice.

Thanks Jimbo O. Pours a hazed roasted apricot color w/ a tall lasting froth. Good lacing w/ aromas of sweet, tart stonefruit nectar. Full nectar w/ a very creamy texture. Nice! Sweet and meaty w/ a defined mild tartness. Flavors from nectarines, plumbs, and apricot, including kiwi, pinapple, and caramel. The finish is long and savory. This brew has a moderate hop profile that does a good job in balancing this one out. It has an appealing milky texture that simply blows my mind. Good stuff man. Trump! This is the closest thing to Angels Share I have ever tasted.

2007 vintage.  Dark, burnt-orange to caramel brown in color, the brew is crowned in a dense, foamy, beige head.  The foam displays excellent retention, leaving sudsy, spotty lacing behind.  Aromas are reminiscent of a triple IPA, with massive orange, grapefruit, and pine hop notes showing atop an equally huge malt base of caramel and buttery toffee.  This thing practically smells sticky.  Vanilla, coupled with a lactic creaminess, lends a smoothing element.  Flavors follow suit, with over the top, resinous hops countering the sweet and sticky toffee malts.  Orange and grapefruit are striking in their authenticity, while pine delivers a mouth stripping, sharp bitterness that the lactose does well to calm down.  Nearly full bodied and sugary, the swallow is smooth, ending with a drying, hoppy finish.  This is really a hybrid IIPA/barleywine through and through.  The closest comparison I can come up with is AleSmith Decadence 2006, though this doesn’t quite stack up to that masterpiece of a beer.  Overall, this is quite good, but not nearly as impressive as Fred.

POured a reddish mud color with a faint off white head. Aroma is very sweet malty with a hint of hops and dark fruits. Flavor is very sweet up front, dark fruits caramel and malts, with a nice backup of hop bitterness.

Bottle @ home.[Vintage 2005] Light light unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, moderate hoppy, herbs, citrus - pine, herbel, plum, licorice, dark honey notes, alcohol. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. (100508)

2006 bottle.  A careful pour to avoid the one finger of sludge on the bottom results in a semi hazy amber brew in my snifter with zero head.  Theres not much carbonation in this bad boy anyway.  Nose is honey, molasses, toffee and dark fruits.  Taste is very cognac like  very sweet dark fruits with a funky earthy aftertaste.  Mouth feel is after dinner spirit like also with an oily, flat mouth feel.  Very warming, but the sweetness hides the alcohol nicely.  This is what I picture a barleywine should be in my minds eye.

2007 bottle:  Dark but not qutie opaque in color this had aromas of caramel, toffee and chocolate.  In the mouth it showed off these flavors along with dark fruit (plum) in a full-bodied beer.  It was rich and concentrated with serious weight on the palate.  The finish was fresher with some dry/bitterness from the hops.  While very enjoyable now I think a handful of years will help this mellow out and drink even better.

Bottle from bitbucket!  Thanks Bob!  Tried this a few times, but always forgot to rate it.  Love these Hair of the Dog beers, though.  Would be reason enough to move to Portland.  On to the beer: 2007 bottle. Pours deep amber with a huge fucking head. I guess it all depends on how your pour and into what glass.  I like using my rondenbach grand cru tulip because it always makes the beers look great. Nose is very hoppy, some alcohol upfront, and some light sweet malts. Flavor is very similar with a bit of hotness. Damnit, this is just how I remember it. Way too much alcohol.  I just dont feel like it blends that well together--at least for my tastes.  This is still very good beer, overall, but the flavors arent my favorite. Still love this brewery, though!

Very nice.  Found it way in the back of my beer fridge.  Orange amber pour with small head.  Aroma of some sweet malt and floral hops.  The hops hit you in the taste.  They overpower the sweet malt flavor and come out strong.  Good bitter finish.

355ml bottle, vintage 2006, shared with Finn Arvid. Murky, orange body. No head. Some laceworks on the glass. Dark hoppy smell with moderate sweetness. Initial taste of mandarin and orange shells follwed by dark honey supported by herbs and spices. Rich finish of malt, bitter hops and alcohol. Twisted mouthfeel and a joy to drink (02.06.2008).

12oz bottle 2007. Floral hop aroma and like most hotd alcohol. Amber body with off white head and moderate lacing. Citrus flavor along with a heavy malt presence and alcohol deteted in aroma wasnt in the flavor. Smooth on the palate.

12oz bottle thanks to amc3000.  2006 vintage.  Pours a cloudy brown-copper color with no head at all.  Unfortunately, I let quite a bit of sediment out of the bottom of the bottle.  Nose is of pitted fruit such as apricot and a bit of syrupy medicine.  Taste is of very ripe peach and apricot fruit.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with some alcohol warmth.  It is quite sweet and has some bitterness in the finish.
a dark red color with aromas of pine, hops, cherries, and alcohol. tastes of childrens cough syrup but it works for some reason. alcoholy taste to wash it down. complex and nice for dessert.

A cloudy brown-amber beer with tons of yeast sediment chunks (Ill give them the benefit of the doubt and blame my clumsy pour) and a decent fluffy off-white head that lasts and leaves lace. The aroma is very sweet, mostly floral hops and some caramel maltiness. The flavor is also quite sweet, with malt notes (toffee, molasses) and finishes long with caramel sweetness. This is a great beer, but a tad sweet for my taste. Alcohol well hidden.

12oz bottle. 2003 Vintage. Poured a medium ruby reddish color with a small sized off white head. Initial pour was clear but clouded up with floaters towards the bottom. Aromas of caramel, dark fruits, nutty, and a trace of citrus. Tastes of caramel, dark fruits (lots of plums and raisins), and brown sugary sweet. Light alcohol in the finish but overall well hidden. I thought this one is aging nicely.

Pours a dirty oramge color with lots of cloudiness.  Huge aroma of sharp bitter peach, citrus, and classic English-ale mustiness.  Theres an amazing alcohol burn that hits early and lasts long, sharp and stimulating.  Some toasty caramel in the background, but the bitter citrus-and-peach hoppiness ultimately dominates the flavors.  This is great, a truly great beer.

January 17th poured from 2007 vintage bottle into Dogfish snifter glass. Served cold from the fridge; allowed to naturally warm to room temperature while sipping.

Aroma: Strong hops. (Will it taste that bitter!?) 

Taste: Malty sweet complemented with hops. Sweet, sugary. Fruity esters. Brown sugar, molasses, homemade sugary caramel. Bittering citrus hops. Hint of hot alcohol. A little rough as a young beer, but shows good potential to meld and mellow with age; cant wait to try an aged Doggie Claws!

Next time I will try this starting at room temperature as Ive had recommendations to drink this beer without chilling.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 2005 vintage

dark caramel color with thin persistent cream head. almost a bit sweet with a grainy feel. very good.

2007 special edition

no head retention, little syrupy body and with mellow complex flavors. even better than the 05.

2008 Release, Tap @ Baileys Taproom... Poured ruby with an off-white head.  Aroma of tart malt and brown sugar.  Silky palate that wrapped around the tongue with a syrupy base.  Flavors of bitter barley-malt.  Alcohol presence is mild but enough to satisfy.  Other flavors of lettuce and herbs which mend with the malt and some hops to balance.  Aftertaste of sweet caramel or maybe toffee.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2008 (bottle, 2005) Pours reddish brown with some sediment and a scant off-white head.  Aroma is very strong, and displays a lot of fruit scents.  Smells of pineapple, lychee, peach, cherry skin, hops, and a substantial amount of toffee and caramel is lurking underneath the fruity smells.  Upon warming, the beer takes on a slightly sour smell, which detracts a bit from the initial aroma.  I think this is the oxidation. Alcohol also is evident as well.  The taste is pretty simple, but very good, with a huge blast of toffee and caramel, that switches to sweet cherry and yields to a slight tartness of cherry skin.  The finish is a light bitterness with lingering tastes of burnt caramel.  The mouthfeel of this beer is great, perfectly carbonated, and the beer is quite full and chewy.  A very well crafted barleywine, and the flavor really stands out here.
 bottle, thanks OSLO! On second tasting with a fresher bottle, I smell a lot of fresh roasted peanuts, with some toffee as well, and musty hops (which must be the Simcoe).  I also thought the flavor was excellent and tasted completely different than the first bottle I had.  The nuttiness was there in the flavor along with toffee, and a light bitterness that blended together very nicely.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2008 [Bottle, 05] Pours red with a little dark sediment and almost no head. Aroma has a lot of caramel, some pineapple, a hint of cherry, and something sort of vegetal. The taste is quite sweet, with alcohol, caramel malt, and a hint of the cherry again. Good mouthfeel with a fairly long, malty finish. I really enjoyed the taste of this, but the longer I drank it the less I liked the aroma. Old rating: 6/3/8/4/16=3.7  
[Bottle, ’06, drank on 10/04/08--thanks go to my sister for getting this from CA] Pours clear dark amber with no head; looks like honey.  Aroma is very nutty and quite sweet--caramel, honey, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is alcohol, also very sweet with the nuttiness in the finish, along with a little toasted malt. Good mouthfeel with a long finish. Much better than the ’05 I had, and an excellent barley wine.

Didnt write down the vintage but I bet this has to be the one I had. Nice floral and caramel in the nose. Flavor is pretty good, not heavy at all until the aftertaste. Not too hoppy, and maybe just a slight bit not agressive enough.
Bottle of the 2007.  Iced tea appearance with a thin head.  Powerful aroma of brown sugar and floral hops.  Rich, sugary sweet flavor, full of fruits.  Flirts with cloying, but still quite nice.

Doggie Claw vertical years 2007 - 2002. Thanks to drewbeerme for bringing all of these years.  All from 12 oz bottles.  Overall an interesting note is that 02 starts off as a lighter orange and the years get darker to 04 and then they get lighter again where 07 returns to the 02 color. Along with the different colored malts these beers seemed quite a bit different from one another.  But based on our tasting, Id recomend drinking this fresh.  2003 vintage. Pours a medium red orange with a tan head. Nose is sweet toffee, brown sugar, caramel, grains and butterscotch.  It kind of reminds me a sugary kids cereal.    Swirling this brings out the unnoticed notes of oxidation and paper.  Sweet flavors, alcohol, red fruit, paper.  Dry finish.  7/3/7/3/12 = 3.2 
  2004 vintage.  Pours a dark red orange with a thin tan head.  The aroma is really vegetal and oxidized but not all together bad.  Brown sugar, red fruit, cereal grains, and dark fruit.  This one is really fruity and the oxidation gets more annoying as it warms.  Flavors are sweet.  Caramels, red fruit, boozy, a charred note i nthe finish and that papery oxidation.  7/4/7/3/13 = 3.4
  2005 vintage.  Pours a clear orange red with a thin beige head.  Nose is vegetables and tropical fruits.  Sugars, caramels, and all around sweet.  Flavors are lighter than the previous vintages.  Fruit, caramels, touch of hops that are faded but contribute nicely.  Balanced well.  This one was my second favorite of the years.  The hops are in a good place and the tropical fruit is enjoyable.  7/4/8/3/14 = 3.6  
2006 vintage.  Pours a hazed orange, almost murky with no head.  Vegetable aromas, toffee, caramel, funky malts.  They smell aged and foul.  Flavors are sweet caramels, citrus, faded hops that are grassy and annoying.  Sugarry and this tastes worse as it warms up.  This was my least favorite of the night.  5/2/6/3/12 =  2.8  
2007 vintage .  Pours a clear orange yellow with an off-white head.  Nose of fresh hops, citrus, caramel, and toffee.  Those hops smell just picked off the vine.  Nice.  Sweet toffee flavors.  Red fruit, cherries, caramels, citrus, fresh hops.  The sweetness is balanced with a good dose of hops. Tasty.  This was by far my favorite of the vintages. 8/3/8/4/15 = 3.8  So even though every beer seemed to be different, Id drink this fresh.

Amber with no head.  Aroma was hops and caramel malts.  Flavor had a bit of hops but most were already faded out.  Strong caramel malty flavor with some raisin,  fig, toffee,  molasses.  Finishes syrupy with almost no carbonation.  Slightly boozy.

The color was cloudy brown/amber.  THe head was thin, off-white, and fizzy.  The aroma was pine, sweet, fermenting fruit, and verry hoppy.  The flavor was fig, fermenting fruit, sweet, pine, and hops.  The palate was smooth and full-bodied.  The finish was warm.

2007 bottle via liquidsolutions. Pours a nice orange amber. Coaxed a half finger creamy light tan head. The aroma is very fruity, sweet citrus, alcohol, grapefruit and orange, caramel. The flavor is very fruity as well, citrusy, alcohol, waxy grapefruit peel, some oranges, sweet, caramel malt. The mouthfeel is nice, full with a nice carbonation, waxy bitter and sweet. Nice finish, very delightful beer.

2007 bottle courtesy of beastiefan2k. Thank you Eugene! Pours reddish-brown with a medium sized creamy head. Aroma is very hoppy. Pine, caramel and and nondescript fruitiness. Hops are not so assertive in the taste, but they do nicely balance the beer. Toffee, peach, strawberry, hops, golden raisins, candied ginger, dates, caramel, lime, some other fruits. Medium body and pretty much perfect balance.

Bottle - Thanks to Irishboy!!!!! Pours an orange amber colour with a slight off white head. Wow, lovely honey-caramel hop aroma, really memorable aroma, quite sweet.  Theres a whole lot goingon in the flavour (in a great way) nuts, hops, caramel, some serious fruitiness, lemons, mango and apple,  caramel through and through, brilliant!!!

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2008 2006 bottle thanks to wj94... he hooked me up! Pretty good example of an American barley wine. I accidentally poured the yeast sediment into the glass and the beer looked like a chocolate milk shake..oops. Besides that, flavor is very nice with a perfectly balanced hop addition. Palate is as clean as can be expected for this style of beer with this much hop character.  Good stuff!
Deep brown body with a light white head.  Sweet malt aroma, with some dark fruit accents.  Taste is sweet with a light spice.  Ending is smooth.

Thanks to Brian for this one.  2007 bottle.  Pours a thick hazy brown and stands up a frothy beige head leaving plenty of lacing.  The fresh thick hop aroma is intense and wonderful.  A subtle spiciness hides behind.  The flavor is sweet with a pleasant dry bitterness from front to back that doesnt overwhelm but blends nicely with a walnut and raisin fruitiness.  Excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2013 Year Made 2005
4/02/2008:  Doggie Claws Baleywine Style Ale has a warm brown appearance, slight haze, and a lasting ivory head that is dense and leaves lots of lacing effects on the inside of the glass.  This beer smells of sweet citrus and rich, creamy caramel.  The aroma is balanced and inviting.  The flavor is deeply malty with lots of caramel and aged dried fruits (such as apricot), vanilla, toasted bread, faint tobacco, with some subtle citrus and herbal hoppiness in the finish.  There is a moderate level of bitterness balanced against the large sticky malty sweetness.  The lingering flavor and aftertaste has pine, is highly floral and perfumy, and beckons one back for another sip.  This beer is surprisingly tame considering its high alcohol content, yet it provides a welcomed warmth.  The thick, full body of the beer is creamy and smooth on the palate.  This is another excellend Hair of the Dog brew.  This was a 2005 bottle and it was very tasty, but I think it will continue to get even better with over the next couple of years...
12 fluid ounce bottle (Alcohol Content 10.5% by Volume) from bitbucket (Nov 2006) and luiss (Jan 2007).  Thanks guys!  I appreciate the generosity.  Rating #422 for this beer.  Score: 8/4/8/4/17=4.1
. . . . . . . . . .
8/05/2010:  Hair of the Dog Doggie Claws Barley Wine Style Ale (Bottled Conditioned)...  Aroma:  Wonderfully aged citrus hops and mouth-watering vanilla caramel.  Appearance:  Beautiful transparent copper color with a nive head of dense, beige-colored foam; Flavor:  Wow, really nice... Still plenty of well-aged citrusy hops with some nice floral notes; moderate bitterness that transitions seemlessly into a smooth, creamy, and slightly chewy toffee malt goodness; dried apricot, dried citrus peel, hints of raisin, herbal/floral tea/hops in the finish and aftertaste; a nice amount of alcohol venting in the finish.  Palate:  Medium-full to full body; creamy, smooth, and mellow; coats the mouth well.  Overall:  This has aged extremely well; FANTASTIC brew; I wish that this was available in my area or even if I had another bottle in me cellar... :(
12 fluid ounce bottle (Alcohol Content 10.5% by Volume) from luiss via trade in 2007  Thanks you!  Score:  8/5/8/4/18=4.3

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008  Bottle courtesy of Hogtown Harry - thanks Harry! 

This thick, luscious concoction has a wonderful floral aroma and a complex taste I can hardly appreciate. Its fruity and strongly herbal with a sweet finish accented with a strong bitterness. I definitely feel the warmth with this one

Bottled.
Hazy amber with a small  off-white head.
Sweet and grassy, hoppy aroma.
Oily palate with loads of sweet maltiness and grassy, fruity hops.

Bottle (07): pours a light, cloudy orange with a thin, white head, aroma of hops and citrus, taste is grapefruit and hops, finsih is dry with a subtle sweetness, this is a very nice barley wine.  Glad I have two more of these aging for later.
Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle 2007: Great complex and strong character, full of flavour and aromar. Hops, floral, citrus, matly, and a light honey lining. Great!
Bottle.  Bought it a NBD in NYC.  Pours into a deep golden color with an explosive aroma of various citrus.  Thick, heavy body, very fruity, floral, and sweet, delicious honey undertones.
pours brown really cloudy, smells brandy and honey, and apple, some bread to and tobacco. tastes same, sticky mouthfeel really amazing stuff. with loads of complexity.
Orange/amber pour with no head. Big, spicy alcoholic malt nose. Spicy malt flavor, too, with a dash of added honeyed sweetness. Mildly astringent yet syrupy on the palate. Wow. Excellent.

This was a bottle of 2007 version,it was still very raw or imature but with ageing it would be excellant,it was a hoppy and sweet tasteing beer with a hot and bitter ending,this would be much better in 2 years but i could not wait.CHEERS!

Seems to vary quite a bit from year to year. Ive had it out of vintage bottles that did not age well and some that did age well. Anything before 2003 seems a bit funky. Hoppy for a barleywine. Easy drinker that will warm you up fast!! Consistency is a problem here, past few years seem to be similar though. good beer.
Bottle (35 cl) at a Göteborg RB tasting. Hazy red amber, low head. Intense fruity malt aroma, with peaches and floral hops. Heavy body, smooth mouthfeel. Well balanced with a long bitter finish.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2015 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 3/15/200812 fl oz bottle, labeled 11% ABV.2007 version.Shady brown color, small white head. Hoppy, bitter, sticky sweet scent. Sweet, hoppy bitter taste. Big smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.8/3/8/4/16=3.9RerateAt Villagio Della Birra 2015.Hazy brown color, teal head. Orange chocolate (Romerska Bågar), malty sweet scent. Sweet, rich, some alcohol, malty taste. Sweet aftertaste. Medium full mouthfeel, medium bitterness.9/4/8/4/18=4.3

Bottle. Hazy orange/amber color, nice creamy beige head. Hoppy, grassy aroma, perfume, malt, floral notes, fruity, some pineapples. Fruity flavor, but also quite alot of grass, creamy, caramel, raisins, some perfume notes. Maybe not 100 percent true to its style, but still a great beer.
